p This question actually involves many concepts and I won't cover them all in details. For more exhaustive details, I suggest reading the whole strong Chapter 5 - Entity Managers and Persistence Contexts /strong of the JPA 1.0 specification (and the other relevant sections mentioned at the end of this answer). I will rather try to describe the most common scenario in a Java EE environment.
p Within an EJB environment, one would typically use:
ul li A em container-managed entity manager /em (must be a JTA entity manager) br ul li em transaction-scoped /em in Stateless Session Beans (SLSB) /li li em extended /em in Stateful Session Beans (SFSB) /li /ul /li li JTA Transaction Management (and not em resource-local transactions /em unless this is strong really /strong what you want) /li /ul
p Here is how a code persistence.xml /code for a JTA entity manager that uses a data source with a JNDI name code java:comp/env/jdbc/AppDataSource /code can be set up, OpenJPA being the persistence provider used by WebSphere:
pre code ?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"? persistence xmlns="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns ersistence" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns ersistence http://java.sun.com/xml/ns ersistence ersistence_1_0.xsd" version="1.0" persistence-unit name="MyPu" transaction-type="JTA" provider org.apache.openjpa.persistence.PersistenceProviderImpl rovider jta-data-source java:comp/env/jdbc/AppDataSource /jta-data-source class com.acme.domain.Foo /class class com.acme.domain.Bar /class exclude-unlisted-classes true /exclude-unlisted-classes properties !-- OpenJPA specific properties -- property name="openjpa.TransactionMode" value="managed" property name="openjpa.ConnectionFactoryMode" value="managed" property name="openjpa.jdbc.DBDictionary" value="db2" roperties ersistence-unit ersistence /code re
p For the OpenJPA properties, refer to the OpenJPA a href="http://openjpa.apache.org/builds/1.2.1/apache-openjpa-1.2.1/docs/manual/ref_guide_conf_openjpa.html#openjpa.ConnectionFactoryMode" rel="nofollow" documentation /a .
p And here is how a SLSB (using Container Managed Transactions) could get a container managed Entity Manager injected:
pre code @Stateless public class EmployeeServiceBean implements EmployeeService { @PersistenceContext(unitName="MyPu") private EntityManager em;
public Employee createEmployee(int id, String name, long salary) { Employee emp = new Employee(id); emp.setName(name); emp.setSalary(salary); em.persist(emp); return emp; } ... } /code re
p And that's all. The life cycle of the entity manager is managed by the container transparently for the application (no createEM/close) and the entity manager participates in the JTA transaction managed by the container (no explicit begin/commit).
p As previously hinted, I'm just scratching the surface, my goal is somehow to put you on the right path. To go further, I suggest grabbing a book (e.g. EJB3 in Action). Meanwhile, the references below would be a good reading.
h3 References /h3
ul li JPA 1.0 specification ul li Section 5.2.1 "Obtaining an Entity Manager in the Java EE Environment" /li li Section 5.5 "Controlling Transactions" /li li Section 5.6 "Container-managed Persistence Contexts" /li li Section 6.2.1.2 "transaction-type" /li li Section 6.2.1.4 "provider" /li li Section 6.2.1.5 "jta-data-source, non-jta-data-source" /li /ul /li /ul
h3 Resources /h3
ul li a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/techjournal/0612_barcia/0612_barcia.html" rel="nofollow" Leveraging OpenJPA with WebSphere Application Server V6.1 /a /li /ul

p It would be my guess that the log4j library that is used by the Weblogic server is used in both your web applications.
p If this is the case, both web apps would share a root classloader serving the global libraries loade by Weblogic.
p If your web apps each provide a copy of log4j, and if you can choose to load the application classes before the server classes (I don't know Weblogic but for WebSphere the setting is 'classloader mode: parent first / parent last') that might solve your problem.

p As Thilo mentioned ServletContextListeners are good for Web Applications.
p If your application does not use the Web Components then you could possibly be looking at WebSphere specific extensions too - StartUp Beans.
p a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v6r0/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.websphere.express.doc/info/exp/asyncbns/tasks/tasb_confstb.html" rel="nofollow" http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v6r0/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.websphere.express.doc/info/exp/asyncbns/tasks/tasb_confstb.html /a
p HTH Manglu

p You have an option of specifying a JVM Custom property which can use the WebSphere variables.
p The JVM Custom property can be used in your log4j.properties.
p Find below some instructions on achieving the same:
p In the admin console the path would be:
p Application servers Your Server Name Process Definition Java Virtual Machine Custom Properties
p The Customer property can use a WebSphere variable as the value for our custom property - KeyForMyCustomProperty. The WebSphere variable would use the standard pattern: ${}
p E.g strong ${MY_VARIABLE} /strong .
p The log4j properties files could access this custom property via
p log4j.appender.messageAppender.File= strong ${KeyForMyCustomProperty} /strong /Message.log
p This approach is not straightforward but achieves the desired results. You can choose to use the same key as the WebSphere variable for the JVM Custom Property then it appears as-if the WebSphere variable is used in the log4j.properties
p HTH Manglu

p If you are not planning to use EJBs and you are only interested in web services then JBoss and WebSphere are both overkill. WebSphere is expensive and takes more administrative effort because of its complexity. It supports federated server deployment and a high performance JMS bus, if you need these features.
p As has already been said, Tomcat would be sufficient for your needs. IF you want additional enterprise grade features then you could look at a href="http://www.springsource.com roducts/tcserver" rel="nofollow" Spring tc server /a .

p WMQ checks permissions on the first object encountered. So if you open an alias, the permissions are checked on the alias and not the base queue. If you open a base queue, the permissions are checked on the base queue and not on any aliases that may point to it. There is no expectation that the ability to open an alias implies an ability to open the base queue. One would need to run setmqaut against both the alias and the base queue with the appropriate permissions.
p I have a longer explanation posted here: em a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/techjournal/1003_mismes/1003_mismes.html" rel="nofollow" Understanding WebSphere MQ authorization and the setmqaut command /a /em .

LTPA Token Not Changing
java security servlets websphere

p If you can't stop the application even for a moment then you probably need to:
ol li To run both versions at the same time. /li li Direct new users to the new version and allow existing user sessions to continue against the old version /li li To be able to detect that the old version is no longer in use and hence can be stopped. /li /ol
p Each of the above is, in principle, possible but specifics of the applcations can present serious obstacles.
p Many organisations simply take the view that there can be a small hiatus in service, for example at 2:00 AM on a Sunday morning. They warn users "system going down", then stop the old version and start the new. This is much simpler than providing 100% up-time.
p One trick with this approach is that it may be possible (I know it can be done in WebSphere, don't know about JBOSS) to deply the new version of the app but not activate it. When an app takes several minutes to deploy and start this can shorten the down time.

p There's a a href="http://bit.ly/c6jlIW" rel="nofollow" tutorial on developerWorks /a which you may be interested in that describes how to run a JMS program outside of a JEE environment using WebSphere MQ.
p The question of whether you need something other than the JMS jar file is another matter. The best answer is to always use the install media supplied by the vendor. I don't know about JBoss but with IBM's implementation that install media includes diagnostic utilities and if you just grab the jar files it may not be supported. Other vendors may also have support issues if you just grab the jar files but I don't have specifics.

p Like so:
p code "file:D:\\tmp\\jms\\mycontext" /code
p There are some examples in a tutorial at developerWorks that may be useful: br em a href="http://bit.ly/c6jlIW" rel="nofollow" IBM WebSphere Developer Technical Journal: Running a standalone Java application on WebSphere MQ V6.0 /a /em

p Each directory is a sub-context which is accessed as a path. Directories are branch nodes that each contain a .bindings as their leaf node. Each branch can have exactly one leaf and zero or more additional branches.
p How you do this depends on the tool you are using. I can provide examples from WebSphere MQ's JMSAdmin tool but others will have slightly (or wildly) different syntax. Since Sun's FSContext is used in both our examples, the context traversal works the same although our administrative tools may differ in syntax.
p Using JMSAdmin you can code DEFINE CTX(subcontext_name) /code and this creates a directory under which will reside a .bindings file. You can then code CHANGE CTX(subcontext_name) /code to make that subcontext the current one. Anything you define will now be in the .bindings file within that subcontext.
p In your code you refer to the subcontext as a path. For example, after opening the initial context you can lookup an object as code subcontext_name/foo /code .
p There's more on the IBM implementation of this in the em a href="http://bit.ly/aWzJc5" rel="nofollow" WebSphere MQ Using Java /a /em manual under em a href="http://bit.ly/cPQgC2" rel="nofollow" Manipulating Subcontexts /a /em . Although the syntax may differ from what you are using, the tool is JMS compliant and uses code com.sun.jndi.fscontext.RefFSContextFactory /code so the principles will be the same.

p We have used WID for a few years now and are still learning how to really use the tool for WESB and WPS. There are pain points for the tooling (as there is for anything), but I do have to say that I am impressed with what the tooling can do (especially as it has evolved over the last few versions).
p The real trick is finding documentation on how to do the things IBM tells you you can do with the tooling. The documentation is often buried somewhere, or is lacking.
p It is also a complex tool that really requires a long time to learn and become good at.
p However, I don't think these are necessarily reasons to shy away from the tools. I like working with and learning the tool. I think it has a LOT of power that would take a lot to develop otherwise.
p Of course, you do have to watch out for the IBM sales people. They tell you that Process Server or WESB can do certain things that you really can't do unless you purchase other products in tandem such as WebSphere Business Monitor or WebSphere Service Registry ;amp; Repository. So just make sure you invest in what you need.

p The links below has more details:
p a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v6r1/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.websphere.nd.doc/info/ae/ae/rweb_custom_props.html" rel="nofollow" http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v6r1/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.websphere.nd.doc/info/ae/ae/rweb_custom_props.html /a br (look for the custom property code httpsIndicatorHeader /code )

p IBM has a href="http://www-01.ibm.com/software/awdtools/developer/application/" rel="nofollow" Rational Application Developer /a (also known as WebSphere Studio Application Developer), which is essentially extends Eclipse specific for IBM (bear in mind that in 2001 IBM donated Eclipse to the Open Source community).

p One useful tip we've used very often is to strong Disable Dynamic Reload of JSPs on Production /strong or set it to check only after a large interval of time. On development instances, this is usually set for the server to check for any changes to the JSP on each request.
p On Weblogic a href="http://download.oracle.com/docs/cd/E12840_01/wls/docs103/webapp/weblogic_xml.html#wp1038491" rel="nofollow" this is called JSP pageCheckSeconds /a and setting it to -1 ensures that the server does not check the disk to see if the JSP has changed each time. If set to 0, pages are checked on every request.
p Other servers have this too
p Glassfish a href="http://docs.sun.com/app/docs/doc/820-4343/abedz?l=ko ;amp;a=view" rel="nofollow" http://docs.sun.com/app/docs/doc/820-4343/abedz?l=ko ;amp;a=view /a
p WebSphere a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v6r1/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.websphere.express.doc/info/exp/ae/rweb_jspreloading.html" rel="nofollow" http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v6r1/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.websphere.express.doc/info/exp/ae/rweb_jspreloading.html /a
p Tomcat a href="http://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-5.5-doc/jasper-howto.html" rel="nofollow" http://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-5.5-doc/jasper-howto.html /a

p I have a WebSphere Portal application running four instances on a single box and after about 7 days of runtime there is only 130-150mb of address space free in native memory (using PMAP). Somewhere in another 7-10 days the figure drops well below 100mb (which we deem dangerous and we start to recycle the JVM). If we don't do the recycle, the JVM will eventually crash with a SIGSEGV signal.
p We've done some initial investigation into class counts and the size of JIT code. Class counts grow, but slowly from 50k onwards...about a couple hundred per day. JITC sizes get to about 210 MB after 7 days and grow about 1 MB per day after that so. In our previous experience we don't find these to be sinister values.
p What we need to to be able to break down what is in the native heap, whether it is threads (all thread counts appear normal and we have fixed thread pools), String pools, constant pools, bytecode, or whatever else.
p One lead we are trying now is reducing the reflection threshold to 0 (shutting off the bytecode accessors for reflectively created classes). This app uses a lot of pointcutting and a lot of reflection, so we're hoping there's a good chance this helps.
p Any advice is welcome.
Breaking Down Native Memory Usage Within a JVM Process on SLES
jvm websphere-portal jvm-crash

View JVM logs for further details. /code re

p In WebSphere, if you code opens two concurrent database connections, you get an error of the form:
p J2CA0086W: Shareable connection MCWrapper id 556e556e Managed connection WSRdbManagedConnectionImpl@52365236 State:STATE_TRAN_WRAPPER_INUSE from resource jdbc/abc was used within a local transaction containment boundary.
p Our framework allows us to do so (nested transactions which can be on a separate connection or multiple named transactions). I've seen lots of references to turning off some switch in WebSphere to turn on connection sharing but no details on how to set this flag. Can someone point me to the steps to achieve this?
p Specifically, if you see this article: a href="http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?rs=180 ;amp;context=SSEQTP ;amp;dc=DB520 ;amp;dc=D600 ;amp;dc=DB530 ;amp;dc=D700 ;amp;dc=DB500 ;amp;dc=DB540 ;amp;dc=DB510 ;amp;dc=DB550 ;amp;q1=j2ca0086w ;amp;uid=swg21121449 ;amp;loc=en_US ;amp;cs=utf-8 ;amp;lang=en" rel="nofollow" http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?rs=180 ;amp;context=SSEQTP ;amp;dc=DB520 ;amp;dc=D600 ;amp;dc=DB530 ;amp;dc=D700 ;amp;dc=DB500 ;amp;dc=DB540 ;amp;dc=DB510 ;amp;dc=DB550 ;amp;q1=j2ca0086w ;amp;uid=swg21121449 ;amp;loc=en_US ;amp;cs=utf-8 ;amp;lang=en /a
p under "Resolving the problem" I want to know how to set the connection pool to be unshareable (assuming that indeed solves the problem).
WebSphere local transaction containment boundary issue J2CA0086W
jdbc websphere jta

p Preface: br Most of J2EE applications are using container managed datasources through JNDI. This is fine as it gives one place for configuring these connections. br The problem arises when we want to use ORM framework (like hibernate) or something that have to know the default schema (mostly for Oracle, may be others too), which can be different from the username that is used to connect to the DB.
p I want to put the default schema name somewhere close to the datasource definition. One of the options would be to put it in JNDI. I will then manually read of from there before construction the EntityManager (well actually using Spring).
p As I found out there is a simple way to specify custom resource (in this situation it will be String with default schema name) in Apache Tomcat like this (correct me if I'm wrong):
pre code Environment name="schemaNames/EmployeeDB" type="java.lang.String" value="empl" description="Schema name of Employees Database for HR Applications" /code re
p Anyway, considering this can be done in Apache Tomcat, how should I configure the same custom JNDI resource (of String type) within other application servers:
ul li JBoss 4/5 /li li WebSphere 6/7 /li li WebLogic 9/10 /li /ul
p If you know about other servers that would be great too.
p Also, as an alternative I don't want to put the schema name in system properties or environment variables.
p Thank you very much !
hr/
p strong Update: /strong br Found some way of achieving it on JBoss. I didn't test it tho. br a href="http://forums.java.net/jive/thread.jspa?messageID=316228" rel="nofollow" http://forums.java.net/jive/thread.jspa?messageID=316228 /a
p Found information for WebLogic, but they talk about doing it programmaticly and not with configuration: br a href="http://weblogic-wonders.com/weblogic/2010/06/12/binding-objects-in-weblogic-servers-jndi-tree/" rel="nofollow" http://weblogic-wonders.com/weblogic/2010/06/12/binding-objects-in-weblogic-servers-jndi-tree/ /a br a href="http://forums.oracle.com/forums/thread.jspa?messageID=4397353" rel="nofollow" http://forums.oracle.com/forums/thread.jspa?messageID=4397353 /a
Custom resource in JNDI on different application servers
java java-ee jboss weblogic jndi

p For WebSphere you can actually set the default schema in your defined DataSource. It is a custom property called currentSchema. (ie, in V7 it is Resources JDBC Data sources your data source name Custom properties currentSchema.
p Otherwise you can use a Name Space Binding and define it there: (ie, in V7 it is Environment Naming Name Space Bindings. You can use JNDI to look this up if you don't want to programmatically set it in WebSphere.
p Can't speak to JBoss and WebLogic as I haven't worked with them.

ul li p If there's a job opening for a Java developer and not one for a .NET developer and you need work, you'll want to know Java. /li li p I'm not sure what you mean, are you asking about different Java runtimes? I think most people stick with Sun's distro. IBM has one for their RAD/WebSphere system, I don't know if it's that much different than Sun's or if it em is /em Sun's with extra libraries added on. /li li p It's older but it's still under development. Java 7 home page is here: a href="https://jdk7.dev.java.net/" rel="nofollow" https://jdk7.dev.java.net/ /a /li li p There is probably a way to use a different icon. There are widget sets that look em close /em to native, but I agree, UI is still a weakness in Java when compared to .NET. Also, if the JRE is installed, I em think /em that nowadays, double-clicking the .jar is enough to get it to run (or maybe it's a trick of the manifest file?). If you want, there are also ways to wrap the .jar in an exe that handles any startup stuff that doesn't work well in the .jar (used to be used before they were reliably double-clickable, but I don't think that's been an issue for a year or two now). /li li p Probably, because that's what my company's standardized on, and it will take a em lot /em of effort to get them to switch platforms (which would require rewriting all apps). If I were starting from scratch, I'd still probably stick with Java because I have the most experience in it for server apps. If I were writing a desktop app I'd go with .NET because that's where the majority of my desktop experience is. /li /ul

How can I teach myself websphere?

p JavaServer Faces (JSF) is a model-view-presenter framework typically used to create web applications. Using the standard components and render kit, stateful HTML views can be defined using JSP or Facelets tags and wired to model data and application logic.
h2 Information to provide when asking JSF questions /h2
p If you want accurate answers to your JSF questions, you will get better answers more quickly if you include the following information in the question:
ul li p strong Which JSF implementation and version are you using? /strong a href="http://javaserverfaces.java.net" rel="nofollow" Mojarra /a or a href="http://myfaces.apache.org" rel="nofollow" MyFaces /a ? 1.0.x, 1.1.x, 1.2.x, 2.0.x, 2.1.x or 2.2.x? Particularly the difference between 1.x and 2.x is too big to be able give a reliable answer which can cover both versions. Also, each of the JSF implementations may have its own set of bugs/quirks so that the answerer can if necessary take this into account. /li li p strong Which view technology are you using? /strong JSP or Facelets (XHTML)? /li li p strong Any faces messages or warnings/errors/exceptions in server logs? /strong If the application appears to be failing silently, make sure that you've added a code h:messages /code tag to your view to avoid that you miss any faces messages, also make sure that you have read the server logs from top to bottom. Provide this information in the question. /li /ul
h2 Minimum requirements /h2
ul li strong JSF 1.0 /strong and strong 1.1 /strong requires a minimum of Servlet 2.4 / JSP 2.0 and Java 1.4. /li li strong JSF 1.2 /strong works on Servlet 2.4, but requires a minimum of JSP/EL 2.1 which goes hand in hand with Servlet 2.5, so it requires after all Servlet 2.5. If you replace JSP 2.1 by Facelets 1.x as default view technology, then you can use JSF 1.2 on Servlet 2.4. It requires a minimum of Java 1.5. /li li strong JSF 2.0 /strong which uses by default Facelets 2.x requires a minimum of EL 2.1 which goes hand in hand with Servlet 2.5, so it requires after all Servlet 2.5. If you supply your own EL 2.1 API/impl, then you can in theory run JSF 2.0 on Servlet 2.4. It requires a minimum of Java 1.5. /li li strong JSF 2.1 /strong requires a minimum of Servlet 3.0 and Java 1.6. /li /ul
p Examples of Servlet 2.4 containers are Tomcat 5.5.x, JBoss AS 4.x and Sun Java Application Server. br Examples of Servlet 2.5 containers are Tomcat 6.0.x, JBoss AS 5.x and Glassfish 2.x. br Examples of Servlet 3.0 containers are Tomcat 7.0.x, JBoss AS 6.x and 7.x and Glassfish 3.x.
h2 Hello World /h2
p strong Preparing: /strong Depending on the server used, JSF may be already builtin (Glassfish, JBoss AS, WebSphere, etc), or not (Tomcat, Jetty, etc). If not, then you'd need to download a JSF implementation to a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4530746/mojarra-or-myfaces-jsf2-0-starter" your choice /a and drop the necessary JAR files in code /WEB-INF/lib /code folder.
p strong Controller: /strong First register the code FacesServlet /code in code /WEB-INF/web.xml /code as follows:
pre code servlet servlet-name facesServlet /servlet-name servlet-class javax.faces.webapp.FacesServlet /servlet-class /servlet servlet-mapping servlet-name facesServlet /servlet-name url-pattern *.xhtml /url-pattern /servlet-mapping /code re
p strong Model: /strong Then create a Javabean class as follows:
pre class="lang-java prettyprint-override" code package com.example;
import javax.faces.bean.ManagedBean; import javax.faces.bean.RequestScoped;
@ManagedBean @RequestScoped public class Hello {
private String name; private String message;
public String createMessage() { message = "Hello, " + name + "!"; return null; // No navigation, so goes back to same view. }
public String getName() { return name; }
public void setName(String name) { this.name = name; }
public String getMessage() { return message; }
} /code re
p strong View: /strong Finally create a Facelets file code hello.xhtml /code as follows:
pre class="lang-html prettyprint-override" code !DOCTYPE html html lang="en" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xmlns:h="http://java.sun.com/jsf/html" h:head title Hello, World! /title /h:head h:body h:form h:inputText value="#{hello.name}" h:commandButton value="Say hello" action="#{hello.createMessage}" br h:outputText value="#{hello.message}" /h:form /h:body /html /code re
p Start the server and open it by a href="http://localhost:8080/contextname/hello.xhtml" rel="nofollow" http://localhost:8080/contextname/hello.xhtml /a .
h3 Online resources and tutorials /h3
ul li a href="http://java.sun.com/javaee/javaserverfaces/download.html" rel="nofollow" JavaServer Faces Technology /a ul li a href="http://java.sun.com/javaee/javaserverfaces/reference/api/index.html" rel="nofollow" Specification and API documentation /a /li /ul /li li Oracle Java EE tutorials ul li a href="http://java.sun.com/javaee/5/docs/tutorial/doc/bnaph.html" rel="nofollow" Java EE 5 tutorial - JavaServer Faces Technology (JSF 1.2) /a - a href="http://java.net rojects/javaeetutorial/downloads/download/javaeetutorial5.zip" rel="nofollow" Tutorial examples /a /li li a href="http://download.oracle.com/javaee/6/tutorial/doc/bnaph.html" rel="nofollow" Java EE 6 tutorial - JavaServer Faces Technology (JSF 2.0) /a - a href="http://java.net/downloads/javaeetutorial/javaeetutorial6.zip" rel="nofollow" Tutorial examples /a /li /ul /li li Coreservlets.com ul li a href="http://www.coreservlets.com/JSF-Tutorial/jsf2/" rel="nofollow" JSF 2.0 tutorials /a /li /ul /li li The BalusC code ul li a href="http://balusc.blogspot.com/2011/01/jsf-20-tutorial-with-eclipse-and.html" rel="nofollow" JSF 2.0 Tutorial with Eclipse and Glassfish /a /li li a href="http://balusc.blogspot.com/2011/09/communication-in-jsf-20.html" rel="nofollow" Communication in JSF 2.0 /a /li li a href="http://balusc.blogspot.com/2010/06/benefits-and-pitfalls-of-viewscoped.html" rel="nofollow" JSF 2.0 CRUD examples /a /li /ul /li /ul
h3 Open source implementations /h3
ul li a href="https://javaserverfaces.java.net/" rel="nofollow" Mojarra /a /li li a href="http://myfaces.apache.org/" rel="nofollow" Apache MyFaces /a /li /ul

ul li a href="http:/ rimefaces.org" rel="nofollow" PrimeFaces /a ( a href="http://www.primefaces.org/showcase/" rel="nofollow" showcase /a ) /li li a href="http://jboss.org/richfaces" rel="nofollow" RichFaces /a ( a href="http://showcase.richfaces.org/" rel="nofollow" showcase /a ) /li li a href="http://icefaces.org" rel="nofollow" IceFaces /a ( a href="http://component-showcase.icefaces.org/component-showcase/showcase.iface" rel="nofollow" showcase /a ) /li li a href="http://openfaces.org" rel="nofollow" OpenFaces /a ( a href="http://openfaces.org/demo/overview/homepage.jsf" rel="nofollow" showcase /a ) /li li a href="http://myfaces.apache.org/tomahawk" rel="nofollow" Tomahawk /a /li li a href="http://myfaces.apache.org/trinidad/" rel="nofollow" Trinidad /a /li /ul

ul li a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2095397/what-is-the-difference-between-jsf-servlet-and-jsp" What's the difference between JSF, Servlet and JSP? /a /li li a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3623911/what-are-the-main-disadvantages-of-java-server-faces-2-0" What are the disadvantages of JSF 2.0? /a /li li a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4441713/migrating-from-jsf-1-2-to-jsf-2-0" Migrating from JSF 1.2 to 2.0 (what's new in JSF 2.0?) /a /li /ul

blockquote p The XSL file is supposed to transform the XSD file to OWL format.
p What freeware tool can I use apply this transformation? /blockquote
p You can use any existing free XSLT processor, but it should implement the version of XSLT as specified of the code version /code attribute of the code xsl:stylesheet /code (top) element of the stylesheet module.
p strong Here is a rather incomplete list of such XSLT processors /strong :
p strong XSLT 1.0 processors /strong :
ol li p strong MSXML a href="http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/en/details.aspx?FamilyID=28494391-052b-42ff-9674-f752bdca9582" rel="nofollow" 3 /a / a href="http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/en/details.aspx?FamilyID=3144b72b-b4f2-46da-b4b6-c5d7485f2b42" rel="nofollow" 4 /a / a href="http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/en/details.aspx?FamilyID=993c0bcf-3bcf-4009-be21-27e85e1857b1" rel="nofollow" 6 /a /strong . /li li p strong a href="http://sourceforge.net rojects/saxon/files/saxon6/6.5.5/saxon6-5-5.zip/download" rel="nofollow" Saxon 6.5.5 /a /strong /li li p strong a href="http://www.download3k.com/Web-Authoring/XML-CSS-Utilities/Download-AltovaXML.html" rel="nofollow" XML-Spy (AltovaXML) /a /strong . /li li p strong . a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.xml.xsl.xsltransform.aspx" rel="nofollow" NET XslTransform /a /strong . /li li p . strong a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.xml.xsl.xslcompiledtransform.aspx" rel="nofollow" NET XslCompiledTransform /a /strong . /li li p strong a href="http://xmlsoft.org/XSLT/" rel="nofollow" LibXMl/LibXSLT /a /strong . /li li p strong a href="http://www.garshol.priv.no/download/xmltools rod/jd.xslt.html" rel="nofollow" JD /a /strong . /li li p strong a href="http://xml.apache.org/xalan-c/overview.html" rel="nofollow" Xalan/C /a /strong or strong a href="http://xml.apache.org/xalan-j/" rel="nofollow" Xalan/J /a /strong . /li /ol
p strong XSLT 2.0 processors /strong
ol li p strong a href="http://sf.net rojects/saxon" rel="nofollow" Saxon 9.x /a /strong . /li li p strong a href="http://www.download3k.com/Web-Authoring/XML-CSS-Utilities/Download-AltovaXML.html" rel="nofollow" AltovaXML2010 /a /strong . /li li p strong a href="http://www.xqsharp.com/xqsharp/beta.htm" rel="nofollow" XQSharp (Beta) /a /strong . /li li p strong a href="http://www-01.ibm.com/software/webservers/appserv/was/featurepacks/xml/" rel="nofollow" IBM WebSphere XML Pack /a /strong (not free). /li li p strong a href="http://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/intel-soa-expressway-xslt-20-processor/" rel="nofollow" IntelÂ® SOA Expressway XSLT 2.0 Processor /a /strong (not free). /li /ol
p strong XSLT IDEs /strong
ol li p strong MS Visual Stusio (2010 or 2008) /strong -- works only with XslCompiledTransform /li li p strong a href="http://www.oxygenxml.com/" rel="nofollow" oXygen /a /strong -- works with all mentioned XSLT processors /li li p strong a href="http://sf.net rojects/xselerator" rel="nofollow" XSelerator /a /strong -- works with all mentioned XSLT processors /li li p strong a href="http://kernowforsaxon.sourceforge.net/" rel="nofollow" Kernow /a /strong : simple, Java-based IDE for Saxon. /li /ol

p I am specifically using WebSphere Integration Developer V7, but I also could be using Rational Software Architect V 7.5.1 (as I have both).
p strong Context: /strong I am trying to create a JAX-WS client to call into the Human Task Manager and Business Flow Manager services in WebSphere Process Server V7, that are exposed via JAX-WS. By default they have attached Policy sets, and provider bindings that specify some WS-Security settings (as these are not defined in the WSDL).
p I have figured out how to make it work using a Dynamic Web Project. I have been able to generate the JAX-WS client code from the WSDL. I have been able to export the policy sets and provider and client bindings from Process Server and import them into my workspace. I have been able to attach the policy set and client bindings to the client service. I have been able to set up a page and a servlet to invoke my web service (to test the client). And I have been able to set up the security settings in the deployment descriptors and websphere binding/extension files to get it work.
p This is all wonderful, but in reality we don't want an ear with a war just to expose the web service client to our other applications we are writing. We want to generate a web service client jar and package it with other applications.
p Given this line of thought I have been able to figure out how to use a regular Java Project in my IDE and generate the web service client into it. I have also been able to attach the policy set and client bindings to the client.
p strong My problem /strong is now how to I invoke this? I have created a dynamic web project with my page and servlet as before to test my client. I set up my client project as a web library dependency so it has access to the client code. I can even set up the deployment descriptors as before to force login and authenication. Only problem now is that I can't figure out how to pass the credentials to my web service now that it is in its own "jar". Before I had access to a menu to set up the TokenGenerator and CallbackHandler. Now, I don't have access to those menus as the client is not in the dynamic web project. So now I have a "disconnect" and it of course fails when trying to run it on the server.
p There has to be a way to do this. I should be able to generate a client jar and pass it what it needs. Anyone encounter this before?
How do I get the login creditials passed to the JAX-WS service client with its associated policy sets and bindings in Rational/WebSphere tooling
java-ee jax-ws ws-security rational websphere-7

p You don't need webdynpro to perform this operation. Webdynpro can be seen as a framework, and it won't be easy to integrate it into your own application.
p a href="http://help.sap.com/saphelp_nw04/helpdata/en/6f/1bd5c6a85b11d6b28500508b5d5211/content.htm" rel="nofollow" JCO /a is a java component (library) allowing the connection to a SAP system. It's quite easy to use. I've integrated the lib into application on WebSphere and Tomcat, without any problem. Some tutorials are available a href="http://www.winfobase.de/lehre/lv_materialien.nsf/intern01/1DDA0D7896600DF5C125709F0045ED23/%24FILE/Tips ;amp;Tricks_JCo_Programming.pdf" rel="nofollow" here /a , a href="http://www.vogella.de/articles/SAPJCo/article.html" rel="nofollow" here /a and a href="http://www.pdfmanual.net/thomas-g-schuessler-arasoft-gmbh-sap-java-connector-tutorial.html#" rel="nofollow" here /a
p The JCO will be used to call Remote-enabled functions on the SAP side (RFC). There are a lot of standard function available. Since you didn't gave us any information on your field, i can't really help on this. If you got access to an R/3 system, transaction BAPI can give you an idea of what already exists.
p If there is no function that correspond to your needs, then an ABBAPer can help you. If you don't need a "expensive big-name outsourcing firms", then a freelance could be the solution.
p However, if you plug into an existing SAP component (and i don't see why you would want to connect to SAP if it does not use SAP...), the apparently "simple" request can be more complex than you think.
p Regards br Guillaume

p I have an existing Java web application running through IBM WebSphere (I'm unsure of the version, but could find out if it helps) that I am looking to implement two factor authentication with.
p The system has a decent user base, and I wanted to distribute hardware tokens to the admin users of the system to ensure strong authentication.
p Minimal impact to the end user is desirable, but I'd like to avoid having the admins need to go through a VPN connection.
p Does anyone know of any products that provide Java APIs that could be directly integrated into the existing application or other products that will provide a minimal impact? I've already spoken with RSA SecurID, but their system wouldn't integrate directly and would require an infrastructure change. Any other ideas/experience is greatly appreciated.
Implementing two-factor authentication into a Java web app
java security authentication

p There is a hierarchy of Java distributions.
p Starting with Java ME -- micro edition for embeded applications on small machines like phones.
p Moveing on to JavaSE which is the standard edition most programmers are familier with.
p Then moving up to J2EE -- enterprise Edition. In addition to SE a J2EE distribution must support several Enterprise level libraries and APIs in the javax.... series of interfaces. The most important of these are the "transactional container", EJB and WS* web services APIs.
p These interfaces are implmented by third parties some open source such as GlassFish and JBOSS but mostly by proprietary (end expensive) products like WebLogic or WebSphere.

p Tomcat is merely an HTTP server and Java servlet container. JBoss and GlassFish are full-blown JEE application servers, including an EJB container and all the other features of that stack. On the other hand, Tomcat has a lighter memory footprint (~60-70 MB), while those JEE servers weigh in at hundreds of megs. Tomcat is very popular for simple web applications, or applications using frameworks such as Spring that do not require a full JEE server. Administration of a Tomcat server is arguably easier, as there are fewer moving parts.
p However, for applications that do require a full JEE stack (or at least more pieces that could easily be bolted-on to Tomcat)... JBoss and GlassFish are two of the most popular open source offerings (the third one is Apache Geronimo, upon which the free version of IBM WebSphere is built). JBoss has a larger and deeper user community, and a more mature codebase. However, JBoss lags significantly behind GlassFish in implementing the current JEE specs. Also, for those who prefer a GUI-based admin system... GlassFish's admin console is extremely slick, whereas most administration in JBoss is done with a command-line and text editor. GlassFish comes straight from Sun/Oracle, with all the advantages that can offer. JBoss is NOT under the control of Sun/Oracle, with all the advantages THAT can offer.

How to generate ORM.XML mapping files from annotations?

p Here is how I would send the data on a base64Binary object (with MTOM or SwAref) in Java at least for testing purposes (as noted with the hard coded data path).
pre obj.setContent( new DataHandler( new URLDataSource( this.getClass().getResource("/someDocument.png") )); re
p Though the normal operation would be to use a FileDataSource to pass the data. Though I am pretty sure some one would have an idea of just creating your own data source. Generally I think that would be a bad idea because the most likely implementation is to use ByteArrayInputStream which uses VM memory and would blow up badly if you are sending a large file.
p If you need to pass on a simple string for test purposes you can do the following:
pre obj.setContent( new DataHandler("test string", "text lain"); re
p Also if you are using WebSphere 7 runtimes, you may need to use the code @MTOM /code annotation in your service implementation if you notice that the data being sent only contains the message, but no attachments.

p Yes IBM JRE/JDK is typically shipped with products, not stand-alone.
p How about you get the WebSphere version that is the target for your activity and install that? Won't that give you what you need? The Single server edition is comparatively small footprint.

p I hate to answer with the obvious... but if you have a support contract with IBM, why not just call IBM support? If you haven't seen it already, IBM's main JDK page is at: a href="https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/java/jdk/" rel="nofollow" https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/java/jdk/ /a .
p However, the Windows offerings are pretty pitiful. IBM hasn't released a new JDK for the Windows platform since early-2006. That JDK was of the Java 5 generation, but there's no indication on the download page (or in the installer's file name) of an SR version. I can't install it and check for you, because of the other Windows caveat of which I hope you're aware: The IBM JDK will strong not /strong install on a Windows machine unless the installer detects an IBM BIOS.
p Given that IBM sold their PC division to Lenovo, I'm not even sure that it is possible AT ALL to install their standalone JDK on a contemporary box. I would contact IBM support if you have a contract... they might be able to tell you differently.
p Either way, the preceding answer points at another possibility. IBM frequently bundles its JDK/JRE, i without the crazy restrictions found in the standalone version /i , inside of other downloads. For instance, I know that WebSphere Community Edition (i.e. IBM's version of Apache Geronimo) comes with one. Good luck finding the specific version you need... but if you do, and don't mind the possibility of violating some license legalese, then you can just ZIP up that directory and copy it to the target machine.
p This whole topic is a damn shame. In terms of bechmarks and runtime performance, the IBM JDK/JRE has always been awesome. However, on the larger "ecosystem" level it's always sucked.

p There are countless ways to serve HTML from Java but virtually all of them rely on java servlets and java server pages (JSPs) which are Java's specification for handling web requests.
p The absolute bare minimum to get going:
ol li Install a href="http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/index.html" rel="nofollow" Java EE SDK /a ensuring to also install Netbeans and Glassfish. /li li Launch Netbeans and create a "Java Web" / "Web Application" project /li li Enter a project name, e.g. MyWebApp /li li In the Server and Settings screen, you need to Add... your server so do so. Point to the file location of your Glassfish server and enter the admin name and password /li li Ignore the framework stuff and Finish /li li NetBeans will generate a sample app and you can click straightaway on Run Main Project. It will deploy your app to Glassfish and load a href="http://localhost:8080/MyWebApp/" rel="nofollow" http://localhost:8080/MyWebApp/ /a from your default browser /li /ol
p Important things to note:
ol li p A file called web.xml tells the host server some basics about your web app. This file can contain a lot of other stuff but the default is some boiler plate. The most interesting part says code welcome-file index.jsp /welcome-file /code which means when you load a href="http://localhost:8080/MyWebApp/" rel="nofollow" http://localhost:8080/MyWebApp/ /a it will default to load index.jsp. /li li p The index.jsp is what gets loaded if you don't specify a page to the server. If you look at index.jsp it's just HTML with some JSP markup.
pre code %@page contentType="text/html" pageEncoding="UTF-8"% !DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd"
html head meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8" title JSP Page /title /head body h1 Hello World! /h1 /body /html /code re /li li p Creating new JSPs is as simple as writing HTML. Netbeans has a wizard to create a simple JSP. /li li p You can embed chunks of Java into a .jsp easily and step in and out of Java / HTML with the % % notation such as
p % for (int i = 0; i 10; i++) { % Hello %=i% br % } % /li li p Glassfish is just one possible app server. As long as you write compliant code it should functional with only minimal or zero modifications on any other implementation of Java Servlet / JSP spec. e.g. Jetty, Tomcat, oc4j, JBoss, WebSphere etc. /li li p This is just the tip of the iceberg. You can make things as simple or complex as you like. /li /ol
p Once you know the basics then it's up to you how deep you go. More advanced topics would be:
ol li Taglibraries - these can remove a lot of java clutter and are considered more correct /li li Expressions - using expressions inside JSP pages to reduce the need for messy %= notation /li li Custom servlets let you move model / business stuff into a Java class and leave the .jsp to just presentational /li li MVC web frameworks like Struts, Spring etc. /li li Security ;amp; filtering /li /ol
p It's a massive subject but it's fairly easy to do something quick and dirty.

p You can use RAFW (IBM Rational Automation Framework for WebSphere) with BuildForge. It does not make sense to use RAFW with other ci servers, since RAFW requires BuildForge.
p You have support for BuildForge and it integrates with other IBM software like ClearCase. Theoretically you have only to deal with one vendor if something in the chain does not work, but IBM has different support teams for their products and you might become their ping pong ball. :(
p Hudson is open source (if you like that), that means you can get the source and modify it to serve you better. But the release cycle is very short (about 1 week, agile development). There is a more stable version with support available now (for cash of course) from the company of the main author of Hudson.
p Hudson is currently main stream and is actively developed. I don't know how the usability of BuildForge is, but Hudson is good (not always perfect). The plugin concept of Hudson is a great plus, not sure if BuildForge has it as well.
p Currently, we are using Hudson, but BuildForge was not looked at in detail.

p So far I have seen non-Java client support only for open source message brokers like Apache ActiveMQ, JBoss HornetQ and Open Message Queue (OpenMQ).
p Are there also closed-source products like WebSphere, WebLogic or Tibco which offer non-Java access to their MOM brokers, using a documented wire protocol (opposite to a closed-source binary client library) which allows to write clients in other languages?
p This is getting more interesting as products (like WebLogic) are available in the (EC2) cloud so that developers can use the cloud instance to develop and test a client application without the need to purchase and install the full version.
Commercial JMS/MOM implementations with non-Java client support?
jms websphere weblogic tibco

p My first thought would be that if it's a quick RPC type call, provided you're calling a different web services for the The call back, I wouldn't be too concerned about a circular reference. Technically you're sending messages "by contract" So as a good practice put your contract definitions in a different project to your service implementation.
p If the .NET processing takes a bit of time it may be worth it to use a message queue and a worker service as well.
p The other consideration is to find out what MQ infrastructure they're actually using. You may be able to avoid the web services altogether as there are .NET connectors for a lot of MQ providers, like
p MSMQ (obviously)
p ActiveMQ a href="http://activemq.apache.org/nms/" rel="nofollow" http://activemq.apache.org/nms/ /a
p ;amp; WebSphere MQ a href="http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/abstracts/sg247012.html" rel="nofollow" http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/abstracts/sg247012.html /a
p Just to name a few. There are also MSMQ bridges.

p So the servlet contains and application servers come with their own JDBC drivers? Will ours conflict? Another concern is that we have developed and tested with one version of the driver and if a customer uses another version, we may have problems.
p Currently we use Spring data source beans, but are in the process of moving to JNDI lookup for the datasource.
Should JDBC drivers be included in a WAR?
java server servlets jdbc application

ul li a href="http://today.java.net ub/a/today/2006/09/19/asynchronous-jax-ws-web-services.html" rel="nofollow" Asynchronous Web Service Invocation with JAX-WS 2.0 /a /li li a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/library/techarticles/0804_sedov/0804_sedov.html" rel="nofollow" JAX-WS client APIs in the Web Services Feature Pack for WebSphere Application Server V6.1, Part 3: Using the JAX-WS asynchronous programming model /a /li /ul

p Well, the "bnd.xmi" files you deleted are the WebSphere-specific deployment descriptors, containing binding information. One of the things that are mentioned there is the name under which to bind each individual EJB home.
p You cannot possibly run an EJB module without this binding information existing em somewhere /em .
p If you delete these files (which are generated by RAD), you have to assign new binding information from within the administration console, or via your wsadmin-based deployment scripts.
p In short... lets start by recovering those files that you erased. :-)

p I encountered this as well, a while ago... and researched it to the max, including spending some time chatting with IBM's support in various levels.
p The code XMLAccess /code protocol doesn't provide for such "system-level" configuration alongside Portlet application deployment; it can only be used to install, customize and uninstall Portlet applications and related artifacts.
p If your deployment strategy involves deploying WAR files directly through code XMLAccess /code , then you will have to manually add the shared-library to the application through the WAS admin console; this will have to be done manually because, when deploying WAR files through XMLAccess, an EAR with some random name is being created by WebSphere Portal to "host" your WAR file; hence you can't script the attachment of a shared library.
p (alternatively, you may wish to add the shared library to the server's ( code WebSphere_Portal /code ) classpath)
p If your deployment strategy, instead, involves deploying Portlet applications packaged as EARs, then you're in a better position; you could automate the shared-library attachment as part of your EAR deployment process, then use XMLAccess to inform WebSphere Portal about the location, in the EAR, of your Portlet applications (which is what Michael mentioned above; it works in WebSphere Portal 6.0 as well).
p Good luck.

p The tempting mechanism is to use ThreadLocal storage, but in some App Servers this is dangerous - the App Server may use pools of Threads and a single request may be processed by different threads at different points.

p I'm not sure what you're asking here so I'm answering with the risk of completely missing the point.
p The question in the title - "Where is Web Container's default locale defined?" - well, that's up to the Web Container's vendor. Each vendor (WebSphere, JBoss, WebLogic etc) may provide their own means of setting a "default locale" for the container, so you'll have to consult the documentation of your Web container. I wouldn't be surprised if some Web Containers don't have a way to set a "default locale" to begin with.
p The second question - "I am wondering if there is anything like that" - is a bit unclear... if you meant what I think you meant, then the answer is above.
p The third question - "why is this missing from code web.xml /code ?" - no particular reason that I know of, really. Remember, the format of code web.xml /code is determined by the Servlet / JSP specification so items included there are items that the spec "drivers" felt should belong there.
p Having said that, many Application Server (and Web Container) vendors provide their own "extensions" to the Servlet / JSP spec (for example, IBM WebSphere provides quite a few extensions). Typically, such "extra settings" are coded in additional XML files under WEB-INF code or /code META-INF` or a subdirectory thereof. It is possible that your Web Container provides means for the developer to specify a "default locale" at the Web Application level... but you'll have to consult the documentation for that (or provide information about your Web Container and we'll try to help you).

p There are several reasons.
p A Java EE app server is a transaction monitor for distributed components. It provides a number of abstractions (e.g., naming, pooling, component lifecycle, persistence, messaging, etc.) to help accomplish this.
p Lots of these services are part of the Windows operating system. Java EE needs the abstraction because it's independent of operating system.
p It should also be said that the full Java EE specification isn't necessary for developing web applications. JDBC, the part of Java that deals with relational databases, is part of Java SE proper. Java EE adds on servlets, which are HTTP listeners, and Java Server Pages, which is a markup language for generating servlets. You can develop fully functional web applications using just these technologies and Java SE. Tomcat and Jetty are two servlet/JSP engines that can stand in for full Java EE app servers.
p If you take note of the fact that .NET has HTTP listeners built into the System.Net module, you realize that it's as if .NET took a page from Java and folded the javax.servlet functionality into the framework.
p If you add Spring and a messaging functionality like ActiveMQ or RabbitMQ, you can write complete applications without having to resort to WebLogic, WebSphere, JBoss, or Glassfish. You don't need EJBs or the full Java EE spec.

p Just FYI. I am guessing you are running WebSphere in "Network Deployment" mode. This behavior you're experiencing is actually by design.
p The reason for it is that the "Test Connection" button you see on the admin console, invokes the JDBC connection test from within the address-space of the em Node Agent /em . There is no way for the J2C Alias information to propagate to the Node Agent without restarting it; some configuration objects take effect in WebSphere as soon as you save the configuration to the master repository, and some only take effect on a restart. J2C aliases take effect on restarts.
p In a Network Deployment topology, you may have 10 server instances all controlled by the same Node Agent. You may restart your server instances many times, but unless you restart the Node Agent itself, the "test connection" button will never work.
p It's a known WebSphere limitation... Which also exists on version 7.0, so don't be surprised when you test it during your next migration. :-)

p If you're running your server by using Rational Application Developer, it is possible that your server is basically waiting on a breakpoint. Sounds silly, but hey, happened to me a few times before.
p If it's a regular installation:
ul li If it's a Network Deployment topology, make sure that the deployment manager and the node agent are up and running. Look at their log; they're often overlooked. /li li If it's a single-server topology, then it's possible that your debug port (7777 by default) is in use. When that happens, the debugger process never quite "connects" to WebSphere. /li /ul
p To sum it up: it starts with the logs...

p I understand it's about classloading in WebSphere. There are options in WebSphere administration about the order in which the classes are loaded at startup. You can chose to load the JAR inside your archive before those belonging to the parent (the app server is the parent) Called "parent first" or "Child first"

p Each version of WebSphere requires a particular JRE version, you cannot vary the JRE WebSphere itself uses. By default WebSphere makes many standard Java classes available to all applications, these include things such as Web Service runtime and XML parsers and so on.
p So if you need to vary the JVM itself (say from 1.5 to 1.4) you're out of luck.
p However if you need to override some of extension classes you can include the relevent JAR files in your application's EAR. Explore the "Parent First / Parent Last" setting on your application.
p IF the classes you want to use are at a higher version of Java (eg. Java 6) then again you're out of luck.
p If I understand correctly you have single cell, with some WAS 6.0 and some WAS 6.1? And you app is deployed to servers at both levels. (I view this is a pretty risky thing to do - so much complexity.) You can create WebSphere Shared Libraries. Create two such libraries, one for the 1.4 JAR and one for the 1.5. You can assign Shared Libraries either to Applications or to Servers. In your case you should assign each library to the appropriate server.

p Log4J reads its configuration exactly once (unless instructed programmatically to do otherwise) within the scope of one classloader.
p Your packaging strategy made WebSphere's Log4J load first, within WebSphere's classloader which is higher in the classloader hierarchy. Log4J initializes and loads; later, when your application (which has log4j embedded in it) makes a logging call, Log4J finds out that it is already initialized, so it doesn't even read the second property file.
p The rule of thumb that must be followed to avoid similar cases is this: If you are using a utility JAR that reads configuration and stores it statically at the classloader level (for example: Log4J; Apache FOP; and many others), then you must bundle that JAR with your application and em not /em have your code refer to AppServer-provided copies.
p Follow that rule and you'll be golden... Even under WebSphere, which, for years, has been notoriously known as having some mess with its classloading strategies.

p Very broad question, and hard to cover. But here are some papers (more or less recent, more or less biased) that you might still find interesting:
ul li a href="http://download.microsoft.com/download/b/0/5/b05a35f6-5b6b-4b7b-ba59-c020da4217d7/middleware_j2ee.pdf" rel="nofollow" Comparing Microsoft .NET and IBM WebSphere/J2EE /a (this is more a .NET vs IBM WebSphere comparison "sponsored" by Microsoft) /li li a href="http://www.theserverside.net/articles/content/MicrosoftIBM/MSCommentaryToIBMResponse.pdf" rel="nofollow" IBM Response "Comparing Microsoft .NET and IBM WebSphere/J2EE" /a /li li a href="http://research.csc.ncsu.edu/efg/oo apers/J2EE_.NET.pdf" rel="nofollow" On The Relative Advantages of Teaching Web Services in J2EE vs. .NET /a /li li a href="http://www-01.ibm.com/software/smb/na/J2EE_vs_NET_History_and_Comparison.pdf" rel="nofollow" J2EE vs. Microsoft .NET - History and Comparison /a /li li a href="http://www.mimerhellas.com/html/library/J2EE-vs-DotNET.pdf" rel="nofollow" J2EE vs. Microsoft.NET - A comparison of building XML-based web services /a /li /ul

p This is a good question. Some have incorrectly stated here that this is an apples to oranges comparison, i.e. Jboss is a container, and Spring is simply a framework, like Struts. However, the reason this is a bit confusing is that both JBoss and Spring have expanded considerably from their original, simple origins, and are thus moving closer towards each other. One easy way to understand JBoss is that the name was original "EJBoss", and it was intended on being an open-source J2EE application server, so it had the advantage over tomcat over serving as an EJB container, and thus could compete with WebSphere and other proprietary application servers.
p And Spring was an IoC framework (now referred to as "Dependency Injection"), essentially a factory for objects so that you can follow a more "loosely coupled" design.
p However, with their popularity, both products expanded. For example, JBoss now has it's own IoC container: a href="http://www.javalobby.org/java/forums/t49723.html" rel="nofollow" JBoss IoC /a
p And while Spring can run perfectly well, coexisting (mostly) happily with JBoss, it doesn't need a full-blown EJB container, it can run easily in tomcat. The whole design goal of Spring was based on the idea of lightweight design, and the use of POJOs, and the lack of requirement for a heavy-weight container, which was very contrary to EJBs, and thus would seem at odds with JBoss.
p a href="http://forum.springsource.org/archive/index.php/t-12906.html" rel="nofollow" Rod Johnson /a has pointed out that there's no reason you can't run Spring in JBoss. So what you have to decide is what parts of the two systems you want to use. But according to this article, on a href="http://www.javaworld.com/community/?q=node/3955" rel="nofollow" JBoss and Spring /a , which covers how well they adhere to standards, it does seem, depending on which technology you select, you are picking a side, as this seems to be a pretty contentious battle, and one more indication that the Java world is somewhat divided within itself.

p It also depends on the server. JBoss will give you empty Strings, but WebSphere will give you null. It's a real PITA. I'm sure there's some standard out there that says one way or another (my money would be on JBoss being the correct implementation) but you should code for both possibilities.

p I have done some significant work around this subject with one of my clients. In a nutshell (which I believe should help you):
p strong If you were to use configuration files /strong , placing configuration files inside the EAR (through exploding / re-packaging) has the drawback of having your EAR files non-portable between different environments (for example, QA environments vs. Production environments). Over time, this increases overhead and there's always the odd chance of confusion between environments.
p Alternatively, you could place these files in a separate directory and add that directory to your server's classpath. This is done differently in each application server; in WebSphere, this is done using the "shared libraries" facility.
p An approach that worked for us better, over the long run, is to use what J2EE technology actually designated to use for such tasks - using code resource environment entries /code , accessible via standard JNDI mechanism under the code java:comp/env /code namespace.
p I would prefer the resource-environment entries' approach over anything else... after trying out pretty much any possible solution.
p Actually what I found odd was if I don't put an code @MTOM /code the resulting message never returns a mutli-part message. However, the web service still accepts the MTOM data in WebSphere.

p I'm not as familiar with Tomcat, but in WebSphere we can set up connection pools to prepare a certain number of connections.
p Also, are you mainly worried about reads or the same number of writes?
p Plus, you may also want to have the database "split" depending on region etc. This way there is no single heavy load across the entire database, but it can then be split and even load balanced.
p There is also the "NoSQL" databases to look into as well. Maybe something to consider. Just ideas to help out.

p There seems to be only a handful of JVMs that are implementations of the a href="http://www.rtsj.org/" rel="nofollow" Real-Time Specification for Java (RTSJ) /a . The Sun/Oracle Java Real-Time System is over $6000 and IBM's real-time WebSphere is over $7000, so many Java developers may never have the opportunity to use either of them. Oracle's JRockit seems to be a free real-time Java implementation with predictable, deterministic behavior, although I am not sure, since their documentation is pretty heavy on marketing language. Other smaller real-time JVMs seem risky by virtue of being developed by small organizations and having smaller user-bases.
p Which real-time JVMs are preferred? Which are most used, trusted, and loved by developers?
Which real-time (RTSJ) JVM is most preferred?
java jvm real-time rtsj

p There is a known issue with WAS v7 connecting to WMQ V6 where MDBs do not reconnect. The APAR mentions failures after a WMQ outage but other types of failure can result in similar behavior.
p In general, the advice is to move to WMQ v7 since WMQ V6 is out of service as of September 2011. The fix was released in v7.0.1.1 and later. No v6 fix pack is listed for delivery of this APAR, although it doesn't mention why. So if you cannot upgrade to v7.0.1.1 or later, then obtain via a PMR and apply IC64098 and see if that solves the problem.
p References: br a href="http://bit.ly/bSx9lc" rel="nofollow" PSP #1316899: /a Information about using the WebSphere MQ messaging provider for WebSphere Application Server Version 7.0 br a href="http://bit.ly/IC64098" rel="nofollow" IBM IC64098 /a : APPLICATION DOES NOT AUTOMATICALLY RECONNECT TO THE QUEUE MANAGER IF CONNECTION IS LOST WHEN USING THE MQ RESOURCE ADAPTER

p (Unless you work for IBM) there is no way to download the IBM JDK separately. It's shipped with the IBM Rational Suite of Software IBM develops.
p The IBM JDK comes also with IBM Java Profiler (which isn't free).
p The Eclipse Platform that is found here a href="https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/eclipse/downloads/helios/#download" rel="nofollow" https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/eclipse/downloads/helios/#download /a is similar to the Eclipse download found on the Eclipse Site. IBM makes it easier for those who can't afford WebSphere Application Developer or Rational Application Developer (which are both Eclipse flavour) to use Eclipse.

p strong Transaction Managers and Websphere: /strong
p Websphere does not use the typical jndi standard when supplying the transaction manager. Spring has worked around this by providing the org.springframework.transaction.jta.WebSphereUowTransactionManager that you can use to lookup the websphere transaction manager.
p strong Datasource and Isolation Levels /strong
p You typically cannot change the isolation level of a datasource and I know you cannot change it when connecting from websphere to DB2 database (it's set as a parameter on the datasource configuration). The allowCustomIsolationLevels flag lets you select different data sources for different requested isolation levels..
p See a href="http://static.springsource.org/spring/docs/3.0.x/javadoc-api/org/springframework/transaction/jta/JtaTransactionManager.html#setAllowCustomIsolationLevels%28boolean%29" rel="nofollow" here /a and a href="http://static.springsource.org/spring/docs/3.0.x/javadoc-api/org/springframework/jdbc/datasource/lookup/IsolationLevelDataSourceRouter.html" rel="nofollow" here /a

p At my place of work we used to use Genesys, but we changed to Nortel for CTI ;amp; TAPI, and IBM WebSphere Voice Response for the user experience. I haven't developed IVR stuff for the other platforms so I can't really say if this one is better than the others, but I can say that our IVR gets a ton of calls and it is rock solid.

p The issue with this is that the WebSphere itself using commons-logging so what is happening is that you are picking up the application server's common logging properties file. Try and change the classloader order for the module to "Load application classes first", this should mean that when your application starts up it grabs its own logging configuration rather than the servers.

p are you using listener ports or activation specs? I don't use JBoss, I use WebSphere, but I found that under the listener port area in WebSphere you can set the max retry count. Also perhaps there is a spot in your administration console where you could change the logging levels so it doesn't spam you? Lastly I would look for a property in your message header called retryCount (or create one if you don't have one). Then use that and check for it in your bean. If it reads it and you have failed N times, then automatically forward to the DLQ without JBoss doing it for you. Might save you some headache.

p The values are the paths and password for the JKS. For example,
p code java -cp "%CLASSPATH%" -Djavax.net.ssl.trustStore="C:\Program Files\IBM\WebSphere MQ\key.jks" -Djavax.net.ssl.keyStore="C:\Program Files\IBM\WebSphere MQ\key.jks" -Djavax.net.ssl.keyStorePassword=password com.ibm.examples.JMSDemo -pub %* /code
p Assuming this is WebSphere MQ and the keystore/truststore are configured with the right objects, this is all that is required.

p I have a web application that runs on the WebSphere application server (WAS 7). In one of the applications, as part of a servlet that runs when the application starts, I create a ServerSocket.
p This is running in a large scale production environment and has worked for many years.

p I am doing work on jsfunit, and i am using WebSphere6.1 application server so can anyone give me answer that is it compatible for JSFunit or i need to do some changes in my server configuration? if possible send me the example?
p Thanks Vinod
Can i use WebSphere 6.1 for JSFunit?
jsf jsfunit

p The "correct" one here is basically using the "default" JRE defined to RSA.
p The "incorrect" points to a particular JRE. That particular JRE isn't installed on your system, probably because you didn't install the WebSphere Application Server 6.1 compile-time libraries during the RSA installation process.
p Have you recently migrated your projects, or are using a different flavor of RAD / RSA than you used to? I have seen this happen so many times before. RAD / RSA are notorious for "surprising" developers with considerably-stupid "migration" processes.

p Use Spring's Executor abstraction. And if you are within a app server then I suggest you use application server's work-manager (spring supports it). For e.g. WebSphere app server and Weblogic both support registering the workmanagers in JNDI. You can then pass the jndi name to spring. a href="http://static.springsource.org/spring/docs/3.0.x/spring-framework-reference/html/scheduling.html" rel="nofollow" Task Executors /a

p strong Update (March 2012): Oracle appears to have quietly disassembled their JavaRTS development team. /strong
p There isn't a good answer to this question. There certainly isn't enough critical mass to say there's a current most-popular RT JVM.
p US Defense systems I'm aware of use s JavaRTS, /s IBM's WebSphere RT, and PERC. Aviation platforms use aicas JamaicaVM. Most of those folks haven't been too concerned about licensing costs, to date. They are concerned by much higher program risks. I've worked with a number of these programs, and I find that the products are of high quality, and there is (at times extraordinary) support from the vendors.
ul li AN/FPS-85 radar uses a href="http://java.sys-con.com/node/548067" rel="nofollow" JavaRTS /a , and though this is a relatively low count, it's a rather high criticality application /li li US Navy's a href="http://www.aonix.com r_10.11.06a.html" rel="nofollow" Aegis Weapon System uses PERC /a /li li US Navy's a href="http://www-03.ibm.com ress/us/en ressrelease/21033.wss" rel="nofollow" DDG-1000 uses IBM WebSphere RT /a /li li a href="http://www.altsoftware.com/company-and-resources/media ast_news/alt-software-and-aicas-partner.html" rel="nofollow" aicas' JamaicaVM is in use in avionics /a platforms, but they are understandably coy about specifics /li /ul
p Many of the vendors have focused on specific clients or domains, and their designs and support infrastructure tend to fall in line with that. If you have a specific application profile in mind, maybe we can get you a better answer.
p The high licensing costs you cite reflect the high expectations users of these products have, and the relatively low density of the demand. The developer community (such as it is) is also more fragmentary because systems with real-time or safety-critical constraints are typically of greater sensitivity (defense, aviation, SCADA) or protected proprietary value (automotive) or both. One excellent forum for real-time Java theory and practice is the annual a href="http://d3s.mff.cuni.cz/conferences/jtres2010/" rel="nofollow" JTRES conference /a , which is a close-knit group of academics and technically-savvy vendors.
p Related on SO: a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4070258/references-to-java-programs-coded-using-primitives-only/4073915" Primitives-only in Java /a , a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1837635/who-uses-real-time-java" who uses RTSJ /a .

p I am developing some web services that must be implemented using JAXWS, and that must run on WebLogic 10.3, WebSphere 7 and Tomcat 5.5. Furthermore, installation of the services must be completely self-contained to avoid conflicts with any other applications in the container. WebLogic and WebSphere are solved, but tomcat gives me trouble.
p Enabling tomcat for jaxws by using JAXWS-RI is functional, but installation of additional jars (jaxws.jar, jaxb.jar) in tomcat or jre is to be avoided.
p Shipping my application with axis2 embedded inside the war is better, but the services get funny URIs. Take for example this service:
p PortType generated with wsimport:
pre code @WebService(name = "AuthenticationServicePortType", targetNamespace = "http://impl.auth.webservice.my.company") @XmlSeeAlso({ company.my.exposed.xsd.ObjectFactory.class, company.my.webservice.auth.impl.ObjectFactory.class }) public interface AuthenticationServicePortType { /code re
p Implementation:
pre code @WebService( portName = "AuthenticationServicePort", serviceName = "AuthenticationService", targetNamespace = "http://impl.auth.webservice.my.company", wsdlLocation = "WEB-INF/wsdl/AuthenticationService.wsdl", endpointInterface = "company.my.webservice.auth.impl.AuthenticationServicePortType" ) public class AuthenticationServiceImpl implements AuthenticationServicePortType { /code re
p In WebSphere, WebLogic and tomcat+JAXWS-RI this service becomes available at the uri
pre code http://localhost/MyProduct/services/AuthenticationService /code re
p However, with axis2 embedded inside the war, the service becomes available at the uri
pre code http://localhost/MyProduct/services/AuthenticationService.AuthenticationServicePort /code re
p Because this is an upgrade of an existing service with a wide installed base, this change is not acceptable.
p Configuring the service via services.xml has been removed from axis2's jaxws support, so that is dead end.
p Using Apache CXF instead of Axis2 is not a good solution because it could create a support nightmare.
p The tomcat version of web.xml looks like this:
pre code ?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"? web-app version="2.4" xmlns="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/j2ee/web-app_2_4.xsd" description My web service /description display-name MyProduct /display-name servlet description JAX-WS endpoint for MyProduct /description display-name MyProduct /display-name servlet-name MyProduct /servlet-name servlet-class org.apache.axis2.transport.http.AxisServlet /servlet-class /servlet
servlet-mapping servlet-name MyProduct /servlet-name url-pattern /services/* /url-pattern /servlet-mapping /web-app /code re
p I also modified axis2.xml to make it look for annotated classes among regular classes:
pre code deployer extension=".class" directory="classes" class="org.apache.axis2.jaxws.framework.JAXWSDeployer" /code re
p Two kinds of solutions would help:
ul li A way of embedding JAXWS-RI inside the war, so nothing has to be installed in tomcat /li li A way to get Axis2 to deploy the services at regular URI's (same as other containers) /li /ul
JAXWS, Axis2 and Tomcat service URLs
tomcat jax-ws axis2

p Has anyone had any experience with a JNDI .bindings file becoming corrupted under WebSphere with extraneous sequences of \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000 characters? This happens infrequently, and when it does, we remove the .bindings file and it is regenerated correctly without the \u0000 characters. We don't know the root cause though.
JNDI .bindings file gets corrupted with \u0000
jndi corrupt

p Unless the application is to join a group of existing applications that are largely one of these two types, there is no simple answer.
p Maintenance cost will be driven by factors such as:
ul li availability of skilled labour for the technology/development platform (i.e. are there more ASP.NET developers available or J2EE?) /li li maintenance costs for the underlying technology platform (e.g. there are many options on Java such as Oracle Solaris on Oracle hardware vs RedHat Linux on Dell hardware vs Debian Linux on Amazon's Cloud service) /li li sophistication of the development tools and supporting third party components available for the specific problem domain (e.g. if the application was heavily reliant on interoperable integration with a partner's WebSphere environment then Java may be more sensible, while if the application needs to generate complex Microsoft Office documents then ASP.NET may be a better option) /li /ul
p If you're not sure, engage a consultant specialising in architecture to assist. Doing so is likely to save a lot of money in the long run, particularly with larger applications.

p The issue I was running into was two fold.
ol li p The configuration for the security context exists in the web.xml. It must be present the installed war at application install time. We had the config commented out so developers wouldn't need to give credentials when debugging and I was trying to uncomment after deploying the war. /li li p You must map roles to your security realm at install time. We have a script that deploys the applications and without modification, the roles were not mapped and the ability to map roles after install was not available. Even installing from the ibm console site, you have to select detailed install and map groups at install time or the link to map is not available. /li /ol
p Once I got the security installed and the redirect to the login page working, we had one other issue. I'm not sure if this is an issue with our JSF code or not, but I could not redirect to a page that used JSF within WebSphere (works fine with Tomcat). Our solution was to just use a jsp page for the authentication page.
p Hope this helps someone else.

p But this is not JEE compliant and specific to WAS only.

p JEE application servers typically use multiple classloaders to isolate applicaitons from each other, and allow new versions of one application to be deployed without affecting other apps.
p You get patterns such as several WAR files and one EJB file in an EAR with a hierarchy of classloaders, each WAR having it's own.
p This does lead to duplication as you describe, but this is not necesserily a bad thing. It means that you can even have different versions of the same JARs deployed a the same time, and that may actually be benficial, allowing incremental migration to new versions.
p Some application servers (WebSphere for exmaple) have explicit support for a shared library concept, and I do use that.
p Be wary of just popping JARs into arbitrary classpaths, you run the risk of destabilising the app server itself.

p As with many aspects of WebSphere Commerce, the main (/only) reason to stick with their OOB Dojo implementation turns out to be the IBM sales team.
p If you stray outside the IBM guidelines your CEO will go to some Commerce open day and see some whizzy 3D animated shopping basket and decide that he must spend some obscene sum of money to buy the latest featurepack and you'll be the poor sap who has to explain that the whizzy 3D animated shopping basket that he's just forked out for won't work because it conflicts with the jQuery actions on such-and-such page etc. etc.
p I feel dirty offering the political answer on a technical site. Perhaps I have been turned to the dark side... But I've also been on teams that have ditched Dojo for the (at the time) far leaner jQuery libraries and watched the political carnage unfold later...
