p It used to be that the JMS a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r0/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.mq.javadoc.doc/WMQJMSClasses/com/ibm/mq/jms/MQConnectionFactory.html" rel="nofollow" MQConnectionFactory /a had pooling built in, but it seems that in version 7, it has been removed.
blockquote p Set the use of ConnectionPooling in earlier versions of the WebSphere MQ classes for JMS. This method is retained for compatibility with older MQJMS applications, but, because this Connection Pooling functionality has been removed from version 7, setting this property will have no effect. /blockquote
p In the absence of anything else, you can use a href="http://commons.apache.org ool/" rel="nofollow" Apache Commons Pool /a . Same idea as DBCP (which uses Pool) but for non JDBC objects.

p The "JCA Connection Pools" represents the totals for the "JMS Connection Factories" and "WebSphere MQ JMS Provider." (Notice that the sum of these two individual stats equals the stats in the "JCA Connection Pools.")
p Also, the connection pooling settings are for em each /em configured connection factory, and the "JMS Connection Factories" and "WebSphere MQ JMS Provider" statistics represent the sum for all submodules (i.e. for all connection factories). Given that you stated "I've set the connection pool for em both /em my FACTORY" (emphasis mine), I'm assuming that you actually have two different connection factories, which could explain why these values are higher than each individual connection factory's max connections.
p If you are using the em Performance Viewer /em in the ISC, you should be able to expand each module to view the individual submodules. If you are checking the stats through code wsadmin /code , you will need to grab the substats ( code getSubStats /code ) for the JCA modules.

p We have a typical situation.
p Two java service components are being developed in parallel.
p Lets say A and B. A is JMS application that picks up message from queue and does some business rules processing. A uses B for database persistence. B does all database operations.
p So, that means B's methods are called from A always. A is developed using a href="http://static.springsource.org/spring/docs/current/javadoc-api/org/springframework/transaction/jta/WebSphereUowTransactionManager.html" rel="nofollow" code WebsphereUowTransactionManager /code /a (server specific subclass of JtaTransactionManager) while B is using JpaTransactionManager. A uses programmatic transaction model (yes, we need it) while B uses declarative model (@Transaction annotation). Both were developed using separate bean configurations.
p Now, in integration, we are facing transaction exceptions. I believe it is due to mis-match between transaction models of A and B. Theoritcally, B will use A's transactional context which is programatic. This makes B's declarative model redundant.
p So, the question is what should be the correct combined transaction strategy to integrate A and B?
p My understanding - A uses programmatic transactions so B also must use programmatic model.
spring transactions strategy for component integration
spring transactions

p You can get the jars one at a time. I recommend using a href="http://www.jarvana.com/jarvana/" rel="nofollow" Jarvana /a to find what jars given files come from and then just search for the jar and you'll find the site. It's not pretty, but frankly I've not seen a better way... even with Maven really. Although, with Maven you should use a href="http://mvnrepository.com/" rel="nofollow" Mvn Repository /a to search for the dependency you need.
p If you are not using Maven, have you looked at a href="http://ant.apache.org/ivy/" rel="nofollow" Apache Ivy /a ? It integrates with Ant nicely and will the dependency resolution just like Maven does.
p You do realise though, that these jars are just of interfaces, and the the implementations of the are provided by the Java EE containers (e.g. Glassfish, JBoss, WebSphere etc) right?

p It a href="http://developer.apple.com/library/ios/#documentation/NetworkingInternet/Conceptual/RemoteNotificationsPG rovisioningDevelopment rovisioningDevelopment.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40008194-CH104-SW1" rel="nofollow" looks like /a you both have to use a client SSL certificate and trust the server SSL certificate, correct?
p In WebSphere 6.1, both are managed under:
p code Security /code code SSL Certificate and Key Management /code code Key stores and certificates /code
p with the client certificate further under:
p code xxxDefaultKeyStore /code code Personal certificates /code
p and the server certificate under:
p code xxxDefaultTrustStore /code code Signer certificates /code
p For the client certificate, use the code Import /code or code Receive /code buttons. For the server, the easiest approach is the code Retrieve from port /code button.
p I confess that I haven't used client-side certificates under WAS before, so you might have additional configuration there, I expect under the code Security /code code SSL Certificate and Key Management /code code Dynamic outbound endpoint SSL configurations /code page to explicitly specify use of your newly-imported client-side certificate when communicating with the APNS server(s).

p Another option for WebSphere is the free a href="http://www-01.ibm.com/software/webservers/appserv/was/featurepacks/dynamicscripting/#" rel="nofollow" Feature Pack for Dynamic Scripting /a , which provides PHP support. I have no idea how the PHP support works, though; for instance whether you could just drop in a Drupal installation under it.

p The easiest approach is to do nothing: WebSphere Application Server v8 supports EJB 2.1 just as well as v7. Why risk changing something that isn't broken?

p Regrettably, there is no support for WebSphere 6.1 under Eclipse. As you noted, WebSphere 6.0 was supported, and now WebSphere a href="http://marketplace.eclipse.org/content/ibm-websphere-application-server-v70-developer-tools-eclipse-36-only" rel="nofollow" 7 /a , a href="http://marketplace.eclipse.org/content/ibm-websphere-application-server-v80-developer-tools-eclipse-36-only" rel="nofollow" 8 /a , and a href="http://marketplace.eclipse.org/content/ibm-websphere-application-server-v85-developer-tools-beta-1" rel="nofollow" 8.5 /a are supported, but 6.1 was not (except in the IBM-branded version of Eclipse, Rational Application Developer).

p WebSphere Application Server doesn't use Port 8080 by default. If port 8080 indicates that Glassfish is running, then you must have installed and started Glassfish. These are two completely different application servers / products.
p The WAS console runs on port 9060 by default, so you may be able to see if you have also started WAS by going to a href="http://localhost:9060/ibm/console" rel="nofollow" http://localhost:9060/ibm/console /a . Also, you can check your running processes (via Windows Task Manager, for example) and installed programs (via Windows Programs and Features, or a simple Explorer search) to determine what might be running/installed.
p If, after installing/starting WAS, you still want to change your port numbers, you can do this by going to "Servers Server Types WebSphere application servers [appserver] Ports" (for individual application servers; also these instructions are for WAS 7.0, but should be em similar /em if you're using a different version). If you are using WebSphere Application Server ND, there are actually a number of different processes/application servers running at any given time (deployment manager, nodeagents, individual app servers) that open up ports as well. I wouldn't recommend changing any of the default port values unless you are sure that you have a conflict though.

WebSphere MQ: Consuming Messages in Batches

p A remote queue in WebSphere MQ terms is simply a queue that exists on another queue manager. You do not need another server, nor even another account. Just define two queue managers on the same server, under the same account and connect them.
pre code crtmqm QMGR1 strmqm QMGR1
crtmqm QMGR2 strmqm QMGR2
runmqsc QMGR1 DEFINE LISTENER(TCP.1414) TRPTYPE(TCP) PORT(1414) CONTROL(QMGR) START LISTENER(TCP.1414)
DEFINE QL(QMGR2) USAGE(XMITQ) TRIGGER DEFINE CHL(QMGR1.QMGR2) CHLTYPE(SDR) TRPTYPE(TCP) + CONNAME('127.0.0.1(1415)') XMITQ(QMGR2) REPLACE * Next one not needed for the demo but usually there's * a channel for reply messages to return on. DEFINE CHL(QMGR2.QMGR1) CHLTYPE(RCVR) TRPTYPE(TCP) REPLACE
START CHL(QMGR1.QMGR2)
DEFINE QREMOTE(TARGET.QUEUE) RQMNAME(QMGR2) RNAME(TARGET.QUEUE) END
runmqsc QMGR1 DEFINE LISTENER(TCP.1415) TRPTYPE(TCP) PORT(1415) CONTROL(QMGR) START LISTENER(TCP.1415)
DEFINE QL(QMGR1) USAGE(XMITQ) TRIGGER DEFINE CHL(QMGR2.QMGR1) CHLTYPE(SDR) TRPTYPE(TCP) + CONNAME('127.0.0.1(1414)') XMITQ(QMGR1) REPLACE DEFINE CHL(QMGR1.QMGR2) CHLTYPE(RCVR) TRPTYPE(TCP) REPLACE
DEFINE QL(TARGET.QUEUE) END /code re
p You can have as many QMgrs on one machine as resources allow. I have seem people with as many as 20 QMgrs on a server but one is the recommended number.
p If you have WMQ v7.0 or earlier you can have only one installation of WMQ on a machine. If you have v7.1, which is current as of this writing, then it is possible to have multiple installations on the same machine. But either way, all QMgrs on that machine run under the code mqm /code account (or on Windows, whatever account you installed and run WMQ under).
Access to the httprequest object within POJO called by WebSphere Command/JSP/etc?
session websphere httprequest commerce web-container

p I would use EJB 3 TimerService for this purpose.
p The problem with asyncbeans is that they are not persistent.
p EJB3 Timers are persistent (file store by default) and can be configured to use a custom WebSphere scheduler if you need something special.
p Usually the defaults are enough.
p Check this tutorial: a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/5/tutorial/doc/bnboy.html" rel="nofollow" Using the Timer Service /a

p I encountered this problem once on a test system. It occurs if WebSphere (incorrectly) determines that the EJB actually runs in the local server. In my case this occurred with two servers running on the same host and configured with the same server name (server1). Unfortunately I don't know any solution (other than reinstalling one of the servers with a different server name).

p Here is an article from IBM entitled a href="http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg1PK85322" rel="nofollow" "Slow Deployment of Applications with Multiple Java Classes Might Occur on WebSphere Application Server Version 7.0" /a that describes some approaches that you can take to help reduce the deployment time of your application. The article focuses primarily on the new support in WAS 7 for Java EE 5, which requires WAS to scan all modules, jars, and classes for annotations during deployment.
p It suggests the following (seemingly in order of preference):
ul li downgrade to J2EE 1.4 modules /li li utilizing the "metadata-complete" attribute in EE 5 module deployment descriptors /li li moving utility jars to shared libs /li li moving utility jars from WEB-INF/lib to the root of the EAR /li /ul
p If your application is relatively small and doesn't have any Java EE 5 modules, then this article might not be as applicable. It's possible that there may be some other WAS or OS configuration you could tune to help deployment performance slightly, but if all these factors are identical, it may just be possible that WAS 7 deployment is in fact slower than WAS 6.1. If you suspect a major downgrade in performance, the article doesn't help and there are no other variables, you might consider contacting IBM support.

p To remotely connect to WAS, first, from the WebSphere Integrated Solutions Console:
ol li Navigate to the application server's Debugging Service: ul li em Servers Server Types WebSphere application servers [serverName] Debugging Service /em /li /ul /li li Check the "Enable service at server startup" checkbox /li li Add/modify the "JVM debug port" if necessary (the port must not already be in use on the server) /li li Add/modify the "JVM debug arguments" if necessary (this may already appear by default): ul li pre -Xdebug -Xnoagent -Djava.compiler=NONE -Xrunjdwp:transport=dt_socket,server=y,suspend=n,address=7777 re /li /ul /li li Apply the changes, Save the new configuration, and Restart the application server /li /ol
p Then, from the Eclipse IDE:
ol li Open the "Debug" dialog (e.g. em Run Debug Configurations... /em ) /li li Right-click "Remote Java Application" and select "New" /li li Configure the Remote Java Application: ol li Name the debug configuration /li li Browse to select the project to debug (optional) /li li Use the "Standard (Socket Attach)" Connection Type /li li Specify the hostname of your WAS server /li li Specify the port number that was set in the WAS debug options /li /ol /li li Click Apply /li li Click Debug /li /ol
p (These instructions are for WAS 7.0, but should be similar for other versions.)

p There are a number of detailed recommendations available in the WebSphere MQ Performance Reports. These are published as SupportPacs. If you start at the a href="http://ibm.co/SupptPacs" rel="nofollow" SupportPac landing page /a , the ones you want are all named MPxx and are available per-platform and per-version.
p As you will see from the SupportPacs, WMQ out of the box is tuned for a balance of speed and reliability across a wide variation of message sizes and types. There is considerable latitude for tuning through configuration and through design/architecture.
p From the configuration perspective, there are buffers for persistent and non-persistent messages, an option to reduce disk write integrity from triple-write to single-write, tuning of log file sizes and numbers, connection multiplexing, etc., etc. You may infer from this that the more the QMgr is tuned to specific traffic characteristics, the faster you can get it to go. The flip side of this is that a QMgr tuned that tightly will tend to react badly if a new type of traffic shows up that is outside the tuning specifications.
p I have also seen tremendous performance improvement allocating the WMQ filesystems to separate spindles. When a persistent message is written, it goes both to queue files and to log files. If both of those filesystems are in contention for the same disk read/write heads, this can degrade performance. This is why WMQ can sometimes run slower on a high-performance laptop than on a virtual machine or server of approximately the same size. If the laptop has physical spinning disk where the WMQ filesystems are both allocated and the server has SAN, there's no comparison.
p From a design standpoint, much performance can be gained from parallelism. The Performance reports show that adding more client connections significantly improves performance, up to a point where it then levels off and eventually begins to decline. Fortunately, the top number of clients before it falls off is VERY large and the web app server typically bogs down before WMQ does, just from the number of Java threads required.
p Another implementation detail that can make a big difference is the commit interval. If the app is such that many messages can be put or got at a time, doing so improves performance. A persistent message under syncpoint doesn't need to be flushed to disk until the code COMMIT /code occurs. Writing multiple messages in a single unit of work allows WMQ to return control to the program faster, buffer the writes and then optimize them much more efficiently than writing one message at a time.
p The em a href="http://ibm.co/MiceAndElephants" rel="nofollow" Of Mice and Elephants /a /em article contains additional in-depth discussion of tuning options. It is part of the developerWorks a href="http://ibm.co/dWMMIdx" rel="nofollow" Mission:Messaging /a series which contains some other articles which also touch on tuning.

p An XADataSource API provides two-phase commit to achieve this in a distributed environment. You need to make your DataSource Wrapper class using this API and the rest would be taken care by the API itself.
p XA is best used with and app server like JBoss or WebSphere etc. But you can configure it in non-managed environments too.

That's em per enterprise /em , not per person, by the way. /li li If your company is an IBM Business Partner and is planning to obtain IBM certification for many developers, the a href="https://www-304.ibm.com artnerworld/wps/servlet/ContentHandler w_com_vpo_value_package" rel="nofollow" Value Plan Option /a costs $2k but reimburses up to $6k of testing fees and includes the Software Access Catalog. /li /ul
p I am a product manager for WebSphere MQ so I'm always interested in whether potential users are able to get access to WebSphere products that they need for trial or development purposes. If none of the options here meets your needs, and this goes for anyone reading this post, I'd invite you to contact me directly using the address in my profile.

p You don't want to edit plugin-cfg.xml manually (except in very rare cases). The hostnames in there come from the Aliases defined for the WebSphere Virtual Hosts.
p By default, those usually have *:80, so changing the server domain name would require no changes at all. For instance:
pre code VirtualHostGroup Name="default_host" VirtualHost Name="*:9080" VirtualHost Name="*:80" VirtualHost Name="*:9443" VirtualHost Name="*:5060" VirtualHost Name="*:5061" VirtualHost Name="*:443" /VirtualHostGroup /code re
p If the WebSphere Virtual Host that your application is using does specify an Alias with a particular domain name, you just change the domain name there.

p You will have to be a bit more specific if you want a concrete example: do you want to do it with a Web Console, JMX or programmatically. ActiveMQ btw creates queues on demand, whenever you need one, not like WebSphere MQ where you will get an exception if the queue does not exist.

p I just found that there is fix that reduces the startup time. The fix is available for Version 6.1.x and Version 7.0.x
p a href="https://www-304.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg1PK69220" rel="nofollow" Fix Details /a
p Here is the description of the fix pack: â€œFor very large applications with a large number of files and directories, application startup time has increased by a significant amount when moving from v5.0 to v5.1/v6.x. This is due to new code in later versions of WebSphere that search the application installation directories for TLD (taglib descriptor) files.â€�
p Add the following property to WebContainer custom properties com.ibm.wsspi.jsp.disableTldSearch true
p On my machine the statup time of Websphere 7 server was reduced from 1 min 30 secs to 45 seconds!

p I think your first question has already been answered adequately by the other posters.
p On your second question, what you are trying to do may be possible depending on the messaging engine used by your application. I know this works with IBM MQ. I have seen this being done using the strong WebSphere MQ Classes for Java /strong but not JMS. The way it works is that when strong Process A /strong puts a message on a queue, it specifies the time it will wait for a response message. If strong Process A /strong fails to receive a response message within the specified time, the system throws an appropriate exception.
p I do not think there is a standard way in JMS to handle request/response timeouts the way you want so you may have to use platform specific classes like WebSphere MQ Classes for Java.

p I think in WebSphere 7 you may have to delve into the administrative console. As ever the WebSphere documentation seems poor but seems to suggest setting the a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v7r0/topic/com.ibm.websphere.express.doc/info/exp/ae/usec_seccustomprop.html" rel="nofollow" com.ibm.ws.security.addHttpOnlyAttributeToCookies /a property:
blockquote p Both the Secure flag and the HTTPOnly flag are enabled by setting the WebSphere Application Server property: code com.ibm.ws.security.addHttpOnlyAttributeToCookies /code . /blockquote
p I found a href="http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21422185" rel="nofollow" this /a , which I hope is applicable to WAS7. Can you try please (I only have WAS 8 at the moment on my system):
blockquote p em strong JSESSIONID cookie: /em /strong
p strong Secure Flag: /strong
p The Secure flag can be set within the WebSphere Application Server administrative interface by selecting AppServer- [Server Name]- Web Container Settings- Session Management. Check the checkbox for â€œRestrict cookies to HTTPS Sessionsâ€�.
p strong HTTPOnly Flag: /strong
p The HTTPOnly attribute cannot currently be set on this cookie. This is registered on the IBM site as APAR PK98436. The fix for this APAR is currently targeted for inclusion in Fix Packs 6.1.0.31 and 7.0.0.9, which are not yet available. With this APAR in place, the HTTPOnly flag can be set on the JSESSIONID cookie by way of the property name: com.ibm.ws.webcontainer.httpOnlyCookies. Refer to the following technote for instructions on enabling WebContainer custom properties. /blockquote
p The a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v7r0/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.websphere.express.doc/info/exp/ae/rweb_custom_props.html" rel="nofollow" com.ibm.ws.webcontainer.httpOnlyCookies /a property is documented on the WAS 7 help site.

p The javadoc for a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/6/api/javax/ejb/EJB.html" rel="nofollow" javax.ejb.EJB /a is somewhat unclear on this point:
blockquote p If no explicit linking information is provided and there is only one session bean strong within the same application /strong that exposes the matching client view type, by default the EJB dependency resolves to that session bean. /blockquote
p It's debatable whether application in this context means "EJB module" or "EAR", so I don't necessarily think IDEA is to blame. I'm not familiar with other vendors, but at least WebSphere Application Server will attempt to disambiguate within the client EJB/WAR module before considering all EJBs in all modules in the EAR.

p A portal represents a web site that provides a single point of access to applications and information. Portal framework is the portion of a portal that is responsible for the rendering and customization of the portal. Portal framework implementation requires implementing set of JSRs for example a href="http://jcp.org/ja/jsr/detail?id=168" rel="nofollow" JSR168 /a and a href="http://jcp.org/ja/jsr/detail?id=286" rel="nofollow" JSR268 /a (portlet spec v1 and v2).
p In order to run portlets you need application server that implements portlet container spec (JSR168 or JSR286). It can be one of the big enterprise products :IBM WebSphere, Oracle WebLogic (both have application servers, express application servers and portals) or some open source portlet containers: JBoss, Pluto, OpenPortal , Liferay etc.
p Security (authentication-authorization) addressed in portlet JSRs. However, portlets are mostly secured with 3rd partiy frameworks (I did it with Spring)
p Regarding what is popular, I guess that the good answer would be "it depends"... If you work for big enterprise company - I would recommend IBM WebSphere 7 Portal, otherwise I recommend you to consider JBoss and Liferay.
p Good Luck!

p This extension provides access to the functionality of messaging and queueing systems, such as the IBM WebSphere MQSeries family of products, from PHP scripts. The interface is designed to make it extremely simple to do the more commonly required tasks such as deliver simple text messages to queues while still allowing skilled users to do more complex messaging operations. For many users the complexities of setting up numerous options can be simply ignored.
p The SAM extension is a framework that provides a very simple API that can be used to access a number of messaging middleware systems. Currently the package includes built-in support for the MQTT (MQ Telemetry Transport) messaging protocol and support for the IBM Messaging and Queuing middleware products. SAM is designed to be readily extended to support other messaging systems and extension modules may be written in C or PHP.

p I am sorry if I sound like someone from Support, but I was not able to recreate your problem. I used RAD version 8 with a WebSphere Application Server version 7. After profile start the process clearly ran in the specified working directory. I checked it using lsof and an example application. Like Terrell already asked, are you sure about the profile settings?
p Two other thing you should consider.
p Personally, I would not develop a piece of software that is so dependent on the current working directory as it sounds in your question. I would rather use Java System Property settings to point to a configuration directory or something similiar.
p Secondly, if you use RAD with a configured WAS (or Tomcat or whatever) server profile, make sure you check the server specific settings inside RAD (context menu of the profile). For example, per default RAD uses its own deployment path for a server profile when it deploys an application to the respective server.

p It is strong not JDK /strong version. It is J2EE/JEE version.
p It is asking you which strong J2EE/JEE /strong version the ear format (deployment descriptor etc) should adhere to: J2EE 1.2 or 1.3 or 1.4 or JEE 5 or JEE 6.
p Application servers publish their complaince levels. And some application servers generally support older ear versions as well. For e.g. WebSphere 6.x is J2EE 1.4 compliant but it can still run 1.3 ear version.

p You are expecting the semantics of synchronous processing with async (messaging) setup which is not possible. I have worked on WebSphere MQ and normally when the consumer dies, the messages are kept in the queue forever (unless you set the expiry). Once the queue reaches its depth, the subsequent messages are moved to the dead letter queue.

p I use Websphere MQ and it comes by default with a "file based queue". So each queue typically has ONE physical file on disk.
p So lets say for this Websphere MQ queue we have multiple readers and writers....I assume there will be some "millisecond locking" overhead between reads and writes, yet I guarantee it will still be quicker than using a full database like DB2 etc.
p Now I have implemented a queue using SQLite and it works in Production happily in WAL mode.
p My question is do you really think there is a huge difference in SPEED between the file based queue used by products like WebSphere MQ or the SQLite based queue? Both are file based after all and the fact that SQLIte is pure ANSI C does it well for speed.
p SQLIte does offer some extra functionality like "update hooks" etc....and numerous others.
p I guess what I would like to know is if you were going to implement a high speed persistent queue in C would you do it in a similar way to WebSphere MQ and have messages in different offsets etc in a single file, or would you use SQLIte in WAL mode?
p Thanks for the help ;-)
Queue File based persistence - WebSphere MQ vs SQLite queue (WAL)
c sqlite websphere-mq

p So, a layered architecture of a web application is like this:
pre code Browser - Web Server - Application Server - Database Server /code re
ul li Browser choices: include Firefox, IE, Opera, Chrome, Safari and the minorities /li li Web Server: Used for serving static content (receive request/return structured data) and forward requests to application server. This category includes Apache Tomcat, Glassfish, IIS, ngnix, lighttpd) /li li Web Application Server: Where the web application framework (like Spring Framework in Java) and web application logic (our actual application) are hosted as well as executed, and access database server. It includes WebSphere, WebLogic, JBoss, Glassfish, Tomcat). /li li Database Server: includes RDBMS like MS SQL, My SQL, Postgre SQL or a href="http://www.w3.org/TR/rdf-sparql-query/#introduction" rel="nofollow" SPARQL /a in the upcoming RDF technology, along with Semantic Web. /li /ul
p According to this architecture, can I safely conclude that a web project is Website if it doesn't have a web application server, and conversely, it is a web project if it has one to handle application logic.
p Also, do I miss something or misclassify something?
Distinguish web site and web app by server types
web-applications n-tier-architecture

p You should not create your own threads when you are in an EJB. Indeed, EJB 3.1 introduces @Asynchronous annotation for this purpose. Previous versions of WebSphere and WebLogic implement WorkManager, another ad-hoc standard (the JSR 237 for making it a standard was abandoned in the end) for worker threads that can be launched from an EJB.

p a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/6/api/javax/servlet/http/Cookie.html#setMaxAge%28int%29" rel="nofollow" setMaxAge /a is supposed to control the maximum age of a cookie, so if my intention is to literally set the maximum age possible the logical thing would be doing:
pre code cookie.setMaxAge(Integer.MAX_VALUE); /code re
p However this results in no code Expires /code in cookie HTTP header at all, I'm testing it on a WebSphere 7. Setting it to something like 1 year measured in seconds works fine.
p Why is that happening?
p PS Have just tested on Tomcat7 - Integer.MAX_VALUE results in code Max-Age=2147483647; Expires=Wed, 06-Mar-2080 21:30:32 GMT /code , so it must be something wrong with WebSphere.
what's the deal with Cookie.setMaxAge(Integer.MAX_VALUE)?
java servlets cookies websphere

p There is an IBM supplied dll (since v5.3 Fixpack8) on Windows called amqmdnet.dll, which is a .NET assembly providing an IBM supported model for MQSeries. ( a href="http://blogs.msdn.com/b/dotnetinterop/archive/2004/11/08/254113.aspx" rel="nofollow" Reference /a ) It is usually located in code C:\Program Files\IBM\WebSphere MQ\bin\amqmdnet.dll /code

p A "portal" is a website that aggregates content and services from other websites. Usually when someone wants to build a portal, it is to solve a problem of finding and using information (they have too much and its all spread out).
p Portal frameworks let you build complex websites that reuse existing content and applications. Examples and popular platforms include: Drupal (an open source php platform), Sharepoint (Microsoft's .Net Portal platform), and IBM WebSphere Portal (based on Java).
p The reuse part is key to a portal - In Drupal you can install modules from the community to quickly (faster than from scratch) replicate the functionality you see elsewhere on the web such as blogs, wikis, discussion forums, user profiles, shopping carts, and database application. In Sharepoint you can do the same thing with "Webparts". In IBM Portal they are called "Portlets".
p The portal platform itself handles the user authentification (login / log out), security (groups and access to resources), and depending on the portal, the search, content management, navigation, language management, device detection (mobile or desktop to direct to correct display templates) and provide a way to extend the portal with plugins, portlets, widgets, webparts or whatever they call them in the portal you select.
p Most Web Content Management solutions can be used alone or in a portal to handle content creation, version control, tagging, security, and formatting.

p The error that you are seeing is because your keystore does not have the signing CA's root and/or intermediate signer certificates. When you get a signed certificate back from the Certificate Authority it must be validated before adding it to the keystore. Pretty much anyone could have intercepted your signing request and signed the certificate. The step of validating it when received insures that it was signed by a CA that you actually trust and not some anonymous man-in-the-middle.
p The way the cert is validated is by checking the CA signature against the public key of the CA that is in your KDB. For that the CA's certificate must already be in the KDB when you attempt to receive your signed cert. If the CA uses an intermediate signer certificate (and for a variety of reasons any commercial CA em will /em use intermediate certs) then you must also have imported the intermediate cert em and /em the root cert. This forms a certificate chain or certificate path from the CA's root cert through any intermediate certs to your signed certificate. Each thing in the chain is authenticated by the thing above it until you get to the root. Your KDB em must /em have the entire chain and because each cert is validated by the one above it, you em must /em import these beginning with the root and working your way down.
p Typically your CA will have posted their signer certs on their web site where you retrieve them using SSL. Fetch those and import them and you will be able to receive your signed cert.
p As it happens, The Sphere Online Journal just published an article that walks you through this process using Verisign as an example, and with screen shots of importing the root and intermediate signer certs. The article is about em a href="http://www.websphereusergroup.org/go/article/view/252716/the_sphere_journal_online_%E2%80%94_february_2012#4" rel="nofollow" Renewing WebSphere MQ Certificates /a /em but the first part of the article creates a kdb file and a signing request, then imports the CA certs and the signed cert.
p Let's also get you to the correct Infocenter. Please look at the WMQ v7.0 Infocenter's section on em a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r0/topic/com.ibm.mq.csqzas.doc/sy11713_.htm" rel="nofollow" Using CA Signed Certificates /a /em . The one you were looking at is for Message Broker and quite frankly the article you linked to is a bit of a mess. I'll see about getting it fixed. For starters, that bit about creating the cert in one kdb, getting it signed, then exporting it, deleting it and importing it to the QMgr's KDB is pure rubbish. Just generate the CSR in the QMgr's own KDB file and receive the signed cert directly to it. This is much easier and is the process illustrated in the article mentioned above.
p Finally, if you go to a href="https://t-rob.net/links/" rel="nofollow" t-rob.net /a and download the WMQ Security Lab from IMPACT 2011 you will find there a lab guide and some scripts. These use self-signed certificates but the scripts can easily be converted to use CA signed certificates and then tailored for use in your WMQ network.
p strong UPDATE: /strong br Responding to he additional questions in the comments:
p em I'm actually planning to use a self-signed certificate, so I guess I only need to extract it and adding it to the client's trust store? /em
p Yes, that is correct. But here's a problem in the WMB Infocenter page that was originally linked in that it asks you to create a cert with the label code qmgrname /code instead of code ibmwebspheremqqmgrname /code . The QMgr finds its cert based on the label and so it em must /em match the specified format. So when you create your self-signed cert, mke sure that the label is the literal code ibmwebspheremq /code with the QMgr name folded to lower case appended. If you have made a cert with the wrong label, you can always export it to a P12 file and then import it to a new KDB with the right label.
p em I used the WMQ SSL Wizard mentioned in the WMQ Security Lab to create the proper configuration. The configuration went smoothly, but when I run the JMS sample included with the SSL Wizard I get the error code MQJE001: Completion Code '2', Reason '2397' /code , the SSL logs shows the following error code main, received EOFException: error main, handling exception: javax.net.ssl.SSLHandshakeException: Remote host closed connection during handshake main, SEND TLSv1 ALERT: fatal, description = handshake_failure /code /em
p There are a few reasons why that might occur. Rather than going through all of them, I'll suggest some diagnostic techniques. When I set up SSL channels, I always use the following procedure:
ol li Get the channel running without SSL. This proves that the basic communication path is working (listener running, ports match, channel object definitions match, etc.). /li li If this is the first time that the QMgr is using SSL, or if the kdb has changed, be sure to issue the code REFRESH SECURITY TYPE(SSL) /code command. /li li Enable SSL by specifying the same ciphersuite at the QMgr and client but be sure that the QMgr's SVRCONN channel is set to code SSLCAUTH(OPTINAL) SSLPEER() /code . This verifies that the em client /em accepts em the QMgr's /em certificate. Only when this works, go to the next step. /li li Now change the QMgr's SVRCONN to code SSLCAUTH(REQUIRED) SSLPEER() /code . This causes the QMgr to request the client's certificate. /li li If using code SSLPEER /code set it to the desired value. /li /ol
p This process isolates the possible problems so that at any point you know where to look. If the process fails in Step #3 then there is either an issue with the SSL configuration of the application, or it cannot validate the QMgr's cert. If the process fails in Step #4 then we know the application's SSL configuration is sound and that it likes the QMgr's cert bu that the QMgr doesn't like the application cert. If we get to Step #5 then it's just a matter of getting the code SSLPEER /code value correct.
p Because you got a handshake failure that appears to be due to the QMgr closing the TCP connection, I am assuming that you have code SSLCAUTH(REQUIRED) /code (which is the default, by the way) and that either the QMgr doesn't have the application's certificate or that you were attempting to use an anonymous connection where the client doesn't require a personal cert. If that is the case, setting code SSLCAUTH(OPTIONAL) /code will get you past the point of failure - although possibly to an entirely new point of failure.

p I got it working. In addition to the above hibernate settings here is what I did.
pre code The object of type WebSphereUowTransactionManager is not an instance of javax.transaction.TransactionManager but there is superclass method inside WebSphereUowTransactionManager called getTransactionManager() this returns object of type javax.transaction.TransactionManager
bean id="wasUOWTxnManagerObj" class="org.springframework.transaction.jta.WebSphereUowTransactionManager"
!-- Now call get getTransactionManager on WebSphereUowTransactionManager object. -- bean id="tranSactionManager" class="javax.transaction.TransactionManager" factory-bean="wasUOWTxnManagerObj" factory-method="getTransactionManager" /bean /code re
p With this change now you can use WebSphereUowTransactionManager. Hope this helps.

p If you search for 'enterprise OSGi' you may have more luck and get some more ideas. Many of the main application servers, including WebSphere, Glassfish, and JBoss now support integration between OSGi and JEE components. One option is to use a JNDI bridge which allows your OSGi services to be looked up using JNDI. Another is to use SCA to connect things together. Apache Aries' SPI-fly project also allows you to expose META-INF/services as OSGi services.

p If you can't upgrade (ancient WebSphere + Java 1.4, ouch!), one possible workaround (more of a hackaround, really) is to write a simple filter, mapped to every request, that does the proper charset conversion and rejects invalid requests.
p I'm sure with some digging you can find an implementation that checks for things you may not have thought of.
p Of course that still leaves 8 years worth of other security (not to mention productivity) problems.
h3 Oops /h3
p Didn't notice didn't notice how old the question is.

p Take a look at the SPNEGO protocol, this is what Sharepoint ( technically IIS ) uses for Single Sign On authentication. I am not familar with CXF, but generally most of the WebServices platforms allow you to supply additional headers with your request. Basically what you need is:
pre code 1. Get authentication token for the sharepoint from user session
2. Use JAAS to generate tokens. /code re
p Look here a href="http://appliedcrypto.com/spnego/spnego_jaasclient.html" rel="nofollow" http://appliedcrypto.com/spnego/spnego_jaasclient.html /a and here a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/technotes/guides/security/jgss/lab art6.html" rel="nofollow" http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/technotes/guides/security/jgss/lab art6.html /a for more details.
p For the case when you want to authenticate browser users to sharepoint. You have to implement SPNEGO protocol in your web app for example you can use a href="http://waffle.codeplex.com/" rel="nofollow" this /a package do it you. Most of the modern app servers support SPNEGO protocol [ JBoss, WebSphere ]. After you implemented SPNEGO protocol, you can grab the kerberos token from 'Authorization' header.
p Then you have two options:
ol li p In case you run your web-app with the same identity as the SharePoint front-end you can just resend the same token to the sharepoint. /li li p In case you running as a different identity, you have to use the user's token to go to active directory and request a ticket for sharepoint service on behalf of your user. The account that your web-app runs under has to be trusted for delegation in Active Directory /li /ol
p Also, I am not sure that SharePoint accepts kerberos tokens within SOAP headers, I believe you have to authenticate using HTTP headers.
p a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/534278/configure-tomcat-for-ad-kerberos-impersonating" This /a question might help you
p If you want to use single sign on feature meaning using current user identity take a look a href="http://dmdaa.wordpress.com/2010/03/13/kerberos-setup-and-jaas-configuration-for-running-sun-jgss-tutorial-against-ad/" rel="nofollow" here /a

p After some digging I can answer my own question ...
p The "Dynamic Web Project" number (2.2, 2.3, 2.4, 2.5) corresponds to the version of the Servlet spec (example. Servlet 2.4, Servlet 2.5, Servlet 3.0).
p Servlet 2.4 (supported by WebSphere 6.1) uses J2EE 1.4 and J2SE 1.3.
p Servlet 2.5 (supported by WebSphere 7.0) uses Java EE 5 and Java SE 5.
p Servlet 3.0 (possibly supported by WebSphere 8.0?) uses Java EE 6 and Java SE 6.
p So, JAX-RS requires annotations which means it needs Java SE 5, and therefore Servlet 2.5.

p The CometD project provides a Bayeux implementation that is portable across servlet containers (Tomcat, Jetty, WebLogic, WebSphere, etc) provided that only HTTP transports are used (i.e. not WebSocket).
p Many of the recent servlet containers now support Servlet 3, and CometD runs natively in any Servlet 3 compliant container.
p See also the a href="http://docs.cometd.org/reference/#java_server_configuration_servlet3" rel="nofollow" section about configuring CometD for Servlet 3 containers /a and the a href="http://docs.cometd.org/reference/#javascript_transports" rel="nofollow" section about the JavaScript transports /a for disabling the WebSocket tranport (in case you do not deploy in Jetty).

p This line:
p code SET CHLAUTH(TEST_CHANNEL) TYPE(ADDRESSMAP) ADDRESS(*) MCAUSER('mq-user') /code
p Says the following:
ul li For connections requesting code TEST_CHANNEL /code ... /li li Originating from em any /em IP address... /li li Set the MCAUSER to code mq-user /code /li /ul
p In other words, enable the channel such that any connections inherit the privileges of code mq-user /code regardless of where they originate and what identity they present. So the behavior you are seeing is the expected behavior based on the code CHLAUTH /code rule above.
p There are a few other problems with the rules as listed:
ul li The use of code PRINCIPAL /code rather than code GROUP /code . On non-windows servers if you specify code PRINCIPAL /code what happens is that the QMgr looks up that ID, queries its primary group and then sets authorizations based on that. So if code mq-users /code has a primary group of code staff /code or code users /code that that is what gets authorized instead of code mq-users /code and is probably not what you intended. Always use code group /code so that you get the result you intend with code setmqaut /code or code AUTHREC /code . /li li Granting code ALL /code on the QMgr makes the ID/group administrative. One of the privileges at the QMgr level is code SET /code and any user in a group with code SET /code rights can set, among other things, authorization control lists. So even though you only granted code AUTHADD(INQ,DSP,PUT) /code the code mq-users /code ID can submit PCF commands to grant all access to all objects. Only grant code CONNECT /code and code INQUIRE /code on the QMgr if that's all you need. /li li There's an assumption stated (in bold, actually) that you would have expected to be required to pass user credentials. Please be aware that WMQ does not validate a user ID and password if you do provide them. It accepts the ID that you assert. The password field is available to exits which can be used to validate the ID and password against, for example, LDAP or the local OS. Such an exit can be purchased from a 3rd party or written but base WMQ doesn't do anything with the password. Had you specified code USERSRC(CHANNEL) /code on the mapping, then your ID would have been used and most likely rejected. But the rejection would have been either because it is in the code mqm /code group (which is blocked by a default code CHLAUTH /code rule) or because there are no code AUTHREC /code records for the group it is in. /li /ul
p For more about hardening WMQ, there are a number of resources collected a href="http://t-rob.net/links" rel="nofollow" here /a . The em Hardening WebSphere MQ /em presentation is from v7.0. Although v7.1 has new controls, the principals remain the same:
ul li Authenticate the connection using IP filtering (for apps or QMgrs where the connection originates in a locked datacenter), SSL/TLS and/or an exit /li li Map the authenticated identity to an code MCAUSER /code value by hard-coding it in the channel or by using an exit or code CHLAUTH /code rule to dynamically set it /li li Administrative connections and high-value applications should be authenticated using TLS /li /ul

p I came across this question and was quite surprised why this should not be the case, since WebSphere Application Server uses standard Java Util Logging.
p To test it, I wrote a quick application which created a couple of different loggers and checked them using the isLoggable() method. You can see the results below. I removed the Levels ALL and OFF to have a compact list, but they also worked as expected.
pre code Server Info: IBM WebSphere Application Server/7.0
Package level/Log Setting FINEST FINER FINE CONFIG INFO WARNING SEVERE isLoggable(finest) Yes No No No No No No isLoggable(finer) Yes Yes No No No No No isLoggable(fine) Yes Yes Yes No No No No isLoggable(config) Yes Yes Yes Yes No No No isLoggable(info) Yes Yes Yes Yes Yes No No isLoggable(warning) Yes Yes Yes Yes Yes Yes No isLoggable(severe) Yes Yes Yes Yes Yes Yes Yes /code re
p From my point of view, I would say it works as expected. Maybe there was a bug and it was solved in the meantime.

p You can test your EJBs using Universal Test Client. See more details here: a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wsadhelp/v5r1m2/index.jsp?topic=%2Fcom.ibm.etools.server.core.doc%2Ftopics%2Fcwejbtc.html" rel="nofollow" http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wsadhelp/v5r1m2/index.jsp?topic=%2Fcom.ibm.etools.server.core.doc%2Ftopics%2Fcwejbtc.html /a
p Although that link is for WebSphere 5, UTC is still available in WebSphere 7.0. Here is how to enable it: a href="http://wpcertification.blogspot.com/2011/04/universal-test-client-application.html" rel="nofollow" http://wpcertification.blogspot.com/2011/04/universal-test-client-application.html /a

p The program must be able to do the following:
ul li Connect ;amp; inquire on the QMgr /li li Create a model queue using inquire, display and get authority against a suitable model queue (you'd generally define a dedicated one for this rather than using the default model queue) /li li Put PCF messages on the command queue with inquire, display and put authority /li li Inquire on the target queue with display authority /li /ul
p Dale Lane wrote a blog post a while back describing this for the general case of: em a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9376800/which-permissions-are-required-for-pcfagent-enquiries" Using WebSphere MQ Explorer as a read-only viewer /a /em . Since WMQ Explorer needs to display all objects of all object types it is a bit more permissive than you are asking for. However, the settings you need are a subset of the ones Dale provides and the post has a lot of good background on the configurations used. I could copy his code setmqaut /code commands here but its worth reading the post.
p Incidentally, if you have a v7.1 QMgr and a new WMQ Explorer (downloaded from a href="http://ibm.co/SupptPacMS0T" rel="nofollow" SupportPac MS0T /a ) there's a security wizard in WMQ Explorer that makes the same settings Dale recommends in his blog post.

p Are you using the SIB or WebSphere MQ ?
p As far as I know, the SIB does not log anything about message consumption by itself. However, you could use a logging framework such as Commons-Logging, Log4J, ... to add some logging details.

p There is other way. See the a href="http://static.springsource.org/spring-ws/site/reference/html/common.html#logging" rel="nofollow" documentation /a .
p Anyway, why code SoapEnvelopeLoggingInterceptor /code is not working with WebSphere? I have not experience with WebSphere but it could happen that your log configuration is being overwritten by the server one. Take a look to the server log configuration.

p Yes, but certain configurations favour certain vendors. See the WCF Express Interop Bindings project on CodePlex:
p a href="http://wcf.codeplex.com/wikipage?title=WCF%20Express%20Interop%20Bindings" rel="nofollow" http://wcf.codeplex.com/wikipage?title=WCF%20Express%20Interop%20Bindings /a
p They offer settings for interop with:
ul li Oracle WebLogic /li li Oracle Metro /li li IBM WebSphere /li li Apache Axis2 /li /ul
p The Oracle Metro (previously known as SUN WSIT) stack is by far the most advanced as regards the WS-*/Oasis standards.

p Java only allows one SSL connection factory class for a JVM. If you are using a JDK thats shipped with WebSphere Application Server v6x/7x/8x or any other WebSphere server tools in Rational Application Developer, then those require IBM ( com.ibm.websphere.ssl.protocol.SSLSocketFactory ) specific class from WebSphere Application Server runtime. because the java security file has the JSSE socket factories set like below
pre code Default JSSE socket factories #ssl.SocketFactory.provider=com.ibm.jsse2.SSLSocketFactoryImpl #ssl.ServerSocketFactory.provider=com.ibm.jsse2.SSLServerSocketFactoryImpl # WebSphere socket factories (in cryptosf.jar) ssl.SocketFactory.provider=com.ibm.websphere.ssl.protocol.SSLSocketFactory ssl.ServerSocketFactory.provider=com.ibm.websphere.ssl.protocol.SSLServerSocketFactory /code re
p So, If you uncomment the Default JSSE Socket factories and commne the WebSphere ones , then WAS is going to puke. Better work around would be to have com.ibm.ws.security.crypto.jar file in your class path , This jar file has a dependency on com.ibm.ffdc.jar file so you need that in your class path well. Both these jarfiles are available under code WebSphere_Install_Dirctory lugins/ /code

p I've done 3 evaluations of WebLogic, JBoss, and WebSphere. WebLogic won every one of them, hands down. Having said that, my simplistic guidance is this: use JBoss if you are NOT worried about scaling past several thousand concurrent users. However, if you intend to scale beyond that, you're going to need something with proven horsepower and robustness - that's WebLogic.
p Note: app server vendors generally sacrifice technical features for stability. In other words, robustness is in dynamic tension with technical features. If you want new features, you get more bugs along with it. It surprises me how many technicians don't get that. But, if you think about why you don't rush out and buy the first new Windows OS version when it comes out, you'll understand perfectly why this is so.
p HTH

p Some time ago I did something similiar. I wanted to use a specific version of a library which was already used within the WebSphere Application Server. That is the reason why you have to put your libraries in the EAR file and set the application server to PARENT_LAST class loader order.
p Correct me if I am wrong, but you also have to specify your custom MQ client libraries in Manifest of your WAR file. You only mentioned Log4J. It should look somehting like this:
pre code Class-Path: com.ibm.mqjms.jar com.ibm.mq.jmqi.jar [...] log4j.jar /code re
p Anyway, you can always check what libraries are in the Classpath of you application if you log into the em Integrated Solutions Console /em (aka em Admin Console /em ) and check the em Troubleshooting /em section. There is a classloader viewer. Just click yourself through the tree and check which library path are mentioned and which you would expect.
p Finally, as Dylan already mentioned in his comment: WebSphere Application Server version 6.1 runs out of support September 30, 2012. :)

p I finally have it working. I'll document my steps in case anyone else runs into similar problems deploying a Play app on WebSphere in the future.
p 1 - The first issue was the 404. Websphere doesn't pass requests for root (/) to the app to handle (wtf?), so the fix is to define a similar route in your routes file:
pre code GET /* Application.index /code re
p instead of (or on top of)
pre code GET / Application.index /code re
p 2 - The next issue was errors related to persistence (JPA) methods not existing. Play uses JPA 2.0, while WebSphere 7 uses their own custom version of OpenJPA 1.0. You can install a href="http://www-01.ibm.com/software/webservers/appserv/was/featurepacks/" rel="nofollow" a feature pack for JPA 2 and OSGI /a (you don't need the OSGI part, so it can be ignored). Note that the feature pack requires that you have WebSphere 7.0.0.9 or later installed. That means matching fix packs for both the app server and the bundled JDK. I.E. fix pack 21 (the latest at the time or writing) for both the server and the JDK need to be installed first before installing the JPA feature pack. At the end of the feature pack installation, it will ask you if you want to run the profile tool. Say yes. This tool will let you "augment" your profile (the server node you're going to install your war on). Augment away!
p 3 - Build a war file that will work in WebSphere:
pre code play war appFolder -o outputFolder --zip --%prod /code re
p This will create a folder named (an exploded war) and a .war file named .war, with the app id set to prod. The exploded war can be deleted.
p Running this command on linux keeps putting my WEB-INF folder inside an unnamed folder (so, down a level from the root level of the war file). In other words, instead of /WEB-INF/, it's creating a structure like //WEB-INF/. Anyway, I'm fixing it manually for now, by re-zipping it properly. Anyone know how to avoid this problem?
p 4 - Install the war file into WebSphere with all the default settings in the admin console...or tweak them if you know what you're doing.
p 5 - I'm not entirely sure if this step is necessary (doesn't change anything for my particular app), but all the advice I've read online about getting Play apps to run in WebSphere say to do this. Meh, it can't hurt. Click on your installed app. Click on the "Class loading and update detection" link. Then select the "Classes loaded with local class loader first (parent last)" option. Ok. Save.
p 6 - Open a browser page to your address (localhost:9080 if running websphere locally), and test. At this point it should work! Hopefully. Good luck.

WebSphere MQ .NET - Difference between IBM.XMS.dll and amqmdnet.dll
.net ibm websphere-mq

p This sounds like a good topic for a new em a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/views/websphere/libraryview.jsp?site_id=1 ;amp;contentarea_by=WebSphere ;amp;sort_by=Date ;amp;sort_order=2 ;amp;start=1 ;amp;end=11 ;amp;topic_by= ;amp;product_by= ;amp;type_by=All%20Types ;amp;show_abstract=true ;amp;search_by=Mission%3aMessaging%3a" rel="nofollow" Mission:Messaging /a /em column but I'll write up the condensed version here. I'll preface my answer by noting that many of my recommendations are contrary to those you might find elsewhere. In some cases this is because the way MQ is commonly used have changed over the years. In other cases it is because the conventional wisdom never worked well to begin with. (Cluster channels named code TO.QMGR /code for example.) In all cases, I prefer conventions which apply to the broadest number of situations. That means it is usually possible to find exceptions to these rules for specific cases but they are broadly applicable nonetheless.
p strong Some general rules /strong br The following apply to all object types.
p em Use the dot character code . /code as a separator. /em br Authorization rules parse names using dot characters as separators. For example, the queue name code MY.EXAMPLE.QUEUE.NAME /code would match rules like code MY.*.*.* /code or code MY.** /code but not code MY.* /code because the dots signify name node separator characters. Do yourself a favor and use dots rather than underscores as your naming node separators consistently.
p em Use machine-parsable names. /em br When you have 5 queue managers and a few hundred objects, you can easily get by doing all your management manually with WMQ Explorer or runmqsc. However, there comes a point where consistency, reliability, repeatability and efficiency demand that you script up some of your routine operations or employ instrumentation to respond to network events. More than anything else this means eliminating ambiguity in names.
p For example, if you create a naming convention that channel names must look like code SRCQMGR.DESTQMGR /code then it is possible for a script to read a code RCVR /code or code SDR /code channel name and derive the names of the two queue managers it connects. However, what does the script do with a channel name like code GA.PAYROLL.OPS /code ? Is it the code GA.PAYROLL /code queue manager connecting to the code OPS /code queue manager? Or is it the code GA /code queue manager connecting to the code PAYROLL.OPS /code queue manager? A human might be able to tell instantly based on context but scripts are notorious for doing what you tell them rather than what you intended. Similar situations arise when queue names have position-dependent qualifiers at both the beginning and the end of the name and a variable number of nodes.
p em Stick with UPPERCASE names. /em br This is for compatibility across all platforms, and in particular z/OS. Although it is true that more z/OS shops are using mixed case, it is also true that there are still a lot of systems out there that only accept UPPERCASE names. While it is easy to say "this doesn't apply to me" I have seen many cases where somebody had problems interfacing to a new business partner because of incompatible names. After all, the ability to interface to just about any platform out there is one of the main reasons for using WMQ in the first place.
p em Don't include attributes of the object in the name /em br In an SOA world, queues and topics are different types of destination and often are interchangeable. Something putting messages to what it thinks is a queue doesn't necessarily know (or care!) if they are actually going to a queue or a topic. A queue that has an application listening on it for messages may be fed by an administrative subscription that is actually roping in publications from one or more topics.
p What we really care about is the nature of the messages - what function do they perform - not whether we are connecting to a local queue or an alias queue. So adding qualifiers like code .QA /code , code .QL /code , code .TPC /code (for topic) and so forth doesn't make sense. Similarly, adding code .RCVR /code onto a channel name sucks up 5 useful characters that could have been better used describing the QMgr name. Worse, these practices bake the topology into the object names, making the system both less flexible and more brittle.
p strong Channel names /strong
p em Point-to-Point Channel names /em br Use names like code SRCQMGR.DESTQMGR /code for code RCVR /code , code RQSTR /code , code SDR /code , and code SVR /code channels. This is biased toward languages that read left-to-right because the intention is to describe the data flow em from /em a QMgr em to /em another QMgr
p em Cluster channels /em br Use names like code CLUSNAME.QMNAME /code . The old wisdom said to use names like code TO.QMNAME /code but if you ever implement overlapping clusters this causes the same channel to be used for multiple clusters. That's bad because you can then never perform maintenance on one cluster without impacting the other. Using code CLUSNAME.QMNAME /code insures that every QMgr has a dedicated code CLUSRCVR /code channel for each cluster in which it participates.
p em Client Channels /em br The exception to the "don't include attributes of the object in the name" is arguably the code SVRCONN /code channel. This is because channels are very much tied to the physical rather than the logical layer of the network. So putting the QMgr name in a SVRCONN channel name is generally OK. I don't object too strongly if people want to add code .SVRCONN /code at the end, either.
p The thing to remember about client channels is that if you use a Client Channel Definition Table (CCDT) then the unique index into that table is the channel name. That means you cannot have the same channel name on multiple QMgrs and still use a CCDT. Since the CCDT is one way to configure the SSL/TLS channel details, this is often not appreciated to its fullest until the "let's finally secure WMQ" project comes along. By using unique channel names for code SVRCONN /code channels from the start, you can future-proof the network. Usually these names look like code APP.QMNAME /code or to make it obvious you aren't dealing with a cluster or point-to-point channel, code APP.QMNAME.SVRCONN /code or similar.
p strong Queue manager names /strong
p em No dots in QMgr names /em br One implication of the previous rules is that cluster and queue manager names must contain only one node and therefore should never contain a code . /code character. This is because channel names are typically derived from the cluster and/or QMgr names. So in the example above, a code RCVR /code channel name like code GA_PAYROLL.OPS /code would tell both humans and scripts that the channel in question connects a QMgr named code GA_PAYROLL /code to a QMgr named code OPS /code .
p em Names of 9 chars or less /em br Channel names can be only 20 characters. Subtract one for the dot separator, divide by two and round down gets you to 9 characters max for queue managers. If there's a possibility that you may set up different channels for classes of service (for large vs small messages, for example, then drop back to 8 chars or less for QMgr names. This leads to code QM1.QM2.A /code , code QM1.QM2.B /code , etc.
p em QMgr names reflect the physical layer /em br In a service-oriented world, we really care about destination names like queues and topics. We care much less about queue manager names because these are just life support for queues and topics. Client apps don't care so much about em which /em QMgr the connect to, so long as they can send requests and receive replies. WMQ very conveniently fills in the reply-to QMgr name on outbound requests so it is rare that an application needs to know about it.
p On the other hand, the administrators need to know about the QMgr name. In the early days it was common to name QMgrs for the host server. Later it became the fashion to name them for the applications they hosted. Now in the SOA world, messaging is infrastructure and usually not associated with any single application so the pendulum has swung back. Give the QMgr a unique name that is meaningful to an administrator.
p em Never reuse QMgr names! /em br It is unfortunately very common to "move" a QMgr from one place to another or to have a primary and disaster recovery QMgr with the same name. This practice usually means some part of the application is dependent on the QMgr name and therefore it is "easier" to reuse the name. IBM introduced the code QMID /code as a way to address some of the problems introduced by reusing QMgr names. The typical use case is that a node gets rebuilt and the QMgr once there is also rebuilt from scratch. The cluster knows it is a new QMgr because the code QMID /code has changed, but the name used for routing and other operations remains the same.
p Although this helped in that limited use case, it doesn't address the issues when both QMgrs with the same name are online at the same time. Nor does it address the problem that a reputable Certificate Authority won't issue multiple certs with the same Distinguished Name which forces reuse of the same certificate for multiple QMgrs.
p Remember that QMgrs are just life support for queues and topics and ideally will be anonymous to the applications using them. Pick a naming convention that allows you to spin up new QMgrs with unique names by the hundreds or thousands, if necessary, so that you don't have to reuse QMgr names.
p strong Other objects /strong
p em Use intention-revealing names /em br Or to put it another way, name the object for what it em does /em and not what it em is /em . For example, if you were in the habit (as many people are) of including qualifiers like code .QL /code for local queues and code .QA /code for aliases, then any change in topology will impact the applications using those queues. Instead, name the queues for the functions they represent.
p em Go left-to-right, most generic to most specific /em br Object names, especially queues, should be constructed hierarchically beginning with the most generic qualifier and proceeding to the most specific qualifier. For example, many shops use code APP.FUNC.SUBFUNC.VER /code where code APP /code is the ID of the owning application, then one or more nodes with the function and subfunction. Many shops add a version qualifier on the end so that new versions of a service can migrate their clients on separate schedules rather than changing the service on the existing queue and making all clients change at the same time.
p em The thing that reads the messages owns the queue /em br If I have a service endpoint represented by a queue then there is a many-to-one relationship between the things that might call the service to the thing that provides the service. The queue is associated with the service and the thing providing that service. Clients are more or less anonymous. Therefore, if any of the stakeholder applications can be said to "own" the queue, it is the service provider app that consumes messages form it.
p em The thing that publishes the message owns the topic. Sort of. /em br The relationship is not as straightforward with topics. Here it is the consumers of messages that are usually anonymous. In that sense if the topic name reflects any application, it is most likely the publisher. However, even publishers can be anonymous, or at least there may many of them and not all publishing at the same time. With topics it makes much more sense that the topic tree nodes are structured for the hierarchy of data or functionality they represent. These names tend to match the names of the publishing apps so sometimes the publisher "owns" the topic as much out of coincidence as anything else.
p em Put positional qualifiers on the left /em br Where names have variable numbers of qualifiers, put the positional ones on the left where scripts and automation can parse them. Some shops where both the beginning em and /em ending qualifiers are positional deal with this by using underscores for separators in the variable section of the name like code APP.FUNC.SUBFUNC1_SUBFUNC2.VER /code . Scripts and authorizations then always see a fixed number of nodes in the name but this approach can be brittle if somebody forgets and makes a name with an extra node or two.
p strong Further reading /strong br This sums up most of the general rules but some of the philosophy behind them has been captured in the Mission:Messaging column. In particular:
ul li em a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/techjournal/0809_mismes/0809_mismes.html" rel="nofollow" Embracing cultural change in the WebSphere MQ community /a /em /li li em a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/techjournal/0811_mismes/0811_mismes.html" rel="nofollow" Migration, failover, and scaling in a WebSphere MQ cluster /a /em /li li The article em a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/techjournal/0901_mismes/0901_mismes.html" rel="nofollow" Planning for SSL on the WebSphere MQ network /a /em discusses distinguished name standards as they apply to WMQ /li /ul

ol li request 1 is logged in server1.log on server 1 /li li request 2 is logged in server2.log on server 2 /li li request 3 is logged in server1.log.2012-02-19 on server1 /li li request 4 is logged in server2.log.2012-02-19 on server2 /li /ol
p Ideally it should write in the following pattern on and only to the below two files
ol li p request 1 is logged in server1.log on server 1 /li li p request 2 is logged in server2.log on server 2
p and should not write on below two files /li li p request 3 is logged in server1.log.2012-02-19 on server1 /li li p request 4 is logged in server2.log.2012-02-19 on server2 /li /ol

p I can change the default Java on CentOS using these steps:
ol li p Add the IBM JDK:
p alternatives --install /usr/bin/java java /opt/WebSphere/AppServer/java/bin/java 3 /li li p Set the new IBM JDK as default:
p alternatives --config java (then select #3 in the list) /li li p Type "java -version" at the prompt to see the result. /li /ol

p Please notice that WebSphere Real Time is actually an IBM Java Virtual Machine different from the standard Oracle one available for download.
p The correct approach depends on which VM you are actually using:
p If you are using the standard VM, use command line arguments.
p If you em do /em use WebSphere, use code Compiler.disable() /code .

p In reading a question about a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2360965/what-really-is-connection-pooling" connection pools /a , I was going to answer that you shouldn't use one if you have to use DB-level permissions for individual users. I'm basing that answer on previous Java/JDBC apps on WebSphere that used connection pooling based on an application account that did all the SQL interactions.
p That made me wonder if it was possible to use connection pooling but with individual user accounts in the database. For example, I do support one app that tracks legal letters to land owners where the modifications to the correspondence info can be audited so it is important to know who changed what and when, hence the individual accounts.
p I would imagine the issues would be similar regardless of platform.
Does using DB permissions on a user-level preclude connection pooling?
database-connection connection-pooling

p WebSphere has something called "request metrics"
p a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v6r1/topic/com.ibm.websphere.express.doc/info/exp/ae/tprf_rqenable.html" rel="nofollow" http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v6r1/topic/com.ibm.websphere.express.doc/info/exp/ae/tprf_rqenable.html /a
p It gives you the possibility to log braked down request execution times on different levels. As you may expect with such monitoring it's easy to collect to much data so there is a possibility to filter events based on additional criteria like java package namespace, EJB name, URI etc.
WebSphere MQ Acknowledgement and Reply-To Queue
java jms websphere-mq

p The ReplyTo fields allow the remote application to address messages back to you. They are not used by WebSphere MQ in routing the original message but are used for addressing acknowledgements and failure reports.
p The way that you specify a queue on a remote QMgr using JNDI lookups is to define the code QMNAME /code field in the queue object. Please see em a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r0/topic/com.ibm.mq.csqzaw.doc/jm10910_.htm" rel="nofollow" Properties of WebSphere MQ classes for JMS objects /a /em for a list of all the properties supported by WebSphere MQ objects. What is not mentioned in the top table is that the code QMNAME /code property of a queue need not match the code QMNAME /code property of the connection factory. When these properties differ, the local QMgr will attempt to resolve a path to the target QMgr when the queue object is opened. As long as it can find a path (either a transmit queue or a QMgr alias must exist with the same name as the target QMgr) and as long as your app is authorized to the transmit queue, you are good to go.
p Note that if you get a JMS exception, you em must /em inquire for the existence of and print any linked exceptions you find. These will have the WMQ reason code that will tell you or the admin whether any problems are related to name resolution, authorization or other. Please see em a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r0/topic/com.ibm.mq.csqzaw.doc/jm35210_.htm" rel="nofollow" Exceptions in WebSphere MQ classes for JMS /a /em for suggestions on how to do this. Note that this is not WMQ-specific advice. JMS specifies a multi-level structure for reporting exceptions and the linked exception is where vendor-specific errors are reported. So em any /em JMS application, regardless of which transport provider is used, should print linked exceptions.

p What are the recommended guidelines for WebSphere MQ naming conventions for queue managers, queues (local, remote, transmit, dead letter queues...), channels etc. I found one at IBM's a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/library/techarticles/0807_hsieh/0807_hsieh.html" rel="nofollow" developerWorks /a but looking to see if there is anything else comprehensive out there. Thanks.
WebSphere MQ Object Naming Conventions
websphere-mq

p According to the info from a href="http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg1PK72991" rel="nofollow" here /a :
p strong Error description /strong
p When using WebSphere Application Server and Feature Pack for Webservices the following exception is encountered when using a service to make calls to the server after creating and configuring the web service proxies.
p The first service call always should create a new HTTP session; the second call needs to use the session from the first one.
p The problem is that during the second call the server no longer returns the session cookie. The client proxy then returns
pre code [03.09.08 13:49:31:892 CEST] 0000000a ExceptionFact 1 org.apache.axis2.jaxws.ExceptionFactory createWebServiceException Create Exception:
javax.xml.ws.WebServiceException: Error: Maintain Session is enabled but none of the session properties (Cookies, Over-written URL) are returned. at org.apache.axis2.jaxws.ExceptionFactory.createWebServiceException(ExceptionFactory.java:178) at org.apache.axis2.jaxws.ExceptionFactory.makeWebServiceException( ExceptionFactory.java:79) at org.apache.axis2.jaxws.ExceptionFactory.makeWebServiceException(ExceptionFactory.java:125) at org.apache.axis2.jaxws.BindingProvider.setupSessionContext(BindingProvider.java:172) /code re
p strong Problem summary /strong
pre code **************************************************************** * USERS AFFECTED: All users of WebSphere Application Server * * Feature Pack for JAX-WS Web Services that * * use cookies. * **************************************************************** * PROBLEM DESCRIPTION: JAX-WS does not allow session cookie * * sharing between client * * BindingProvider instances for * * synchronous proxy invocations * **************************************************************** * RECOMMENDATION: * **************************************************************** JAX-WS does not allow session sharing between the client BindingProvider instances for synchronous proxy invocations. JAX-RPC did allow session cookie sharing between clients. /code re
p strong Problem conclusion /strong
p The JAX-WS synchronous proxy code was corrected and now supports session sharing between client BindingProvider instances.
p JAX-WS allows client applications to copy session cookies from one BindingProvider's request context and put it on another BindingProvider instance's request context to effectively share a session.
p The fix for this APAR is currently targeted for inclusion in fixpack 6.1.0.25 and 7.0.0.1. Please refer to the Recommended Updates page for delivery information: a href="http://www.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?rs=180 ;amp;uid=swg27004980" rel="nofollow" http://www.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?rs=180 ;amp;uid=swg27004980 /a

I can take two paths: br 1. Implemenet a logic that will ,based on content, be able to presume original queue. br 2. Use BO queue per Queue. br Is that correct?
Input queue of Message in WebSphere MQ Backout Queue
websphere-mq

p Since I ran into some additional "gotchas", I thought I'd post my final solution.
p The script I am using does not call a webservice, but directly connects and reads the WebSphere queue. However, in order to do this, I have to add a reference to amqmdnet.dll.
p You can add a reference to a Script strong Task /strong (which sits on the Control Flow canvas), but not to a Script strong Component /strong (which is part of the Data Flow).
p So I have a Script Task, with reference and code to read the contents of the queue. Each line in the queue is just a fixed width record, and each is added to a List. At the end, the List is put into a Read/Write object variable declared at the package level.
p The Script feeds into a Data Flow task. The first component of the Data Flow is a Script Component, created as Source, as billinkc describes above. This script casts the object variable back to a list. Then parses each item in the list to fields in the Output Buffer. Various split and transform tasks take over from there.
