p I've been considering for some time now to get into be b2b integration business. I've researched the tools available for doing this, like Oragle's WebLogic Integration, IBM's WebSphere, or Microsoft's BizTalk. They all seem to do the job (each having their ups and downs).
p I've also looked at some companies that already are doing this (ex: a href="http://www.hubspan.com" rel="nofollow" www.hubspan.com /a ). It seems that b2b integration is very needed service.
p Although my background is in integration of commercial products with open source software, I feel that concerning the b2b integration world, I still feel that I need to feel some blanks.
p So basically I'd like to clear a few things concerning all this:
ol li p All the frameworks that I previously mentioned are just that, frameworks. They allow to build an application ON TOP of the said frameworks, they are not itendet ot be a final product. I assume that this is because the integration needs of different companies vary so much, that an out-of-the-box solution is just not possible. So my question is, do the applications build with the said frameworks vary so much from business to business, that it's not possible to reuse them? /li li p Also, is it possible to build a single framework of Suppliers and Customers (build a Core of somekind), and connect new Costumers and/or Suppliers as they come? (this is the way a href="http://www.hubspan.com" rel="nofollow" HubSpan /a did it, not counting the developing of custom Connectors to the Client ERP systems). Or will I have to do a separate integration for each Customer? /li li p How much work hours is required to complete a typical integration project, (assuming everything is planned and executed properly)? (For the sake of simplicity, let's say that the integration includes only 'Query Product Price', 'Query Product Availability', and 'Purchase Order Management'. /li li p And finally, is this a job for a sigle person (can I do this myself?, assuming I have the knowledge to do it) or a team is required? /li /ol
p Thanks in advance for sharing your thoughs and oppinions.
B2B Application Building and Maintenance Cost
integration b2b

p As far as I know it is Java that does not allow to kill a thread which is hung. The best thing is to avoid hanging threads by hunting down the cause. Like already mentioned in the other answer, try to force the application server to create a thread dump (aka Java Core) and analyze its content. On Linux/UNIX systems a
pre code kill -3 pid /code re
p will do the job. You'll find free graphical tools in the internet to look into these dumps. I typically use one which is called a href="https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/community/groups/service/html/communityview?communityUuid=2245aa39-fa5c-4475-b891-14c205f7333c" rel="nofollow" IBM Thread and Monitor Dump Analyzer for Java /a . The WebSphere Application Server log file will tell you the thread name to look for.

p WASCE 3 is a Java EE 6 container, so it has support for JSF 2.0 (if it wouldn't have this, it couldn't be called Java EE 6).
p Do note that people typically don't mean WASCE when they refer to WebSphere. WASCE is another name for the server otherwise known as Apache Geronimo. The difference is that it's specifically supported by IBM.
p What people do mean with WebSphere is the one you can find here: a href="http://ibm.com/software/webservers/appserv/was" rel="nofollow" ibm.com/software/webservers/appserv/was /a
p For JSF 2.0 you would need the latest version, which is version 8.

p I haven't tried this, but here's a possibility
p I'm assuming you are wanting to disable WAS 7 .dmp files.
p from the AppServer\java\bin directory command-line run
p code java -Xdump:what /code
p This shows that .dmp files are created when certain types of events occur
pre code -Xdump:system: events=gpf+abort+traceassert, label=P:\IBM\WebSphere\AppServer\java\bin\core.%Y%m%d.%H%M%S.%pid.%seq.dmp, range=1..0, priority=999, request=serial /code re
p It's for an older jvm version, but see this a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/javasdk/tools/topic/com.ibm.java.doc.igaa/_1vg000131402ee-11e49e6e566-7fdc_1001.html" rel="nofollow" infocenter page /a for what these mean.
p You should be able to disable from the WAS solutions console. Mine is a href="http://localhost:10042/ibm/console" rel="nofollow" http://localhost:10042/ibm/console /a but I run WebSphere Portal on WAS - your port may be different.
p Login and go to Servers/Server Types/WebSphere Application Servers/ rocess definition/Java Virtaul Machine page.
p Add the -Xdump:system:... settings you wish to the existing arguments being careful not to mess up the existing syntax. Depending on what is causing the crash you could remove that from the events= portion. Probably gpf is the cause. You can look at line 1TISIGINFO in the .txt files that accompany the .dmp files. I have a few that say Dump Event "gpf".
p You may be able to set these settings on the WAS server properties in RAD as well but I couldn't find anything there.
p Of course, you are just covering up the problem by doing this, but at least you will not have to endure the .dmp file writing while you are trying to find the problem.

p The JMS specification does not provide an API for object inquiry, however IBM provides one using native Java classes and the C API using Programmable Command Formats, or PCF for short. The PCF reference docs are a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r1/topic/com.ibm.mq.doc/zr00120_.htm" rel="nofollow" here /a .
p If you have installed the WMQ client code ( a href="http://ibm.co/SupptPacMQC71" rel="nofollow" free download with registration /a ) you will have the sample programs on your laptop. By default, these reside in code C:\Program Files (x86)\IBM\WebSphere MQ\tools\pcf\samples /code for Windows or in code /opt/mqm/samp/ /code for UNIX/Linux. Take a look at code PCF_ListQueueNames.java /code for a starting point. If you were to substitute code MQCMD_INQUIRE_Q /code for code MQCMD_INQUIRE_Q_NAMES /code in that program you'd be very close to what you require.
p Alternatively since you requested alternatives, you might look at a href="http://ibm.co/SupptPacMO72" rel="nofollow" SupportPac MO72 /a . This SupportPac can be used as a client version of code runmqsc /code so that you can, from a central server, write scripts that query your entire WMQ network. Of course, it also works in local bindings mode. Among the other features that make MO72 great for scripting is an option to format output to one line per object. This lets you grep out the line of interest, then strip out the value of interest.

p I believe the middleware people are wrong:
blockquote h3 JMSMessageID from MQMD MessageID /h3
p All messages sent from JMS have unique message identifiers assigned by WebSphereÂ® MQ. The value assigned is returned in the MQMD messageId field after the MQPUT call, and is passed back to the application in the JMSMessageID field. The WebSphere MQ messageId is a 24-byte binary value, whereas the JMSMessageID is a string. The JMSMessageID is composed of the binary messageId value converted to a sequence of 48 hexadecimal characters, strong prefixed with the characters ID: /strong . JMS provides a hint that can be set to disable the production of message identifiers. This hint is ignored, and a unique identifier is assigned in all cases. Any value that is set into the JMSMessageId field before a send() is overwritten. /blockquote
p From: a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv6/v6r0/index.jsp?topic=%2Fcom.ibm.mq.csqzaw.doc%2Fuj25470_.htm" rel="nofollow" Mapping JMS header fields at send() or publish() /a .
p Also I remember noticing that prefix while working with JMS-WebsphereMQ bridge. But actually - why do you care? del This is a code String /code id, the specification doesn't say anything about its structure, except that it has to be unique. /del
p UPDATE: Actually, as mentioned by em @skaffman /em , the code ID: /code prefix is required by a href="http://download.oracle.com/otndocs/jcp/jms-2_0-edr-spec/index.html" rel="nofollow" JMS specification /a :
blockquote h3 3.4.3. JMSMessageID /h3
p All code JMSMessageID /code values must start with the prefix â€˜ code ID: /code â€™. Uniqueness of message ID values across different providers is not required. /blockquote
p This means that WebsphereMQ bridge is adding code ID: /code prefix only to be compliant with JMS spec. And, as also noted by em @skaffman /em , ActiveMQ is not compliant with it...

p IBM JDKs (including WebSphere Real Time) support the java.lang.Compiler API, including the disable() and enable() calls. It's not something we generally recommend using, because it obviously interferes with the JIT compiler's heuristics used to identify what code should be compiled, but the facility is there and supported from Java 5 on (which is where the Compiler API was introduced).

p I'd guess the difference is the way the code ClassLoader /code s behave. Can you use the code Class /code variant instead? MyClass. a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javase/1.5.0/docs/api/java/lang/Class.html#getResource%28java.lang.String%29" rel="nofollow" class.getResource() /a ? We use code Class.getResourceAsStream() /code under WebSphere 6.1 all the time.
p Or perhaps try prefacing your resource path with a leading slash.
p Using the code Class /code variant, your relative path will look in the code resources /code subdirectory under the package of code MyClass /code . But the code ClassLoader /code variant might not.

p There is no standardized way to access files stored under WEB-INF. The spirit of the WEB-INF folder is that it contains data that the framework (container/server) reads. It is not seen as a place for data that the user of the container (you) read directly. Depending on the container software (and version) that you are using (Tomcat vs. JBoss vs. WebSphere vs. WebLogic, etc), you might be able to kludge your way into WEB-INF, but it would not be portable across containers, and so I would not recommend it.
p Consider putting the files somewhere else, such as in the classpath or in a subfolder of the webapp that is not WEB-INF.

It requires to create an EAR to run it on WAS, but in this case there're 2 projects in project explorer; EAR project ;amp; the normal one... the normal is almost an empty project, but everything from SVN is kept under EAR project. But they can't simply access index.jsp file from WebContent folder when they try to run EAR project on WAS, it says strong "Failed to find resource /index.jsp" /strong .
p Any suggestions?
existing Spring MVC project into RAD + WAS
spring-mvc websphere rad websphere-7 ibm-rad

p I am not 100% sure what exactly causes the problem, but it is related to some incompatibility.
p On websphere it often help to change the class loader order for the WAR!! to "parent last"
hr
p In one of my projects I have also had some problems with code org.apache.xerces /code on Webshpere. In this case it worked after exclude code org.apache.xerces /code from shipping with the application.
p "My" error was
pre code by: java.lang.ClassCastException: org.apache.xerces.jaxp.validation.XMLSchemaFactory incompatible with javax.xml.validation.SchemaFactory at javax.xml.validation.SchemaFactory.newInstance(Unknown Source) at com.ibm.ws.jpa.management.JPAPxmlInfo.extractPersistenceUnits(JPAPxmlInfo.java:239) /code re
p So I never connected org.apache.xerces with your tiles problems.
p BTW in the same project I used Tiles and it worked on WebSphere 7.0 (with excluded code org.apache.xerces /code ). But I used other Versions:
ul li tiles 2.2.1 /li li commons-digester 2.0 /li /ul

p Actually, code System.exit() /code is too brutal and... won't work. Retrying of failed messages is handled on the broker (WMQ) side so the message will be redelivered once you restart your application.
p The problem you are describing is called a href="/questions/tagged oison-message" class="post-tag" title="show questions tagged 'poison-message'" rel="tag" poison-message /a and should be handled on the broker side. It seems to be described in a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv6/v6r0/index.jsp?topic=%2Fcom.ibm.mq.csqzaw.doc%2Fuj25590_.htm" rel="nofollow" Handling poison messages /a in WMQ manual and in a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/library/techarticles/0405_titheridge/0405_titheridge.html" rel="nofollow" How WebSphere Application Server handles poison messages /a .

p You have to deploy Jersey for the former to work, don't you? The latter is part of WebSphere and officially supported under WebSphere (meaning you can get IBM support if you have problems with it).
p (A quick web search does show at least a few hits on quirks or difficulties with Jersey under some versions of WebSphere, some of them even right here on StackOverflow.)

p We just ran into this problem last week. It seems like the specialized plug-in class WebSphereUowTransactionManager has been changed in Spring to adapt to Websphere 7.x
p We were using Spring framework version 3.0.5 against a WebSphere 6.1 installation. However, when we migrated to WebSphere 7.1 we had similar problems to the ones you mentioned above. We went crazy for a while trying to figure out the problem until we upgraded our Spring framework to version 3.1.1. Now everything runs smoothly once again.
p Best of luck.

p I think this is always going to be a tradeoff between performance during normal operations and how quickly a down cluster member is detected.
p See this article, a href="http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21219808" rel="nofollow" Understanding HTTP plug-in failover in a clustered environment /a and a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v7r0/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.websphere.base.doc/info/aes/ae/rwsv_plugincfg.html" rel="nofollow" this plugin-cfg.xml reference in the WebSphere 7 InfoCenter /a .
p From the article, the answer will involve the code ConnectTimeout /code , code ServerIOTimeout /code , and code RetryInterval /code settings, but note the warning that:
blockquote p In an environment with busy workload or a slow network connection, setting this value too low could make the HTTP plug-in mark a cluster member down falsely. Therefore, caution should be used whenever choosing a value for ConnectTimeout.â€‹â€‹ /blockquote

p See
ul li a href="http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/moreinfo/jee.php" rel="nofollow" Eclipse IDE for Java EE developers /a , /li li a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/radhelp/v8r5/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.rad.install.doc/topics/t_install_wdt.html" rel="nofollow" Installing WebSphere Application Server Developer Tools for Eclipse /a , /li li a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/aix/tutorials/au-wasonlinux/section2.html" rel="nofollow" Install and configure WebSphere Application Server on UNIX and Linux systems /a br/ as well as /li li a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/forums/thread.jspa?threadID=119101" rel="nofollow" IBM developerworks Forum thread about installing WAS CE onto MacOSX /a . /li /ul
p In brief, Eclipse has full support for WAS and is platform-agnostic. WAS can be installed onto OSX all right with only a few custom steps to allow for OSX FS hierarchy differences, though it's not an officially supported setup.
p a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4775341/set-up-eclipse-to-work-with-java-ee" Set up Eclipse to work with Java EE /a question may be useful to configure integration for a project.

p I have a Java EE web application (WebSphere 7). The code looks up EJBs on the app server by doing JDNI look ups.
p In my development environment (Eclipse / IBM RAD), the EAR project is called customerEAR, so the JNDI lookup is like this:
pre code ejblocal:customerEAR.ear/customerEJB.jar/CustomerService@com.mydomain.service.CustomerServiceLocal /code re
p But when the EAR is deployed on the production application server, the lookup fails and the log file states that the EJB is available at:
pre code ejblocal:server1-dev-customerEAR.ear/customerEJB.jar/CustomerService@com.mydomain.service.CustomerServiceLocal /code re
p It's possible that the guy deploying the EAR to the server is actually renaming the EAR file from customerEAR.ear to server1-dev-customerEAR.jar -- or maybe WebSphere is renaming stuff on deployment? I can't get hold of the deployment guy to find out for sure.
p But, regardless, my question is:
p Is there a cleaner way to do the lookup of the EJBs? Like, by using a shorter lookup name, or a "relative path" instead of the "full path"?
p Any suggestions are greatly appreciated, thanks!
p Rob
Is there a shorter name I can use to do a JNDI lookup of an EJB?
ejb websphere

p I have EAR with one web application inside. In this web application I get a data source reference through JNDI. So I have a JDBC type resource reference in my web.xml:
pre code resource-ref description TCCC Database /description res-ref-name jdbc/tccc /res-ref-name res-type javax.sql.DataSource /res-type res-auth Container /res-auth /resource-ref /code re
p I have to deploy my EAR to strong WebSphere App Server 7.0 /strong and for my resource reference (jdbc/tccc) I must specify a JNDI name in order to bind this logical name to the physical location of the DB resource.
p I successfully set up and configured a JDBC provider, data source and security settings on my WAS instance according to the documentation. And using web administration console I've deployed my EAR binding manually on some step HOST and JNDI so that strong ibm-web-bnd.xml /strong looks like:
p code virtual-host name="default_host" resource-ref name="jdbc/tccc" br binding-name="jdbc/tccc/oracle " /code
p Where â€œjdbc/tccc/oracleâ€� is a JNDI name for the datasource that I configured on WAS. Everything is working fine.
p But now I want to do all deployment just by using strong ws_ant /strong and appropriate tasks like InstallApplication, UninstallApplication etc. I've created an appropriate build.xml file with needed tasks and now can uninstall and install my app. But how can I bind app JNDI name to JNDI name of datasource on server. Using defaultBindings task I can bind host to default_host. How I can achieve the same with JNDI. I've been trying to set defaultDataSource argument in defaultBindings task but it always creates ibm-web-bnd.xml with the same binding-name value:
p code virtual-host name="default_host" resource-ref name="jdbc/tccc" br binding-name="jdbc/tccc " /code
p Importang thing: I have to bind resource reference only strong during deployment /strong to bind to different datasources in future.
WebSphere 7 deployment using ws_ant
deployment websphere websphere-7

p No, it is not possible to directly call methods in a backing bean in another WAR. Here are a few alternative approaches:
ol li Expose the methods in the "other WAR" using something like Remote EJBs or SOAP/REST services. /li li Store the data in a cache that is visible to both WARs. If you use JBoss, then JBoss Cache could meet your needs. /li li Enable session-sharing, and store the data in the session. Not all app servers support this; I know WebSphere does. /li /ol

p The EJB specification requires that the container schedule "catch up" timer events if it's unable to fire a timer because it was already running. In practice, containers probably recalculate the next fire time after the method has completed, and then immediately re-execute if the next fire time is "before" the current time. I know this is how WebSphere Application Server works.
p Note that the default code ConcurrencyManagement(ConcurrencyManagemementType.CONTAINER) /code for the bean and code Lock(LockType.WRITE) /code for the timer method will prevent any other methods from being executed. If you need other methods on that bean, you might consider using code ConcurrencyManagementType.BEAN /code .

p Trace for SOAP WS messages can be enabled by following these steps on Websphere 7 administration console:
ul li Go to administration console /li li Go to: Servers - WebSphere application servers - server Change Log Detail Levels /li li In the package tree find this package, click on package name and choose 'All Mesasges and Traces', as result you should have log details set as below: /li /ul
blockquote p *=info: com.ibm.ws.websvcs.trace.*=all /blockquote
ul li Click on 'OK' and then Save the changes. /li /ul
p SOAP request/responses can now be found in em trace.log /em on your appl. server.

p Channels are expected to go down. The idea is that they stay active as long as there is traffic and then time out. Assuming they've been configured to trigger, the presence of a message on the XMitQ causes the channel to start up again.
p The reason for this is that a triggered channel will generally restart if interrupted by a network failure or other adverse event. However if a channel is configured to stay running 24x7 then the only way it stops is due to one of these adverse events and that increases the likelihood that human intervention will be required to restart the channel. On the other hand, a channel that times out can survive all sorts of nasty network events that occur while it is inactive. Allowing it to time out when not in use thus improves overall reliability of the channel.
p So how do you cause a channel to trigger? Make sure the transmission queue contains the code TRIGGER /code , code TRIGTYPE /code , code TRIGDATA /code and code INITQ /code attributes. For example, to define a transmission queue to the code JUPITER /code QMgr:
pre code DEF QL(JUPITER) + USAGE(XMITQ) + TRIGGER + TRIGTYPE(FIRST) + TRIGDATA('MYQMGR.JUPITER') + INITQ(SYSTEM.CHANNEL.INITQ) + REPLACE /code re
p The only variable of the bunch is code TRIGDATA /code which contains the name of the channel serving this XMitQ.
p Of course, the channel initiator must be running but in modern versions of WMQ it starts by default (based on the value of the queue manager's code SCHINIT /code attribute) so generally em will /em in fact be running.
p The channel that is in code STOPPED /code state cannot be triggered. By default the code STOP CHL /code command uses code STATUS(STOPPED) /code so most of the time manually stopping a channel prevents triggering. If you want to stop a channel in such a way that it will restart (for example to test triggering) use the code STOP CHL(CHLNAME) STATUS(INACTIVE) /code command. If the channel is already in code STOPPED /code state, either issue the code START CHL /code command to make it start immediately or use the code STOP CHL(CHLNAME) STATUS(INACTIVE) /code to change the status from code STOPPED /code to code INACTIVE /code without starting it.
p Once the channels are up, the code DISCINT /code attribute of the channel determines how long it will run before timing out. The value is in seconds and defaults to 600 which is 10 minutes. The code DISCINT /code , code KAINT /code and code HBINT /code combine to determine when the channel comes down. Note that the TCP spec calls for things using keepalive to disable them by default so if you want to use keepalive on your channels, you em must /em enable it in the QMgr tuning as described a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r1/topic/com.ibm.mq.doc/cs13390_.htm" rel="nofollow" here /a .
p Please see a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r1/topic/com.ibm.mq.doc/ic10580_.htm" rel="nofollow" Triggering Channels /a in the Infocenter for more on the configuration details. Take a look at a href="http://ibm.co/SupptPacMD0C" rel="nofollow" SupportPac MD0C /a em WebSphere MQ - Keeping Channels Up and Running /em if you want to know more about the internals and tuning. (The SupportPac is a bit dated but the principles of tuning mostly still apply. Where there are discrepancies, the Infocenter is the authoritative version.)
p If you want to keep channels up continuously, set code DISCINT(0) /code but remember that triggering remains the preferred option. Some shops need to minimize response times during the business day and so set code DISCINT /code to a value that allows the channels to time out at night but generally keeps them running all day. If for some reason you have triggering set up right and the channels go down prior to code DISCIINT /code you should be able to check in the error logs for the reason why. These reside in the QMgr's directory under code errors /code . For example, on UNIX/Linux they are in code /var/mqm/qmgrs/qmgrname/errors /code and on Windows the default location is code C:\Program Files(x86)\WebSphere MQ\QMgrs\qmgrname\errors /code . Look for the files named code AMQERR??.LOG /code where code ?? /code = code 01 /code , code 02 /code , or code 03 /code . The logs rotate where code 01 /code is current, code 02 /code is next and so on. If you have a very busy QMgr you need to capture these as soon as the channel goes down or they could roll off.

Fixing those problems eliminated this exception.

p Experimentation indicates that it takes on the order of strong 12 minutes for the files to appear! /strong
p One more bit of background that may be significant: There are 19 application servers on this one WebSphere instance. WebSphere insists that there be a lot of chatter between them, even though they don't need anything from each other. I wondered if this might be slowing things down when it comes to deployment. Or if there's some timer in the bowels of WebSphere that is just set wrong (usual disclaimers apply...I'm just showing up and finding this situation...I didn't configure this installation).

p In fact it depends on many factors:
ul li p If both jar files are in the same ClassLoader, for instance the Java classpath ( code -cp /code option), normally it should be the first file found in the jar list order. /li li p If deployed in a JavaEE container, like in an EAR file or in code WEB-INF/lib /code or a WAR file, there is no warranty the container will load the same class between two startups. In that context, the only thing sure is that code WEB-INF/classes /code is searched before code WEB-INF/lib /code /li li p In a complex ClassLoader hierarchy, the default behavior is parent-first search but JavaEE implementations have introduced mechanisms like parent-last policy (WebSphere) or filtering thanks to deployment descriptors (WebLogic) /li /ul
p An option may be to declare a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/technotes/guides/jar/jar.html#Main%20Attributes" rel="nofollow" jar file dependencies /a in code META-INF/MANIFEST.MF /code file thanks to the code Class-Path /code attribute. It should enforce a loading order at the ClassLoader level, particularly when started with code java -jar myapp.jar /code but it may depend on implementations in a JavaEE context.
p em Remark: /em when using an OpenSource project, it may be fair to submit a change request and publish your changes or improvements so that the community takes benefits from it. Then your project may update to main stream without such a difficulty of wild patches in your ClassPath.

p I'm not so sure about the jms interface, but in native WMQ, the queue manager does not automatically requeue the message to the backout queue. it is up to the application to query the backout_count, compare that to the backout_threshold, and put the messages to backout_queue.
p You should read "How WebSphere Application Server handles poison messages" -- a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/library/techarticles/0405_titheridge/0405_titheridge.html" rel="nofollow" http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/library/techarticles/0405_titheridge/0405_titheridge.html /a
p Also important to read "Best Practices: WebSphere MQ shared queues and application programs", scroll down to Issue 6 -- a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/library/techarticles/0512_elkins/0512_elkins.html" rel="nofollow" http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/library/techarticles/0512_elkins/0512_elkins.html /a

p I believe this is a problem with your EJB container. I am not sure what you are using (JBoss, WebSphere, WebLogic, etc), and I am no expert on any of them (we stopped using EJBs a long time ago), but any time you get a NoClassDefFound error, it means the current ClassLoader (the one that loaded the .class your code id "in") cannot find a referenced class.
p I know many, many moons ago, JBoss used to have the idea of a "Universal ClassLoader". Basically, all JARs/EARs/WARs were loaded in one big pool. The problem is that a lot of time the code needed different versions of the same JAR, and they were not always compatible. Also, there technically a security risk if someone drops a "custom" class/JAR into the mix ahead of yours. I think it was around JBoss 3.5 that they switched away from the Universal ClassLoader, as I remember our app needed a LOT of work to fix things up to work right. Most of this was a packaging issue for us.

p The embeddable EJB container in WebSphere Application Server does not support ExtendedJTATransaction, but it does support java:comp/TransactionSynchronizationRegistry. I am not familiar with Hibernate, but it would seem that it should be updated to use TransactionSynchronizationRegistry when available.

p Any queue designated as an error or exception queue (backout queue in WebSphere MQ terminology) is an ordinary queue. The code BOQNAME /code on a primary queue points to the backout queue but there is no attribute of the backout queue that points back to the primary queue. This might be a one-to-many relationship because any number of primary queues might point to a single backout queue.
p One way to do this in WMQ Explorer would be to make sure that code BOQNAME /code is visible in the display and then sort the queue list on that column. Then look for all instances with your backout queue name in them.

p If you don't have the problem in WebSphere v6, it's possible it is a leak in v8 itself. But it's also possible that v8 is being more strict about something that v6 was letting you get away with.
p Have you checked that you're reusing all the Axis2 client objects that you can, rather than recreating ones on every call that you don't need to recreate? I recall us having some leakage in Axis2 client code under WAS v6.1 and realizing that we were recreating objects that we could be reusing instead.

p There is no way.
p You should preferably not explicitly map to the container's default servlet in any way. You're not only tight coupling your webapp to the specific container, but until about one year ago, there was also a huge security hole when doing that in Tomcat and clones (JBoss, WebSphere, etc). It enables the attackers to request files (containing possibly sensitive information) in code /WEB-INF /code and code /META-INF /code whenever the default servlet was mapped on a different URL pattern than code / /code . See also a href="https://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=50026" rel="nofollow" issue 50026 /a , reported by yours truly.
p Rather map your front controller servlet on a more specific URL pattern instead of code /* /code and create and map a global filter on code /* /code which forwards to either the front controller or continues to the default servlet depending on the current request URI. See for a concrete example also a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/870150/how-to-access-static-resources-when-using-default-servlet/3593513#3593513" How to access static resources when using default servlet /a .

p Does JMS mean "Java Message Service" to you?
p I doubt that there's a course devoted solely to that topic. It's more likely to be part of a larger Java EE class given for one of the app server vendors (JBOSS, WebLogic, WebSphere, Glassfish, etc.)
p You could also look into ActiveMQ instruction from a vendor like Spring.
p I'd be surprised if the general information available on-line was insufficient. The details of configuration are usually app server specific.

p From the WebSphere documentation:
blockquote p a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v8r0/index.jsp?topic=%2Fcom.ibm.websphere.nd.multiplatform.doc%2Finfo%2Fae%2Fae%2Fujpx_rewrite.html" rel="nofollow" http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v8r0/index.jsp?topic=%2Fcom.ibm.websphere.nd.multiplatform.doc%2Finfo%2Fae%2Fae%2Fujpx_rewrite.html /a
p Rewriting rules define how the proxy server rewrites URLs. Responses that have been redirected by target servers typically return a 302 status code with a location header that defines the URL that the client should be redirected to. Rewriting this URL is necessary if the target server is not aware of the proxy servers. The redirected URL is modified to correctly point clients to the proxy server instead of directly to a target server that may not be visible to clients. Use the following properties to configure the URL rewriting rules for a proxy server
p Avoid trouble: The proxy server only supports rewriting redirected responses. Therefore, these the following settings only apply to redirected responses. These settings do not apply to requests because the proxy server does not support URL rewriting for requests. /blockquote

p Migrating a legacy application from WebSphere v.6 to WebSphere v.8. The application's web.xml only contains declarations of servlets but not servlet-mappings. Yet all servlets without a servlet-mapping are accessible by a default url pattern /servlet/[servlet name]. However, on WAS8, if web.xml is updated with attribute version set to "3.0":
pre code web-app xmlns="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee/web-app_3_0.xsd" **version="3.0"** /code re
p servlets loose default mapping and need to be explicitly mapped otherwise it's 404 page not found.
p Is there a way in servlet 3.0 or at least WebSphere 8, to define a default url pattern for all servlets? There's InvokerServlet for tomcat, is there a version of it for WebSphere v.8?

p The jar and context factory mentioned would tend to indicate that the WMQ client was borrowed from a WebSphere Application Server install rather than using the stand-alone WMQ client installer. If that is the case you can likely fix this quite easily by installing the stand-alone client. You can obtain this free (with registration) as a SupportPac. These are by version so you have your choice of:
ul li V7.1 client is a href="http://ibm.co/SupptPacMQC71" rel="nofollow" SupportPacMQC71 /a (Preferred) /li li V7.0 client is a href="http://ibm.co/SupptPacMQC7" rel="nofollow" SupportPacMQC7 /a /li li V6.0 client is a href="http://ibm.co/SupptPacMQC6" rel="nofollow" SupportPacMQC6 /a (Out of support as of September 2012) /li /ul
p Note that installing the client from the IBM-supplied installer provides a number of additional features such as diagnostics for tracing, version display, initial verification test code, sample source code, etc. This is the method of install that IBM will support so even though you can get it to work by copying the jars from the WMQ server install, using IBM's media is recommended.
p Note also that the packaging of the Java and JMS classes has changed between versions. It is important to know which version that you are using and refer to the corresponding docs for code CLASSPATH /code and other config options. The v7.1 implementation has many functional improvements and is the only version that will take advantage of the features on a v7.1 QMgr. However it will connect to em any /em version QMgr so if this is new development, try to use the v7.1 client now so that you don't end up needing to upgrade down the road.
p The Infocenter links for each version of the client are:
ul li V7.1 Infocenter a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r1/topic/com.ibm.mq.doc/jm10330_.htm" rel="nofollow" Environment Varariables for JMS /a ;amp; a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r1/topic/com.ibm.mq.doc/jm10300_.htm" rel="nofollow" Installing classes for JMS /a /li li V7.0 Infocenter a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r0/topic/com.ibm.mq.csqzaf.doc/cs10120_.htm" rel="nofollow" Clients /a and a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r0/topic/com.ibm.mq.csqzaw.doc/uj10120_.htm" rel="nofollow" Using Java /a manuals /li li V7.0 Infocenter a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv6/v6r0/topic/com.ibm.mq.csqzaf.doc/cs10120_.htm" rel="nofollow" Clients /a and a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv6/v6r0/topic/com.ibm.mq.csqzaw.doc/uj10120_.htm" rel="nofollow" Using Java /a manuals /li /ul
p One of the utilities supplied with the IBM installer is the code setmqjmsenv /code script (and code setmqjmsenv64 /code when installing the 64-bit client) in the code java/bin /code directory. You can look here to determine the code CLASSPATH /code and other environment variables needed for your version of WMQ Client Classes for Java.

p My simple piece of code was intended to login to web application (loginUrl - using http POST) and then go to another page within same app (theurl - using GET).
p Here's my code:
pre code host = 'http://myhost.mydomain:9080' theurl = host + '/am/ve/mod/console/'#?orderBy=ORDER_BY_ADMIN_APP ;amp;order=ASC ;amp;viewBy=1 ;amp;pagesize=20'
username = 'myuser' password = 'mypass' loginUrl = host + '/am/en/common/j_security_check' values = {} values['submit'] = '1' values['dest'] = 'null' values['j_username'] = username values['j_password'] = password
data = urllib.urlencode(values) headers = {'Cache-control': 'max-age=0', 'Pragma': 'no-cache', 'User-agent': 'Mozilla/5.0'}
cookieprocessor = urllib2.HTTPCookieProcessor() http_handler = urllib2.HTTPHandler(debuglevel=1) opener = urllib2.build_opener(http_handler, cookieprocessor)
print "========================= POST request =====================" request = urllib2.Request(loginUrl, data, headers) opener.open(request) print "========================= GET request =====================" request = urllib2.Request(theurl, headers=headers, unverifiable=True) page = opener.open(request)
print "Final url: " + page.geturl() /code re

p I had the same issue with WebSphere 6.1. As Ceki pointed out, there were tons of jars that WebSphere was using and one of them was pointing to a older version of slf4j.
p The No-Op rollback happens only with slf4j -1.6+ so anything older than that will throw an exception and halts your deployment.
p There is a documentation in a href="http://www.slf4j.org/codes.html#StaticLoggerBinder" rel="nofollow" SLf4J site /a to resolve this. I followed that and added code slf4j-simple-1.6.1.jar /code to my aplication along with code slf4j-api-1.6.1.jar /code which i already had.
p This solved my issue. Hope it helps for someone who faces this issue.

p This indicates that there's a conflict with another JSF implementation in the webapp's runtime classpath. Full fledged Java EE application servers like JBoss AS, Glassfish, WebSphere, Weblogic, etc already ship with JSF bundled since that's part of the Java EE API. If you supply JSF in your webapp's code /WEB-INF/lib /code as well, it may conflict with the appserver-bundled JSF. The JSF API part will be loaded from the appserver-provided JSF libraries, but the JSF impl part will be loaded from the webapp-provided JSF libraries. If they are of a different version, then you'll get configuration errors like this.
p You have 2 options:
ol li p Remove the webapp-bundled JSF and rely on the server-bundled JSF. /li li p Tell the server to use webapp-bundled JSF instead. How to do that depends on the server make/version. In your particular case with JBoss 7.x, that would be a matter of adding the following context parameter to webapp's code web.xml /code :
pre class="lang-xml prettyprint-override" code context-param param-name org.jboss.jbossfaces.WAR_BUNDLES_JSF_IMPL aram-name param-value true aram-value /context-param /code re /li /ol
p Barebones JSP/Servlet containers like Tomcat, Jetty, etc doesn't ship with JSF bundled, that's why you would need to provide your own JSF libraries in code /WEB-INF/lib /code when targeting such containers.
h3 See also: /h3
ul li a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5815623/jsf-2-issues-in-application-servers" JSF 2 Issues in Application Servers? /a /li /ul

p Solr is using unmanaged threads here and is doing a JNDI lookup in the java: namespace in one of these threads. That is not supported in WebSphere because WebSphere identifies the java: namespace based on the thread performing the lookup. Tomcat does this based on the thread context class loader, which explains the difference in behavior. Note that unmanaged threads are not allowed by the J2EE specs, so that WebSphere's behavior is actually standards compliant.

p If somebody comes over this issue again in relation to the EJB TimerTask - like I just did - here is a hint if you're using WebSphere Application Server:
p There are 2 batch files / shell scripts in the profile's bin folder, which can list and delete the EJB timer tasks. In my case, I had some timer tasks which serialized objects with a different, outdated serialVersionUID. I was't able to get rid of them, since the serialized objects really changed. So I just used those:
p findEJBTimers.bat cancelEJBTimers.bat
p Your timer tasks are gone then and so are the error messages. In my case that was exactly what I needed, but it was hard to get this infos.

p Turns out older versions of WebSphere used proprietary ibm-web-*.xmi descriptors to define vendor specific deployment options. However, since v8.0 the support for .xmi files got dropped (yet still supported for backwards compatibility in applications declared as servlet "2.4"). The old application I was migrating contained the following ibm-web-ext.xmi in WEB-INF:
pre code ?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"? com.ibm.ejs.models.base.extensions.webappext:WebAppExtension xmi:version="2.0" xmlns:xmi="http://www.omg.org/XMI" xmlns:com.ibm.ejs.models.base.extensions.webappext="webappext.xmi" xmi:id="WebApp_ID_Ext" reloadingEnabled="true" fileServingEnabled="true" directoryBrowsingEnabled="false" serveServletsByClassnameEnabled="true" webApp href="WEB-INF/web.xml#cchange" extendedServlets xmi:id="ServletExtension_1" extendedServlet href="WEB-INF/web.xml#Servlet_1" /extendedServlets jspAttributes xmi:id="JSPAttribute_1" name="keepgenerated" value="true" jspAttributes xmi:id="JSPAttribute_1333518196516" name="reloadEnabled" value="true" jspAttributes xmi:id="JSPAttribute_1333518196517" name="reloadInterval" value="10" /com.ibm.ejs.models.base.extensions.webappext:WebAppExtension /code re
p so the attribute serveServletsByClassnameEnabled="true" made the old app map servlets by name without servlet-mapping. This is not supported if the application is servlet 3.0..
p No, it is not possible to either replace or disable CDI in WebSphere Application Server. My only (unsatisfactory) suggestion is to rework your code to avoid the idiosyncrasies.

p SOA main principles: Build systems as set of services where each service is
ul li Coarse-grained /li li Interoperable /li li Loosely coupled /li /ul
p A company offers a lot of business services (coarse-grained) developed over many years and exposed to the users (human or other systems) in some form. There are more chances that each of these features have been designed and developed not keeping the above three principles in mind. Moreover, each of those features might be running on disparate heterogeneous platforms, using different technologies etc.
p What if you want to integrate these disparate features thus creating new solutions (For e.g. Amazon store front is a new service composed of their catalog service, shopping cart service etc)?
p You have two choices:
ol li Building the new feature from scratch keeping the 3 principles in mind. But it is a very costly endeavor, and one thatâ€™s almost never successful. /li li An effective and less risky alternative is to assemble/compose it from existing, proven (well tested) services. /li /ol
p Option 2 is where strong ESBs /strong can help with their support for routing, transformation, monitoring etc. strong a href="http://camel.apache.org/" Apache Camel /a , a href="http://www.mulesoft.org/" Mule /a /strong are open-source ESB's. Endpoints ;amp; Routes are the terminology used in EIP ( a href="http://www.enterpriseintegrationpatterns.com/toc.html" Enterprise Integration Patterns /a ) that these ESB's implement. ESB's can take help of strong MOM's /strong when they want to route/integrate services that are running on heterogeneous platforms (For e.g. the catalog service might be running on a mainframe system but the shopping cart is implemented using strong stateful EJBs /strong running in a Java Application server). strong Message queue /strong is a concept in MOM that acts a temporary storage of the message between the sender and receiver. This temporary storage provides lot of benefits like asynchronous delivery, guaranteed delivery etc. Now, there can me multiple MOM vendors like IBM (WebSphere MQ), open-source ActiveMQ etc. We can use strong JMS /strong to keep your code independent of the vendor.
p I tried to relate all the concepts with an example. I also tried to keep it short. Please ask follow up questions to gain more understanding.
p MOM is not a requirement to implement SOA. For e.g. if all of your services are exposed over SOAP via HTTP then you doesn't need a MOM in this case.

p I don't know of anyone who has done volume testing of mosquitto to that number of connections. I suppose one thing you could do would be to test an instance of mosquitto on your chosen runtime and connect lots of client threads to it during your system testing.
p IBM's implementation using WebSphere MQ as the MQTT broker has been shown to support up to 100,000 concurrent connections. I believe IBM's free broker RSMB is limited to 1024 connections.
p You might want to consider how to scale out your broker using bridges and a provisioning service to work out which broker to connect new users to.

p You may be thinking of the Web Tools Platform (WTP) from eclipse. MyEclipse integrates much of the functionality of WTP but has a different way of configuring and deploying to servers. The MyEclipse servers view tab is called "Servers", the WTP servers view tab is called "WTP Servers". Double clicking on a server in WTP Servers will bring up an editor window of the type you describe. In the MyEclipse Servers view, you can bring up the configuration dialog by right clicking on the server and selecting "Configure Server Connector".
p In base MyEclipse, you don't have the option of setting ports and security from the server connector, for WebSphere. However, if you switch to the Blue Edition of MyEclipse (more money, though), you do get more extensive configuration capability for WebSphere. I'm not sure what options you have in base MyEclipse; if you can find VM arguments (setting system properties) that provide what you want, you can set these on the JDK page of the configuration screens or, if there are program arguments that can be set, these can be added via a launch configuration, which you can create from the server connector configuration pages (and can modify them by going to the Run Configurations (which can also be reached by right clicking on the server in the Servers view).
p Hope this helps. For better support, the MyEclipse forums (on their web site) are your best option.
p I had similar problem with CXF + XmlBeans + WebSphere, and i solved it by removing the org/w3c/dom package from XmlBeans dependency using truezip-maven-plugin.

p No, base WebSphere MQ does not directly transfer files. The semantics for moving files include such things as file names, directory paths, conversion of names across different types of filesystem (i.e. a UNIX filetree versus a z/OS Partitioned Dataset). Messaging uses semantics specific to queues and topics and these are drastically different from those for files.
p Accordingly, base WMQ does not attempt to perform file semantics as part of its core functionality. The a href="http://ibm.co/WMQFTE" rel="nofollow" WebSphere MQ File Transfer Edition /a and a href="http://ibm.co/INdXGf" rel="nofollow" IBM Sterling Connect:Direct /a provide that functionality. In the case of FTE, managed file transfer is natively built on top of WebSphere MQ.
p Many people have in the past written solutions to move files using messaging, whether that's WebSphere MQ or another transport provider. It turns out that doing so in a robust way is a non-trivial task. Here are some of the issues:
ul li If you make each file a single message then message sizes vary considerably. It is very difficult to tune the messaging engine to simultaneously perform with very large and very small messages. /li li If you break the files up into chunks then you cna tune chunk size for optimal messaging performance but now you must deal with sequence preservation and resend of missing messages. /li li The general problem of whether to append, replace or rename a destination file with the same name. /li li The general problem of how to make the file available at the destination in a transactional manner. You don't want the recipient to grab half a file. /li li File integrity (FTE hashes the file to insure it doesn't get changed in transit). /li /ul
p These are a sampling of the issues to do this in a general-purpose way. However if all you need is a one-time, point-to-point solution then have a look at a href="http://ibm.co/SupptPacMA01" rel="nofollow" SupportPac MA01 /a , the Q program. It will take files and either put a line at a time into a message or make the entire file a single message. It can also be used as a pipe so it's possible to have two instances of Q where one pipes messages to a queue and the other retrieves them.

p Take a look at the a href="http://t-rob.net/links" rel="nofollow" Hardening WebSphere MQ /a presentation for v7.0 and earlier. The thing to remember is that WMQ does not authenticate anything. It authorizes based on OS identities and groups but there is no password checking being done.
p For situations where QMgrs and clients live on Windows networks, the connection uses the SID and so it appears that some useful authentication was performed. BUT if a connection from a non-Windows platform is attempted, the Windows QMgr uses the string representation of the ID. So for example, if someone has a Linux VM on their desktop they can easily create a user ID called MUSR_MQADMIN and the Windows QMgr will accept the connection. There is a setting that causes the Windows QMgr to only accept connections with SIDS that it can resolve but even there its just a matter of knowing what the SID values are to spoof them on a connection.
p The lesson here is that strong any /strong QMgr, even one on Windows, must be configured to authenticate remote connections. With WMQ v7.1 and later, the QMgr has functionality to map X.509 certificate DNs to user IDs, or to perform IP filtering. Prior to v7.1 these functions required an exit such as a href="http://mrmq.dk" rel="nofollow" BlockIP2 /a . Capitalware sells a href="http://www.capitalware.biz/mqausx_overview.html" rel="nofollow" MQAUSX /a which has the functions of BlockIP2, plus will perform ID and password authentication and is supported.
p The first recommendation is to use a v7.1 QMgr so that you get the code CHLAUTH /code rules for mapping and filtering. Even if you don't use certificates v7.1 limits administrative connections so it is harder for an attacker to gain full admin rights. Then if you need password validation, use SSL channels (to encrypt the password and prevent simply replay attacks) in combination with an exit that you can write yourself or purchase.
p Just be aware that allowing a connection from outside your domain doesn't present any new challenges. The pre-v7.1 Windows QMgr that does not have MCAUSER set in the channel definition or by an exit allows remote administrative access, even from connections originating in the local Windows domain. There was em always /em a need to harden that QMgr, even though honest users will have received authorization errors if the administrator did not set up auths for them.
p strong Summary: /strong br For clients originating outside your administrative domain, I'd recommend mutually authenticated TLS/SSL channels. The same page I linked to above also contains the WMQ Security Lab guide and scripts which show how to script the creation and exchange of WMQ certs and configure WMQ Explorer with them.
p Whatever else you do, the code MCAUSER /code on any legitimate channel must be set either in the configuration or by an exit. If the client is allowed to specify the ID, there is nothing to prevent it from specifying an administrative ID. For channels that are NOT being used such as code SYSTEM.DEF.* /code and code SYSTEM.AUTO.* /code , set the MCAUSER to a value that cannot be a local ID such as code no!body /code or on v7.1 and later code *NOACCESS /code .

p You can get a third-party library, or you can use the connection pooling your Java EE container (for example, JBoss or WebSphere) provides for you.
p To do this, you configure and use a JNDI datasource.
p Here are details for Tomcat:
ul li p a href="http:/ eople.apache.org/~fhanik/jdbc-pool/jdbc-pool.html" rel="nofollow" http:/ eople.apache.org/~fhanik/jdbc-pool/jdbc-pool.html /a /li li p a href="http://www.tomcatexpert.com/blog/2012/01/24/using-tomcat-7-jdbc-connection-pool-production" rel="nofollow" http://www.tomcatexpert.com/blog/2012/01/24/using-tomcat-7-jdbc-connection-pool-production /a /li /ul

p Are you referring to this comment on the a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/333664/simple-long-polling-example-code" question /a ,
blockquote p running this on a regular web-server like Apache will quickly tie up all the "worker threads" and br leave it unable to respond to other requests /blockquote
p Recent versions of apache tomcat support a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/web/library/wa-cometjava/" rel="nofollow" comet /a which allows non blocking IO to allow tomcat to scale to a large number of requests. From this a href="http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-02-2009/jw-02-servlet3.html?page=2" rel="nofollow" article /a ,
blockquote p Thanks to the non-blocking I/O capability introduced in Java 4's New I/O APIs for the Java Platform (NIO) package, a persistent HTTP connection doesn't require that a thread be constantly attached to it. Threads can be allocated to connections only when requests are being processed. When a connection is idle between requests, the thread can be recycled, and the connection is placed in a centralized NIO select set to detect new requests without consuming a separate thread. This model, called thread per request, potentially allows Web servers to handle a growing number of user connections with a fixed number of threads. With the same hardware configuration, Web servers running in this mode scale much better than in the thread-per-connection mode. Today, popular Web servers -- including Tomcat, Jetty, GlassFish (Grizzly), WebLogic, and WebSphere -- all use thread per request through Java NIO. /blockquote

p WebSphere Commerce supports this out of the box, you can learn more about it on the a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wchelp/v7r0m0/topic/com.ibm.commerce.madisons-starterstore.doc/refs/rsmmadisonpcheckoutmultipleconfirm.htm?resultof=%22ship%22%20%22address%22%20" rel="nofollow" InfoCenter /a

p Try using code SELECT COUNT(1) FROM projects /code instead of code COUNT(*) /code . It has been known to improve some performance.
h3 EDIT /h3
p With regards to your edit, looks like you're not making use of Connection Pooling mechanism. If you don't use one, each call will try and open up a new connection which can be expensive. A Connection Pool, on the other hand, maintains a pool of connections, ready for use whenever needed. If you do a code connection.close() /code in your code, it will simply go to the pool for reuse rather than completely disconnected.
p You might want to check a a href="http://java-source.net/open-source/connection-pools" rel="nofollow" list /a of commonly used connection pools. I prefer DBCP or C3P0.
p Note: If you use an application server such as WebSphere / WebLogic / JBoss, you don't need to worry about this as it would've already been taken care of for you. All you've to do is to make your application use code DataSource /code s instead of direct code DriverManager.getConnection() /code and configure the connections on your application server.

pre code javax.naming.ConfigurationException: A JNDI operation on a "java:" name cannot be completed because the server runtime is not able to associate the operation's thread with any J2EE application component. This condition can occur when the JNDI client using the "java:" name is not executed on the thread of a server application request. Make sure that a J2EE application does not execute JNDI operations on "java:" names within static code blocks or in threads created by that J2EE application. Such code does not necessarily run on the thread of a server application request and therefore is not supported by JNDI operations on "java:" names. p By default Sles Linux does not expose a port outside the box.
p So by setting the debug port in WS to 7777 via the webpage(IBM/console) only exposes the port internally to the box. To expose it you need to enter â€œ0.0.0.0:7777â€�, but the web page does not allow this as a value.
p So to change it by hand go to this file on the box...
p /opt/IBM/WebSphere/AppServer rofiles/WRSProfile/config/cells/WRSNodeCell/nodes/WRSNode/servers/server1/server.xml
p Then replace 7777 with 0.0.0.0:7777 in the file. (there are 3 places to change this in the file)
pre code services xmi:type="debugservice:DebugService" xmi:id="DebugService_1331818723840" enable="true" jvmDebugPort="0.0.0.0:7777" jvmDebugArgs="-agentlib:jdwp=transport=dt_socket, server=y,suspend=n, address=0.0.0.0:7777" BSFDebugPort="4444" BSFLoggingLevel="0" ... jvmEntries xmi:id="JavaVirtualMachine_1183122130078" verboseModeClass="false" verboseModeGarbageCollection="false" verboseModeJNI="false" maximumHeapSize="1024" runHProf="false" hprofArguments="" debugMode="true" debugArgs="-agentlib:jdwp=transport=dt_socket, server=y,suspend=n, address=0.0.0.0:7777" genericJvmArguments="" /code re
p Then stop and start the server.
pre code /opt/IBM/WebSphere/AppServer/bin # ./stopServer.sh server1 /code re
p ..
pre code /opt/IBM/WebSphere/AppServer/bin # ./startServer.sh server1 /code re
p You can now connect a debugger to the machine!

p When the console gets the list of servers to display, it does make mbean calls to all of the servers, and if there is a network problem between the dmgr and the node, this could cause some delay in displaying the server page. The nodes page, however, should not have that issue. What is your topology? How many nodes/servers and how many are local/remote?
p How can you tell the problem is more serious on the remote nodes than the local nodes? br Are other console operations slower, or only ones that display status? Do you have the same problem with wsadmin commands? The console issues a queryNames to search for the server mbeans. Does the following wsadmin command run much more slowly on the remote node than the local node? If so, how much more slowly?
pre code print AdminControl.queryNames('WebSphere:type=Server,node=myNode') /code re
p Replace myNode with either the local or remote node name.

p * em I just got my wrist slapped for not having a question that goes quite along with the spirit of stackoverflow. On the suggestion of an SO mod, I've posted this question again over at programmers stack exchange. Here it is: * /em
p a href="http:/ rogrammers.stackexchange.com/questions/145999/what-is-the-alternative-to-an-enterprise-portal-strategy-in-the-java-space" Same Question Reposted over at Programmers.StackExchange /a
p I'm trying to garner insight from as many sources as I can, and I wanted to hear from the big brains at Stackoverflow.
p strong Disillusionment in the Portal Space /strong
p I'm seeing a disturbing number of large, enterprise clients who have become disillusioned with their enterprise Portal experience, especially those in the WebSphere Portal Server (WPS) space. Millions have been invested, yet the promise of personalized content with aggregation and integrated collaborative tools has never come to fruition. The move to WPS 7.x is a big rip and replace move, and clients are wondering if they should move somewhere else completely.
p strong Portal Software: A horrible option that is better than all the alternatives /strong
p There are loads of Portal haters out there, and sometimes a portal solution is indeed overkill, but when you're talking about large, multi-national corporations, how would one recommend they architect a global solution without a portal server? Portals aren't always as fun to work with as Tomcat or JBoss AS, but when it comes to integrating multiple applications, managing content, updating individual applications that are deployed as individual war files, managing security down to the portlet level, proving a certain amount of personalization to users, and help with the overwhelming task of managing the thousands of pages large scale enterprises have as part of their internal and external websites, is there a better technology out there?
p strong Garnering community insight and feedback /strong
p I've been trying to garner as much insight as possible. I wrote a little article on TSS about the issue:
p a href="http://www.theserverside.com/news/thread.tss?thread_id=64293" rel="nofollow" Which other alternatives to portal exists on market? /a
p a href="http://www.theserverside.com/tip/Every-enterprise-needs-an-employee-portal-Or-do-they" rel="nofollow" Every enterprise needs an employee portal. Or do they? /a
p I'm also resurrecting a thread at the CodeRanch to see if I can get any insight from that handsome crew.
p a href="http://www.coderanch.com/t/578949 ortals-Portlets/java/alternative-Enterprise-Java-Portal-Any" rel="nofollow" Updated Thread Asking for an Alternative to a Portal Software Stragety. Circa 2012 /a
p a href="http://www.coderanch.com/t/449227 ortals-Portlets/java/Which-other-alternatives-portal-exists" rel="nofollow" Insight required: A viable alternative to enterprise Portal software? Circa 2009 /a
p I'm also looking for some insight from the twitterati (@potemcam).
p It's not so much a cross-posting as much as it is an attempt to really gather some keen insight from the community. If I can get some solid responses and experiences, I'd like to aggregate them into an advice article over at TSS. So, any insight or experiences would be more than helpful.
p strong Insights and Experiences Welcomed /strong
p Looking forward to hearing your insights. By the way, I'll be cross-linking to this thread from the other sights as well so people with the same questions will be able to bounce back and forth and see what the community is saying on this topic.
What is the alternative to an enterprise portal strategy in the Java space?
java websphere liferay portal wps

p as for me I get application status in websphere 6.1 this way:
pre code #-------------------------------------------------------------- # get app object name #--------------------------------------------------------------
appObjectNames = AdminControl.queryNames('type=Application,cell=' + cellName + ',node=' + nodeName + ',process=' + serverName + ',name=' + appName + ',*')
lineSeparator = java.lang.System.getProperty('line.separator') appObjectName = appObjectNames.split(lineSeparator)[0] appObjectName = appObjectName.strip()
#-------------------------------------------------------------- # get application status #--------------------------------------------------------------
if len(appObjectName) == 0: tprint(prefix + 'application ' + appName + ' is stopped') else: tprint(prefix + 'application ' + appName + ' is started') /code re
p I guess this should work in WebSphere 7.0 as well.

p There are many Java EE servers available today. But the popular and commonly used Java EE servers are as follows:
ol li JBoss AS /li li IBM WebSphere /li li Glassfish /li li BEA Weblogic /li li JOnAS /li li Resin /li li Apache TomEE /li li Apache Geronimo /li /ol
p Those are internal WebSphere variables. They have nothing to do with log4j.

p As mentioned by dbreaux, WebSphere variables are not available as a System Property. The standard trick is to create a custom property for the JVM say WAS_SERVER_NAME which is assigned the value ${WAS_SERVER_NAME}.
p WAS run time would assign the value to the JVM property and then it would be available to log4j.
p HTH
p Manglu

p WebSphere MQ WCF custom channel has a feature "Assured Delivery" that guarantees that a service request or reply is actioned and not lost. This is the 1-phase commit (also known as SYNC_POINT in) WMQ.
p "Assuered Delivery" is a service contract attribute. a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r0/topic/com.ibm.mq.csqzav.doc/un12400_.htm" rel="nofollow" Here /a are more details about the feature.

pre code import java.util.Properties as Properties import javax.management.ObjectName as ObjectName import com.ibm.websphere.management.AdminClient as AdminClient import com.ibm.websphere.management.AdminClientFactory as AdminClientFactory
class DeploymentManager: def __init__(self, host, soapport, user, password): self.host = host self.soapport = soapport self.user = user self.password = password
def create_admin_client(dmgrhost, dmgrsoapport, user, password): props = Properties() props.setProperty(AdminClient.CONNECTOR_TYPE, AdminClient.CONNECTOR_TYPE_SOAP) props.setProperty(AdminClient.CONNECTOR_HOST, dmgrhost) props.setProperty(AdminClient.CONNECTOR_PORT, dmgrsoapport) props.setProperty(AdminClient.CONNECTOR_SECURITY_ENABLED, "true"); props.setProperty(AdminClient.USERNAME, user); props.setProperty(AdminClient.PASSWORD, password); props.setProperty("javax.net.ssl.trustStore", "/opt/IBM rofiles/dmgr01/etc/DummyClientTrustFile.jks"); props.setProperty("javax.net.ssl.keyStore", "/opt/IBM rofiles/dmgr01/etc/DummyClientKeyFile.jks");
adminClient = AdminClientFactory.createAdminClient(props)
return adminClient
def get_servers(): servers = [s for s in adminClient.queryNames(queryName, None).toArray()]
return servers
def get_server_states(servers): serverstates = {} for server in servers: name = adminClient.getAttribute(server, "name") pid = adminClient.getAttribute(server, "pid") state = adminClient.getAttribute(server, "state") serverstates[name] = {'name' : name, 'state' : state, 'pid' : pid}
return serverstates
DMGRs = [] DMGRs.append(DeploymentManager('dmgr1_host', 'dmgr1_soap_port', 'dmgr1_user', 'dmgr1_pw')) DMGRs.append(DeploymentManager('dmgr2_host', 'dmgr2_soap_port', 'dmgr2_user', 'dmgr2_pw')) DMGRs.append(DeploymentManager('dmgr3_host', 'dmgr3_soap_port', 'dmgr3_user', 'dmgr3_pw'))
for DMGR in DMGRs: adminClient = create_admin_client(DMGR.host, DMGR.soapport, DMGR.user, DMGR.password) queryName = ObjectName("WebSphere:*,node=*,type=Server,name=srv*")
servers = get_servers() serverstates = get_server_states(servers)
print '## %s ##' % DMGR.host keys = serverstates.keys() keys.sort() for key in keys: print '%s %s: %s' % (serverstates[key]['name'], serverstates[key]['pid'], serverstates[key]['state'])

p These files are part of a feature known as Enhanced EARs. See the a href="http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/abstracts/redp4582.html" rel="nofollow" WebSphere Application Server V7: Packaging Applications for Deployment /a redbook for more information. In short, application-specific configuration can be included in the application to minimize the per-server configuration that an administrator must perform when installing an application.

p Simply put, Enterprise Service Bus is more of an architectural concept. The idea is to realise integrations in terms of business services. An ESB can actually be implemented as a set of policies and guidelines where applications agree upon a given set of formats and a given communication protocol (SOAP/WS, Messaging, etc), a way to describe services etc.
p ESB servers (Service Mix, IBM WebSphere Message Broker, JBoss ESB, Mule ESB, MS BizTalk Server, you name it) essentially provides a toolbox for realising this. The number of servers, the topology, what protocols/data formats to use etc. often needs to be decided for each situation and enterprise environment. An application environment built up of batch controlled legacy/main frame systems needs a very different integration setup then for instance an event driven Java EE or .NET stack of applications.

p I am intressted in methods to do (non intrusive) performance profiling in a Spring application deployed in a Java EE server. In my case I use WebSphere Application Server 7, WebSphere MQ 7 and OpenJPA/IBM DB2.
p I only need a brief overview of potential bottlenecks etc. I could always log time stamps and do some analysis, but if you guys have any best practice, I am listening!
Good profiling methods for spring applications on Java EE server
spring java-ee profiling websphere
p WebSphere platform messaging (also called SIBus) is typically used via the JMS API.

p I see the point. This might be a bit tricky with "pure" JMS.
p What you essentially want to do is to let the portal publish messages to a topic, but not let the PAYROLLAPPs subscribe to that topic (since all of them would get a copy of the message). So what you would need is some logic in between that distributes the message from the topic subscription to one queue per application type. From that queue, normal load balanced (the competing consumer pattern) can be implemented with JMS.
p Different JMS providers have special implementations that can acomplish this task a href="http://activemq.apache.org/virtual-destinations.html" rel="nofollow" ActiveMQ has its Virtual Destinations /a , a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r0/topic/com.ibm.mq.amqnar.doc s10120_.htm" rel="nofollow" WebSphere MQ has its server side subscriptions that can subscribe from a topic to a queue /a . In the case your JMS provider does not have any way to handle this, you might want to look at adding some routing middleware to your topology. Apache Camel is a nice, lightweight one, but there are lots of others that can setup some routing in the middle without affecting the real applications.
blockquote blockquote p Update for detailed questions /blockquote /blockquote
ol li p The Queues below the line has to be there for sure (if your applications uses messaging). The "Some distrib. logic" box shouldn't be needed. The "Some routing logic" box could be an ESB or in this very case, be implemented in the messaging server, for instance ActiveMQ with virtual destinations (or WebSphere MQ or perhaps RabbitMQ among others). /li li p There are a lot of buzwords in the domain of integration. Simplified (depending on who you ask - ESB can also be seen as an architectural pattern, but let's keep it simple), an ESB is a server application (or a topology of multiple servers in practice) that is a centerpiece of an integration landscape. The ESB server simply contain logic and small message flows that takes messages (files, or whatever) from one application and routes them to many applications, transform them to other formats, encrypts, converts from one transport protocol such as HTTP/SOAP to File etc. /li /ol
p JMS is a rather confusing and missused word. Java has to some extent dominated the enterprise messaging domain in the last years, so JMS is sometimes used pretty much as a synonym to Messaging. However, Messaging, (or message queueing, asynchronous messaging, MOM=message oriented middleware, etc.) is to be simply considered as a family of similar transport protocols that features a central relaying server. Is is not at all a Java only thing. Many successful ESBs setups I worked with actually leverage on a Messaging backbone
ol li p In your situation, I would not go too deep into the academical hilosophical differences between ESB and EAI software. They will most likely do pretty much the same things for you. Instead, look at the hard facts such as price, support, resource footprint, monitoring, tech. features, learning curve etc. Be it Camel/ServiceMix, Mule, JBoss ESB, Microsoft BizTalk, IBM Message Broker, Tibco etc. /li li p Hah! Was it perhaps a salesman? An ESB will do just fine. A Messaging server will do in your case as well, such as ActiveMQ as has been pointed out already. BPM suits are fine for orchestrating semi-automatized business processes or if there is major business logic in the integration layer. Otherwise, avoid that added complexity. /li /ol

p Prior to EE 6 (available in WebSphere Application Server 8.0), there is no way to share code resource-ref /code across EJBs. You must redeclare the code resource-ref /code in each EJB.
p In EE 6, you can declare the resource-ref with a name such as code java:module/env/jdbc/employee /code , and it will be visible to all EJBs in the module (and code java:app /code is visible to all modules, and code java:global /code is visible to all apps).

p There is no such standard feature. One technique is to use a thread-local, but you need to carefully ensure you call .remove() to avoid causing problems with your container's thread pool.
