p WebSphere MQ does not perform any authentication. Local applications are authenticated by the operating system and so their ID can be trusted. (By definition, if you cannot trust the local OS authentication then the entire server is compromised.) Just as with local connections, WMQ trusts that the ID connecting remotely is genuine. It is up to the WMQ administrator to determine what level of authentication to employ. In WMQ v7 there are two choices - authenticate with SSL/TLS channels, or use a channel exit to authenticate.
p In either case, it is the channel's MCAUSER value that decides what ID is used for authorization. If the MCAUSER is left blank then the channel will use the user ID that the client sends. In your case you received a 2035 error because the client sent an ID that was not in the administrative (mqm) group. Had your client sent the ID 'mqm' (or on Windows 'MUSR_MQADMIN'), the connection would have succeeded. If your program is Java or JMS, the ability to select the ID presented is part of the API. Just tell the QMgr who you want to be.
p If you are willing to allow remote connections to execute OS commands on the server, then just put the administrative ID in the channel's MCAUSER. (For example, MCAUSER('mqm') on UNIX/Linux or typically MCAUSER('MUSR_MQADMIN') for Windows.) However, be aware that remote users with admin rights can remotely execute arbitrary OS command-line code using the QMgr. This is a feature of WMQ and not a bug, hence we NEVER recommend this in Production. In fact, I personally recommend that development environments enable security. Waiting until Production to figure out how to authenticate connections and what authorizations are needed often leads to unnecessary deployment delays.
p If you want to use IP filtering to mitigate that threat, you can either move to WMQ v7.1 which includes this feature natively, or use an exit such as a href="http://mrmq.dk" rel="nofollow" BlockIP2 /a . Either of these solutions will allow you to create rules that filter incoming connection requests by IP address, user ID, etc.
p Note that on a v7.0 QMgr all the channels are unprotected by default. So even if you filter incoming requests on one channel, if the others are left in their default state, anyone can still connect and execute commands as the administrator. For a comprehensive review of all this, please take a look at the Hardening WebSphere MQ presentation at a href="http://t-rob.net/links" rel="nofollow" t-rob.net /a . Scroll down to the v7.0 presentations.

p The default operation of MQ is that when a message is sent (MQPUT or in JMS terms producer.send), the application does not get a response back on the MQPUT call until the message has reached a queue on a queue manager. i.e. MQPUT is a synchronous call, and if you get a completion code of OK, that means that the queue manager to which the client application is connected has received the message successfully. It may not yet have reached its ultimate destination, but it has reached the protection of an MQ Server, and therefore you can rely on MQ to look after the message and forward it on to where it needs to get to.
p Whether client connected, or locally bound to the queue manager, applications sending messages are responsible for their data until an MQPUT call returns successfully. Similarly, receiving applications are responsible for their data once they get it from a successful MQGET (or JMS consumer.receive) call.
p There are multiple levels of message protection are available. If you are using non-persistent messages and asynchronous PUTs, then you are effectively saying it doesn't matter too much whether the messages reach their destination (although they generally will). If you want MQ to really look after your messages, use synchronous PUTs as described above, persistent messages, and perform your PUTs and GETs within transactions (aka syncpoint) so you have full application control over the commit points.
p If you have very unreliable networks such that you expect to regularly fail to get the messages to a server, and expect to need regular retries such that you need client-side message protection, one option you could investigate is MQ Telemetry (e.g. in WebSphere MQ V7.1) which is designed for low bandwidth and/or unreliable network communications, as a route into the wider MQ.

p First of all, if it is unspecified, this means that it is left as a container's implementation detail. br So you should look into code WebSphere /code specifically. br I think the same would happen in code Tomcat /code as well, since the security constraints (if I recall correctly) are implemented via code Valves /code and so would precede the application code in the request chain. br From my point of view it makes sense, since if you assign the protection to your container, then if the request reaches your filter then it should have already passed your container's authentication mechanism (my point of view is that the filter is part of your resources). br In Tomcat you would solve your problem by replacing the code Filter /code with a code Valve /code

p Middleware messaging was born of the need to persist data locally to mitigate the effects of failures of the remote node or of the network. The idea at the time was that the queue manager was installed locally on the box where the application lives and was treated as part of the transport stack. For instance you might install TCP and WMQ as a transport and some apps would use TCP while others used WMQ.
p In the intervening 20 years, the original problems that led to the creation of MQSeries (Now WebSphere MQ) have largely been solved. The networks have improved by several nines of availability and high availability hardware and software clustering have provided options to keep the different components available 24x7.
p So the practices in widespread use today to address your question follow two basic approaches. Either make the components highly available so that the client can always find a messaging server, or put a QMgr where the application lives in order to provide local queueing.

p a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VoiceXML" rel="nofollow" VoiceXML (VXML) /a is the W3C's standard XML format for specifying interactive voice dialogues between a human and a computer. It allows voice applications to be developed and deployed in an analogous way to HTML for visual applications. Just as HTML documents are interpreted by a visual web browser, VoiceXML documents are interpreted by a voice browser.
p Typically, HTTP is used as the transport protocol for fetching VoiceXML pages. Some applications may use static VoiceXML pages, while others rely on dynamic VoiceXML page generation using an application server like Tomcat, Weblogic, IIS, or WebSphere. br Historically, VoiceXML platform vendors have implemented the standard in different ways, and added proprietary features. But the VoiceXML 2.0 standard, adopted as a W3C Recommendation on 16 March 2004, clarified most areas of difference. The VoiceXML Forum, an industry group promoting the use of the standard, provides a conformance testing process that certifies vendors' implementations as conformant.

p Ok. There are two parts to your question (and I'm sticking to the base application server here):
p a) writing applications: WebSphere Application Server is a J2EE application server. So any web resource or forum or blog describing how to write servlets or JSPs or applications that use EJBs will work. There are lots of those. If you want to stick with IBM resources, you could look for redbooks or developerworks articles. For more general information (patterns, practices, etc) you could try a href="http://theserverside.com" rel="nofollow" http://theserverside.com /a .

p There is also a a href="http://www.youtube.com/user/WebSphereEducation" rel="nofollow" WebSphere education channel on youtube /a which addresses both questions.

p All versions of WebSphere MQ Client can talk to all versions of WebSphere MQ queue manager. If you use the latest version you benefit from the latest fixes and performance enhancements but in terms of function you are limited by the back-level QMgr. You don't em lose /em any function that you would get by using the same version client as QMgr, you just cant wring v7.1 function out of a v7.0 QMgr by using the v7.1 client.
p As a rule, use the latest client.
p That said, here are your download links:
p a href="http://ibm.co/SupptPacMQC71" rel="nofollow" WMQ Client v7.1 /a br a href="http://ibm.co/SupptPacMQC7" rel="nofollow" WMQ Client v7.0 /a
p The only wrinkle is the client-side differences. For configuring the client, use the Infocenter that matches the client version. To see which functionality to expect from the QMgr, use the Infocenter that matches the QMgr.
p a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r1/index.jsp" rel="nofollow" WMQ V7.1 Infocenter /a br a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r0/index.jsp" rel="nofollow" WMQ V7.0 Infocenter /a

p In addition to solution provided by Vadim, I would like to share two links that describe a couple of alternative workarounds, and explanation of the mechanisms causing this seemingly counter intuitive mode of operation.
p If you're using SSO (single sign on) between different applications, there may be a little drawback of using com.ibm.ws.security.web.logoutOnHTTPSessionExpire=true setting. This setting essentially invalidates LTPA token. Since security cache at server refreshes from LTPA token when it times out, invalidated LTPA will cause revalidation (login) of user for remaining applications [1].
p Answer to Question 9 (which seems to be same as our question) at [2] provides ideas for two alternative workarounds for this problem, where you may time out authentication using servlet filters based on lifetime and inactivity.
p [1]: a href="https://www-304.ibm.com/support/entdocview.wss?rs=180 ;amp;context=SSEQTP ;amp;uid=swg21078845" rel="nofollow" Security Cache, LTPA Token, and Session Time Outs /a (requires login)
p [2]: a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/techjournal/1003_botzum/1003_botzum.html#sec2c" rel="nofollow" Q ;amp; A: Frequently asked questions about WebSphere Application Server security /a

p WebSphere supports a number of registries and these days a federated repository is the norm in WAS.
p The federated repository can be made up of file based (a file in the File System where user assword, groups etc are stored, LDAP Server, databases etc.
p At the end of the day, user information is stored in some registry. JBoss/tomcat keeps them in different files (like the names that you mentioned) and also supports LDAP and possibly other user registries. Similiarly WAS supports multiple such user registries.
p You pick and choose what is the best one for your environment.
p Have a read at this to get a good understanding this space
p a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/techjournal/0701_ilechko/0701_ilechko.html" rel="nofollow" http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/techjournal/0701_ilechko/0701_ilechko.html /a
p In short, if you want to store your users, the simplest and easiest choice would be strong fileRegistry.xml /strong

p br Correct, by default JRules comes with Studio and RES. br
p RES is a WAR file you need to deploy on a WAS. I think that by default it is only provided with the messy WebSphere but you can download some "bundles" for JBoss, WebLogic, ... and more. br Program / Ilog Jrules / documentation / How to install RES - RTFM br br One could use WebSphereCE but this is just crappy. br It is provided by default and you can use that straight away but you don't want to use it in live or even for POCs. br We call this pseudo WAS "Bernardo" like in Zorro because it is silent :)
p BTW: you don't need RES to execute a rule. Specially with JUnit, you can export the ruleapp or ruleset (I don't remember) and use POJO straight away. br Create a new project in Studio called: "new java project for rules" ish and the wizard will create all you need to execute your rules locally. br You will just need to code the InputParameters and retrieve the OutputParameters in order to assert. br EZ PZ lemon squizzy :)
p From there you can load the ruleapp in your "before" JUnit method, makes sense? br Rather that connect the RES itself. br br To sum up, if I were you: br 1/ I would create the example project I mentioned. So I have the code example. br 2/ I create my own ruleapp (right click on the rule project / export / ruleapp) and store it somewhere. br 3/ prepare my JUnit classes - Assertion + "Before" methods br 4/ run it locally without RES br 5/ I'm happy as Larry br 6/ Now I deal with RES and configure it br br Hope it helps

p Quoting a href="http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21254153" rel="nofollow" http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21254153 /a , official description is;
blockquote p Environment entries can be used to specify variables not specific to WebSphere Application Server, but are defined by other elements, such as UNIXÂ®, Language EnvironmentÂ® (LE), or third-party vendors, among others. These variables tend to be operating system-specific. /blockquote
p So they are OS specific (i.e PATH for Windows, LIBPATH for AIX, LD_LIBRARY_PATH for Solaris).
p For an example case where usage is necessary; quoting a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/dmndhelp/v7r0mx/topic/com.ibm.wbit.help.runtime.doc/deploy/topics/rcfglibadapters.html" rel="nofollow" http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/dmndhelp/v7r0mx/topic/com.ibm.wbit.help.runtime.doc/deploy/topics/rcfglibadapters.html /a
blockquote p If a native library is dependent on other native libraries, the dependent libraries must be configured on the LIBPATH of the JVM hosting the application server (rather than on the native path shown in the above figure) in order for that library to load successfully. You should configure an environment entry by selecting Servers Application Servers server_name Java and Process Management Process Definition Environment Entries (where server_name is the name of the server; for example, server1). On the Environment Entries page, create a new environment entry to specify the LIBPATH of the JVM. /blockquote
p You can access these variables by using System.getenv() (not System.getProperties(), which returns custom properties and generic JVM arguments).

p MQTT protocol is suited for small devices like sensors, mobile phones etc that have small memory footprint. These devices are typically located in a brittle network and typically have low computing power.
p These devices connect to an organizations back-end network via MQTT protocol for sending and receiving messages. For example a temperature sensor in an oil pipeline would collect temperature of the oil flowing through the pipe and send it to the control center. In response a command message could be sent over MQTT to another device to reduce/stop the flow of oil through that pipe.
p WebSphere MQ has the capability to send/receive messages to/from the MQTT devices. So if you plan to implement a messaging based solution that involves devices ;amp; sensors, you can consider MQ and MQTT.
p HTH

p I came upon a task of writing a script which first initiates a silent installation of Websphere MQ client 32 bit on a windows server. Then check if the installation was successful or not..... So I wrote the following script:
pre class="lang-sh prettyprint-override" code @echo off REM Author : Akshay Sinha REM Date Created : 07/05/2012 REM Installing Websphere MQ....... Msiexec /q /i "%CD%\MSI\IBM WebSphere MQ.msi" /l*v .\install.log /m mif_file TRANSFORMS="1033.mst" AGREETOLICENSE="yes" echo Script to check if the installation failed !!! echo Waiting for installaion to complete....... REM Script will wait for 2 mins, This is to ensure that install.log gets fully generated. ping 123.45.67.89 -n 1 -w 120000 nul echo Wait Over find /C "Installation operation failed" "%CD%"\install.log tmp.log for /f "tokens=1,2,3 delims=:" %%a in (tmp.log) DO ( SET /a FOUND_STR=%%c echo %FOUND_STR% ) del tmp.log SET %FOUND_STR%=%FOUND_STR: =% echo %FOUND_STR% if %FOUND_STR% EQU 0 ( echo Installation Of MQ completed without any errors!!!!! EXIT /B 0 ) if %FOUND_STR% GTR 0 ( echo There were errors while installing MQ.. Pls Verify!!! EXIT /B 1 ) /code re
p the script is working fine for a fresh installation. ie if the mentioned software was not installed on the system already.
p However, I need to enhance this script such that, it should check the system for existing installations of Websphere MQ and its version. --if the version is not the one which we require(which of course , i will provide from command line) , it should initiate a uninstallation.
p The problem is I don't want to use the approach of searching the file system. So how do I accomplish this task using WMI classes.?? I looked up Win32_Product class, but it only returned me one installed program(Although, I have arnd 40 applications installed on my system).So I want to know: 1)what is the concrete method of searching for a particular program on a system.(I am open to VbScripting or batch programming) 2)Does the value of registry key for a installed software remains same across all systems and does it differ with different virsions??
p Thanks in advance.

p Thanks PA for that TIP.. however I came up with a solution using VBScript. I am calling this script from my original batch file. Actually I wrote a vb script which enumerates the different registry keys available at :
pre code SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall\ /code re
p and search for "IBM WebSphere MQ" as the "DisplayName". When found , it will then list its version number and "Product code". Please note that we can use "Product code" for installation purpose from commandline... Following is the script I wrote. I am posting it here for everyone's use. Please feel free to use it..........
pre code '------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 'Script Name : listMQ.vbs 'Author : Akshay Sinha 'Created : 05/10/12 'Description : This Script attempts to check if the correct version of Websphere MQ is already installed on the system. ' : If found the Script will exit with a ERRORLEVEL of 0. ' : If found but not of correct version... Script will exit with a ' ERRORLEVEL of 1..Which in turn will initiate a Uninstalation ' : If not found, Script will exit with a ERRORLEVEL of 2 and initiate a ' a fresh installation. ' : Syntax: at command prompt - ' : C: Cscript listMQ.vbs ' : Check the value of %ERRORLEVEL% after execution. ' : C: echo %ERRORLEVEL%. Should give 0,1 or 2 '------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Const HKLM = ;amp;H80000002 'HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE
strComputer = "." strKey = "SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall\" strEntry1a = "DisplayName" strEntry1b = "QuietDisplayName" strEntry1c = "DisplayVersion" strEntry1d = "UninstallString"
Set objReg = GetObject("winmgmts://" ;amp; strComputer ;amp; "/root/default:StdRegProv") objReg.EnumKey HKLM, strKey, arrSubkeys WScript.Echo "Installed Applications" ;amp; VbCrLf intVersionNum="1.0.0.0" For Each strSubkey In arrSubkeys intRet1 = objReg.GetStringValue(HKLM, strKey ;amp; strSubkey, strEntry1a, strValue1) if intRet1 "" Then objReg.GetExpandedStringValue HKLM, strKey ;amp; strSubkey, strEntry1a, strValue1 intCompare=StrComp("IBM WebSphere MQ",strValue1,vbTextCompare) IF intCompare = 0 THEN objReg.GetExpandedStringValue HKLM, strKey ;amp; strSubkey, strEntry1c, intVersionNum strUninstall=strSubkey WScript.Echo "Congratulations!! Websphere MQ is already installed on this system" WScript.Echo strEntry1a ;amp; " : " ;amp; strValue1 WScript.Echo strEntry1c ;amp; " : " ;amp; intVersionNum END IF End If Next
IF intVersionNum="1.0.0.0" THEN WScript.Echo "Sorry Websphere MQ was not found on this system" WScript.Quit 2 END IF
intVersionCompare=StrComp("7.0.1.5",intVersionNum,vbTextCompare) IF intVersionCompare = 0 THEN WScript.Echo "Congratulations!! Correct version of Websphere MQ is installed" WScript.Echo "Uninstall String for this product is : " ;amp; strUninstall WScript.Quit 0 ELSE WScript.Echo "Wrong Version of MQ installed" WScript.Echo "Initiating Unistallation....." WScript.Quit 1 END IF /code re
p This is a pretty self explanatory script..Please let me know if you run into any issues.

For the JMS listener, Camel (or the underlying spring framework perhaps) initiates own threads (seems to be simple java threads more or less) to deal with JMS requests.
p I also have a transactional Database attached to the application. So, in spring, I have something like this definied to grab a transaction manager (WebSphere built in JTA probably).
pre code tx:annotation-driven /code re
p So my problem is, that I get an error like this when a Camel/JMS is triggering an event in the application:
pre code org.apache.openjpa.persistence.PersistenceException: TransactionManager not found in JNDI under name java:comp/websphere/ExtendedJTATransaction /code re

WebSphere JNDI lookup in non managed threads

p If the properties files are at the root of the EJB, then the EJB class should be able to find the properties files. If you're running with Java 2 security enabled, then you'll need to grant FilePermission; see PROFILE_HOME/config/cells/CELL/nodes/NODE/app.policy for ${webComponent} and ${ejbComponent}.
p Simply placing the properties files in EAR/lib won't work because the EAR/lib/ directory is not on the classpath, only the .jar files within it are on the classpath. It might work to add code Class-Path: lib/ /code to the EJB jar MANIFEST.MF, but directory class paths are not required by the JavaEE spec, so I do not know if they are supported by WebSphere Application Server.
p Referencing the properties files directly in the MANIFEST.MF Class-Path also doesn't work because only JARs and directories are supported (see above for JavaEE caveat regarding directories).
p In general, it's probably best to remove the leading slash from code /lib /code . It's unclear from the JavaEE platform specification whether this should refer to the code lib /code directory in the EAR or to a directory in the root of the machine file system.

p The classes you mention are generated by WSAD (WebSphere Application Developer, which is ancestor of RAD) during 'generate deployment and rmic code' phase of build process. You can also tell this from the class names, which probably have funny prefixes and suffixes attached original bean name and reside in the same package. So, developer did not write these classes himself, they are generated for WebSphere, and they shall be omitted (cleaned up from project) before migrating to an application server from another vendor. On how to get rid of these classes you may find instructions at tech note below.
p a href="http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21244438" rel="nofollow" EJBDeploy generation and deletion of stubs, ties and generated deploy code /a
p I would say that you have a pair of problems here, because most probably Enterprise Java spec that was used is not currently supported by new servers (it is probably 1.2 as it is very old). So you must first perform a specification level migration, then application server migration.
p For specification level migration (i.e. Java EE 1.2 to 1.4 at least) I would say your best bet would be to use RAD (Rational Application Developer), which can perform specification migration by using simple wizards. You may find information about how to perform this migration at article below.
p a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/radhelp/v7r0m0/topic/com.ibm.etools.rad.migration.doc/topics/tmgv6j2eewiz.html" rel="nofollow" Migrating the specification level of J2EE projects /a
p Once you upgrade spec level it will be easier to migrate your project to another server because as the spec level increases, effort for server to server migration decreases. At this point what you shall do basically is prepare application server specific deployment descriptors for your target server (Glassfish), for which you shall check glassfish website. A good entry point would be Glassfish migration wiki, and Glassfish verification tool (I can't put links to these because I don't enough reputation to post more than two link at the moment :)

p HTTPOnly cookies became an option in WebSphere 6.1 at fixpack 31, so you have to be at least at that fix level. Their configuration is documented a href="http:/ ic.dhe.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v6r1/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.websphere.nd.doc/info/ae/ae/rweb_custom_props.html" rel="nofollow" on this page of the InfoCenter /a .
p The Secure flag is configured under the console's code Session Management /code , code Enable cookies /code page, and can be specified at the Application Server level or overridden in the Enterprise Application's code Web Module Properties /code . Note that if you do the latter, you must select the checkbox to "Override session management". In either case, you'll check the checkbox to "Restrict cookies to HTTPS sessions".

p Could be related to the following bug in WebSphere: a href="http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?rs=180 ;amp;uid=swg1PM39817" rel="nofollow" http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?rs=180 ;amp;uid=swg1PM39817 /a

p I've inherited an incomplete but small web project (Java EE 5, running on WebSphere 7).
p The project consists mostly of JSPs that are accessed directly via their URL, and most JSPs look up their own reference to the EJBs (services) they need. Also, there's a Servlet for every form that gets submitted by the HTML code in the JSPs.
p Architecturally speaking, is there anything em wrong /em with this?
p I was thinking it would be better to have an MVC design. I don't want to convert everything to JSF because I don't want to convert all the HTML and embedded Java scriptlets into JSF tags and managed beans.
p I don't really want to use Struts or Spring MVC because they're not part of the Java EE 5 toolkit that comes out of the box with WebSphere, and I don't want to add additional complexity with the additional libs and config files.
p I was thinking about building my own little MVC with a "ControllerServlet" that accepts a command and dynamically build and execute the command object, and redirect to the JSP view.
p But I ask myself again, is there anything "wrong" with JSPs that post to Servlets? It's actually kind of elegant in its simplicity.
p What do you think?
p Any suggestions are GREATLY appreciated! Rob
what's the 'right' way to do a MVC for JSPs in Java EE 5?
mvc jsp jsf java-ee servlets

p Putting back a message to the queue after some error is called em backout /em in the Websphere MQ world.
p There are two alternatives how to handle it:
ol li p In the queue manager: You can configure em backout threshold /em and em backout requeue name /em properties for the given queue. After backout treshold is reached, queue manager will put the message to the queue specified by the backout requeue name instead of redelivering it. See a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wmqv7/v7r0/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.mq.explorer.doc/e_properties_queues.htm ;amp;resultof=%22BOQNAME%22%20%22boqnam%22" rel="nofollow" WebSphere MQ queue properties /a for more information. /li li p In your application: If you use JMS API, check the JMSXDeliveryCount property by calling a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/1.3/api/javax/jms/Message.html#getIntProperty%28java.lang.String%29" rel="nofollow" msessage.getIntProperty("JMSXDeliveryCount") /a before you start processing the message. If it reaches some treshold, handle the message as errorneous. /li /ol

p But the methods it's complaining about are really in the classes and I've redeployed it and restarted the server. So it seems that some changes are not updated. What is the correct way to handle this? I can compile and clean the project but there's this runtime exception when I try access the JSP page. I use RAD 8 and WAS 8 and that's where the stacktrace appears.
h2 Update /h2
p I did not solve this yet. The environment is IBM RAD 8 (=Eclipse) and WAS (websphere) 8 and my JSP doesn't recognize the newly added method to my Java class. I suspect there is some kind of caching going on that won't enable me to reload my classes. I've tried deleting the temporary files from the JSP and restarting the server and also I've cleaned the project but the error still appears. What should I do?
h2 Update 2 /h2
p I could remove one of the offending classes and instead get a noclassfounderror but that is not much better. The IBM RAD is not working for me, it would've been better to develop from the command prompt than an IDE that makes it impossible for you to do development.
How to reload my classes so that this stacktrace will disappear?
java jsp java-ee websphere rad

p Can I force a browser to cache the pages responded by WPS 6.1?
p Is force a browser to cache the pages a way to fulfill the requirement?
p I've try to create a filter and config it in the wps.
pre code filter filter-name Cache Filter /filter-name filter-class com.samaxes.filter.CacheFilter /filter-class init-param param-name expirationTime aram-name param-value 120 aram-value /init-param /filter filter-mapping filter-name Cache Filter /filter-name url-pattern ortal/* /url-pattern /filter-mapping /code re
p It is working, but the HTTP header is still:
p Cache-Control no-cache br/ Content-Language en-US br/ Content-Type text/html; charset=UTF-8 br/ Date Fri, 11 May 2012 07:50:19 GMT br/ Expires Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 GMT br/ IBM-Web2-Location ... br/ Pragma no-cache br/ Server WebSphere Application Server/6.1 Transfer-Encoding chunked br/ Vary User-Agent,Cookie br/ How to get the correct response header? br/ Cache-Control : max-age=120 br/ Expires : br/
p Thanks
How to force browser to cache the page in websphere portal
websphere browser-cache websphere-portal
Why isn't this simple JPA ManyToOne relationship working?
java-ee jpa

p We have a large web application, some of which uses a href="http://tiles.apache.org/" rel="nofollow" Apache Tiles /a which, in places, are heavily nested. On all web application containers tested (Tomcat, JBoss, JonAs and I think WebSphere) there have been no issues, however on a href="http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/middleware/weblogic/overview/index.html" rel="nofollow" WebLogic /a we have problems.
p On WebLogic our nested tiles don't get rendered properly; only dynamic server-side scripted content gets rendered, all static (i.e. plain HTML content) gets ignored. em Why is this? /em
p strong Environment details: /strong
ul li OS: Windows and Solaris (seems irrelevant) /li li Java version: 6 /li li WebLogic: 11gR1 /li li Apache Tiles: 2.2.2 /li /ul
p The issue may be caused by improper use of Tiles and how they should be nested, if so please let me know, but ideally, due to the extent of this, possibly improper use, we'd like to find a workaround.
p We did try changing the character encoding to avoid use of WebLogic's JSPWriter (from a quick inspection of source code, the choice of a href="http://docs.oracle.com/javaee/1.4/api/javax/servlet/jsp/JspWriter.html" rel="nofollow" JSPWriter /a depends on character encoding settings). Changing encoding to a combination of UTF-8 and UTF-16 (which was wrong and broke things in other containers) fixed the WebLogic issue because it no longer used WebLogic's JSPWriter (and all that came with it).
p strong Example WAR: /strong
p I have produced a very simple example that demonstrates this issue:
p em Most important file for explanation; code displayTable.jsp /code /em
pre code %@ page language="java" contentType="text/html; charset=UTF-8" pageEncoding="UTF-8"% %@ taglib prefix="tiles" uri="http://tiles.apache.org/tags-tiles" % div id="displayTable" class="displayTable" p %= "This gets printed" % !-- But this doesn't... -- table tbody tr td This doesn't /td td 1 /td /tr tr td get printed /td td 2 /td /tr tr td ...no it doesn't /td td 3 /td /tr /tbody /table /div /code re
p em The page that imports displayTable.jsp; code test.jsp /code : /em
pre code %@ page language="java" contentType="text/html; charset=UTF-8" pageEncoding="UTF-8"% %@ taglib uri="http://tiles.apache.org/tags-tiles" prefix="tiles" % tiles:insertDefinition name="pageTemplate" tiles:putAttribute name="pageContent" div p Test /div div tiles:insertDefinition name="displayTable" /div /tiles:putAttribute /tiles:insertDefinition /code re
p em The page template; code pageTemplate.jsp /code : /em
p If code test.jsp /code didn't wrap contents using this file, everything works...
pre code !DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd" %@ page language="java" contentType="text/html; charset=UTF-8" pageEncoding="UTF-8"% %@ taglib uri="http://tiles.apache.org/tags-tiles" prefix="tiles" % tiles:useAttribute name="pageContent" html head title Testing WebLogic and nested tiles /title /head body tiles:insertAttribute name="pageContent" /body /html /code re
p em The output source of the above: /em
pre code !DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd" html head title Testing WebLogic and nested tiles /title /head body div p Test /div div This gets printed? /div /body /html /code re
p I can provide the rest of the WAR contents if required, please ask.

p WebSphere Application Server doesn't have builtin support for pooling arbitrary connections. It does support JCA and its connection pooling, so probably the closest you'll get is to write your own resource adapter that opens connections. That's no exactly trivial, and unfortunately, I'm not aware of any libraries that already do this.

p In WebSphere Application Server (like almost all application servers), there is a hierarchy of class loaders:
pre code Application server class loaders | Includes WAS_HOME lugins, WAS_HOME/lib, etc. | +-- Application class loader | Includes files in lib/ folder of the .ear | Includes all JARs referenced from Class-Path in all .war | +-- StrutsWeb.war class loader | Includes WEB-INF/classes and all JARs in WEB-INF/lib | +-- Axis2Web.war Includes WEB-INF/classes and all JARs in WEB-INF/lib /code re
p The code classloader /code element in your config snippet is nested within code ApplicationDeployment /code , so it corresponds to the application class loader. You probably don't want to modify this element, you probably want to modify the delegation mode of the individual WAR modules. However, if changing this setting is having an effect, then you probably have JARs on the application class loader class path that should actually be within the WEB-INF/lib of your WAR modules.

Best way to convert existing java projects to osgi bundles

p We have an application which is deployed to a WebSphere server running on UNIX, and we are experiencing two issues:
ol li a system hang which recovers after a few minutes - to investigate, we will need the thread dump (javacore). /li li a system hang which does not recover and requires WebSphere to be restarted - to investigate, we will need the thread dump and heap dump. /li /ol
p The problem is: when a system hang occurs, we do not know whether it is issue 1 or 2.
p Ideally we would like to manually generate the thread dump first, and wait to see if the system recovers. If it does not, then we generate the thread dump and the heap dump, before restarting WebSphere.
p I know about the code kill -3 /code (or code kill -QUIT /code ) command. The command would generate thread dump only (if the parameter code IBM_HEAPDUMP=false /code ), or thread dump and heap dump (if code IBM_HEAPDUMP=true /code ). However, code IBM_HEAPDUMP /code has to be set before WebSphere is started and cannot be changed while WebSphere is running.
p Is my understanding correct, regarding the code IBM_HEAPDUMP /code parameter and the code kill -3 /code command?
p Also, is it possible get the logs in the way I described? (i.e. when generating JVM diagnostics, choose whether to generate heap dump or not on the fly)
Is it possible to choose whether to generate heap dump or not on the fly?
unix jvm websphere signals heap-dump

p My Apache configuration:
pre code ProxyPassReverseCookieDomain backend-server proxy-server
ProxyPass / http://backend-server:10039/ ProxyPassReverse / http://backend-server:10039/ /code re
p The problem is, some generated resources contained absolute URIs targeting at backend-server:10039...
p What else should I configure to properly access WebSphere Portal behind reverse proxy?
WebSphere Portal behind reverse proxy and getServerPort()
apache websphere reverse-proxy mod-proxy websphere-portal

p Because I can answer my own questions, here's what the problem was:
p At server-side, portlets and JSPs in WebSphere Portal use code request.getServerHost() /code and code request.getServerPort() /code . To make these methods work behind reverse proxy (which sends code Host: /code header). I had to add:
pre code ProxyPreserveHost On /code re
p to apache configuration and:
pre code com.ibm.ws.webcontainer.extractHostHeaderPort = true trusthostheaderport = true /code re
p additional properties to Web Container in IBM Console: code WebSphere application servers - WebSphere_Portal - Web Container Settings - Web Container - Custom properties /code .
p These properties are described a href="http:/ ic.dhe.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v7r0/topic/com.ibm.websphere.express.doc/info/exp/ae/rweb_custom_props.html#returningtheportnumberfromtherequesthostheaderfirst" rel="nofollow" here /a .

p For example, if IHS/Apache is listening on code https://myserver.com /code and WAS is on code http://192.168.12.34:12345 /code (all ports/hosts fake), then my redirect comes back as code http://myserver.com /code - correct host and port but wrong protocol.

p The approach suggested by Brad is good but I would do it subtle differently.
p In the custom property of the Server JVM, I would add a property Server-Name and specify its value as WAS_SERVER_NAME.
p here is the bread crumb for this:
p Servers - - Process Definition - Java Virtual Machine Custom properties
p Add a new one wiht say ServerName with value ${WAS_SERVER_NAME}
p Every WAS Server instance has this WebSphere Variable set to the name of the Server instance. You don't need to worry about making typos (or similar errors here) and this approach works for all WAS Server.
p You can create a Server with such values set as a template and when you create a new server, these are always present for you.
p HTH

p That can happen if you're using Tomcat 6.0.16 or newer or a fork of it using the same Apache EL parser, like JBoss AS and WebSphere AS. You basically need to tell the Apache EL parser to not coerce the primitives to their defaults by the following VM argument which is supported since Tomcat 6.0.17:
pre class="lang-none prettyprint-override" code -Dorg.apache.el.parser.COERCE_TO_ZERO=false /code re
p This problem is not related to JSF. It doesn't occur on Glassfish, for example.

ol li The code is exactly the same, but the bundle is different. /li li WebSphere Portal Express is designed for small business. /li li WebSphere Portal Enable and WebSphere Portal Extend are for large busniess and for large scale deployment. /li li WebSphere Portal Express installs and configures DB2. /li li WebSphere Portal Enable and WebSphere Portal Extend comes with derby, and you have to configure it with other databases. /li li WebSphere Portal Express has a different license package from WebSphere Portal Enable or WebSphere Portal Extend. /li li The license forbids clustering with WebSphere Portal Express. /li li The license allows clustering with WebSphere Portal Enable and WebSphere Portal Extend. /li li WebSphere Portal Extend is bundled with the Lotus Collaborative Component CDs. /li li WebSphere Portal Enable is not bundled with the Lotus Collaborative Component CDs. /li li WebSphere for Z/OS has different CDs, because it is for mainframes and that is true for both WebSphere Portal enable for Z/OS and WebSphere Portal Extend for Z/OS. /li li When you see the phrase "WebSphere Portal" that means any WebSphere Portal family except that for WebSphere Portal Express or WebSphere Portal for Z/OS. /li /ol

p Our official support for WebSphere is as follows:
p WebSphere 6, 7, and 8 are supported by our ICEfaces 1.8 EE product running on JSF 1.2. br WebSphere 7 and 8 are supported by our ICEfaces 3.0 EE product running on JSF 2.1
p Support for WebSphere 8 was recently added in the latest 1.8 EE release:
p a href="http://res.icesoft.org/releasenotes/icefacesEE-1.8.2.GA_P04-RN.html#Supported_Platforms" rel="nofollow" http://res.icesoft.org/releasenotes/icefacesEE-1.8.2.GA_P04-RN.html#Supported_Platforms /a
p So in your situation, an upgrade to ICEfaces EE 1.8 or ICEfaces EE 3.0 (recommended) would be the required course of action.

p Having the classes in a JAR vs in WEB-INF/classes makes no difference. Either your package name(s) are wrong in the web.xml, something else in your web.xml is configured incorrectly, or your resource classes aren't annotated properly (or, possibly, some WebSphere devilry is at work--I've never used it myself, but I've heard of really strange class path problems with it). If you show a resource class, a full web.xml, and more of the logs around the error, someone might be able to point out what's going wrong.

p I'm running WebSphere App Server 7 connecting to WebSphere MQ. The WebSphere MQ resource adapter has the defaults - maxConnections defaults to 10 and connection concurrency is set to 1. Each queue connection factory you create also has a max connections property that is set to 50. Our application has MDBs using activation specifications (there are actually 12 different MDBs). It will also need to use a queue connection to send a reply for each request.
p Now - the application seems to come up fine even with 12 activation specs used (i.e. the app works ok) even though there are only 10 max connections configured for the resource adapter. Therefore, I have the following questions on the relationship (or lack thereof) of these two settings:
ol li Are the settings on the MQ resource adapter actually used? Or do I just think that 12 requests could be processed in parallel when really only 10 would be? /li li Are the settings on the queue connection factory used for everything, or partially (ex: the response needs to be sent so if a new connection is opened then it will use the queue connection factory's settings [and the resource adapter only applies to the activation specs])? /li li Can I expect a single queue connection to be re-used for the listener and sending of the response (the response goes back to the same MQ queue manager)? /li /ol
WebSphere MQ max connections under WebSphere App Server 7 - which takes precedence?
websphere websphere-mq

p WebSphere has (had?) a Rapid Deploy feature that you can use for "hot" deployments. Essentially it fired up a headless Eclipse for this, but it was much faster than a full EAR build and just as dynamic as going through WTP.
p At the time, we had an Ant task that we used to copy the files over to the WRD directory. I'm not sure how that would work with Maven, but I imagine one could rig up something.

p I suggest using Spring Security for this. We have implemented this exact pattern in WebSphere. The trick is to use the pre-authentication mechanism that Spring Security provides and then define only the authorization rules in the configuration.
pre code http session-management session-fixation-protection="none" custom-filter position="PRE_AUTH_FILTER" ref="preAuthenticationFilter" intercept-url pattern="/j_security_check" filters="none" intercept-url pattern="/ibm_security_logout" filters="none" !-- put authorization intercept-url elements here... -- /http /code re
p You have to define some other beans as well, such as the pre-authenticated filter and a custom entry point, but that's documented here: a href="http://static.springsource.org/spring-security/site/docs/3.0.x/reference reauth.html" rel="nofollow" http://static.springsource.org/spring-security/site/docs/3.0.x/reference reauth.html /a

p Since you didn't specifically mentioned in steps you followed, have you configured your sas.client.props as in the client setup link you have provided?
p You may check RedBook a href="http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/abstracts/sg247771.html?Open" rel="nofollow" Implementing Kerberos in a WebSphere Application Server Environment /a for examples on how to make this configuration, as well as remaining configuration for Application Client.
p Section 13.5 (13.5 Configuring the JEE application client) gives examples for setting up your thick client runtime, including sas.client.props file.

p Within RAD, edit your server definition (double click on WebSphere Application Server in the Servers view). Under the section "Publishing settings for WebSphere Application Server", check "Run server with Resources on Server" (versus within the workspace).
p Restart everything and retry your role mapping.
p Also note that user/group mapping via the WebSphere console is a multi-step process. You must click OK on the "Security role to user/group mapping" after returning from the panel on which you actually map roles. (That is, you must click OK twice to get the role mappings to stick.)

p (I'm using Oracle and JPA (from Java EE 5, WebSphere 7)).
p I have a Project class, Project has a list of Tasks.
p Each Task has a sequence number so I can determine the task's sequential order (Task.seq), and a assigned user (Task.userId), and a String status Task.status ("IN_PROGRESS" or "COMPELTE"). The tasks for a project get "COMPLETED" by their assigned user in their numerical sequence.
p My problem is ... this is the tricky bit ... I need a query that does the following:
p Given a userid, find all Projects where the current task of that project is assigned to the user. (The 'current task' is the first task found in numerical sequence that has a status of "IN_PROGRESS".)
p I'm not great with SQL, and pretty new to JPA -- please help!
p PS. For example, here's the query I'm currently using that gets me all Project objects with the task list populated:
pre code select distinct p from Project p left join fetch p.taskList /code re

p br Let me clarify what is RES because it seems there is a misunderstanding here, it may be me. br RES is used in Ilog terminology to describe multiple things: br - The web interface that allows you to manage your ruleapp. br - The actual application that you deploy on your WebSphere CE (or else) in order to execute the rules. br - The .jar files that allows you to execute the ruleapp locally. br br You, AFAIK, cannot connect RES using a local JAVA application. br What you have coded is calling the rule engine contained in the RES*.jar files in order to execute your ruleapp locally. br There is no way you can use your JAVA application like you are using your EJB application. br You have to use a webservice or else which is feasible if you put the ruleapp name as a parameter of the web service for instance. br You are using miniloan so you probably know the example using the web interface where you can tell which version of the ruleset to use. br It will be the same if you want to programmatically manage your ruleapp deployed on RES (real application on your application server) you will need to use MDB. Nothing else. br br It is disapointing, I know because I went through that, but there is no way I know (at least) to do that. This is not the behaviour you have to follow. br br To make it work then put your ruleapp in the classpath (or root of your JAVA application in eclipse) and run it... Then you will execute your rules. br br RES doesn't provide the same tools than RTS where you can access RTS from any JAVA application in order to manipulate your rule project. br br You are 100% correct there is no way to tell the J2SE connection what is the server URL and hence no way to run your rules from the server. br Hope it helps.

p That is true.
p A non-official way to get IBM JDK 7 is to download and install a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/downloads/ws/was/" rel="nofollow" WebSphere 8 /a for Windows platform (trial version) and a href="http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg27004980#ver80" rel="nofollow" latest fix pack /a because it may contain JDK updates too.
p As a result, you will find IBM JDK 7 in code AppServer/java7 /code directory you can zip and copy to any other Windows system whatever its underlying hardware. No registration key required, you just have to add bin into your code PATH /code and eventually set code JAVA_HOME /code environment variable.
p Of course, that operation works and it is mainly used for developer workstations but you have to contact IBM if you expect to get support about running productively JDK 7 on Windows.

p Spring Security offers a comprehensive, container-neutral approach that I have successfully used on both WebSphere and Tomcat (particularly building / testing on Tomcat and deploying on WebSphere).
p What I really like about the framework is that it gives you an application-centric, source-neutral view of the current user and their authorities in the application. So that means that you can load the user and the authorities from anywhere, and only the configuration need be concerned with where it comes from (LDAP, database, property file, in-memory testing object, SAML assertion, etc.)
p It also gives you a lot of fine-grained authorization control (URL-based and method based) that you simply don't have defined in Java EE Security. You can use regular expressions and Ant-style expressions for pattern matching that you wouldn't otherwise have. The expression syntax is also quite rich. If you need to do data-specific access control, DDL is provided for you to add to your database and integrate directly into your security.
p Spring Security runs as a filter to all of your requests to the web container using the "/*" URL mapping (or whichever mapping you choose to secure).

p strong Using JNDI data sources. /strong
p em Referred from Spring in Action: /em
blockquote p Spring applications will quite often be deployed to run within a JEE application server such as WebSphere, JBoss, or even a web container like Tomcat. These servers allow you to configure data sources to be retrieved via JNDI. The benefit of configuring data sources in this way is that they can be managed completely external to the application, leaving the application to simply ask for a data source when itâ€™s ready to access the database. Moreover, data sources managed in an application server are often pooled for greater performance and can be hot-swapped by system administrators. /blockquote
p Sample applicationContext-dataSource.xml:
pre code ?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"? beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:jee="http://www.springframework.org/schema/jee" xsi:schemaLocation=" http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans-2.0.xsd http://www.springframework.org/schema/jee http://www.springframework.org/schema/jee/spring-jee-2.0.xsd"
!-- D A T A S O U R C E S -- jee:jndi-lookup id="dataSource" jndi-name="jdbc/myDatasource" resource-ref="true" /beans /code re
p Hope this helps.

p I'm working on a project using JSF 1.2 deploying a portlet to WebSphere Portal Server 6.1 on top of WAS 7. For various contractual olitical reasons, we're stuck with JSF 1.2.
p However. we are using Spring beans throughout our application in order to get AoP logging.
p It is somewhat annoying that we can't use JSF 2.0. In particular, view scope would be ideal for our app. It will be a high usage site and keeping all the page beans in session scope is wasteful and I'm sure will cause raised eyebrows from our non-functional testing team later on.
p It occurred to me that I could emulate View Scope by using Spring's custom scope and a custom JSF component that simply maintains a map of active beans set by the Spring scope and attaching this component on our pages. Together with a custom variable resolver that can find beans in this map, we should be able to emulate view scope
p (Our journey is only four pages, but each page has a few postbacks to the same page)
p How does this approach sound? I want to be sure I'm not somehow shooting myself in the foot before I present this to my project colleagues and dash off and start ripping apart the bean code we've already written.
Emulating jsf 2.0 view scope in JSF 1.2 with Spring beans
java spring jsf javabeans

p First, open the response queue. Then pass that object to the set reply-to method on the message. That way the service responding to your request knows where to send the reply. Typically the service will copy the message ID to the correlation ID field so when you send the message, take the message ID you get back and use em that /em to listen on the reply queue. Of course if you use a dynamic reply-to queue even that isn't neessary - just listen for the next message on the queue.
p There's sample code that shows all of this. If you installed to the default location, the sample code lives at code "C:\Program Files (x86)\IBM\WebSphere MQ\tools\jms\samples\simple\SimpleRequestor.java" /code on a Windows box or code /var/mqm/toolsjms/samples/simple/SimpleRequestor.java /code on a *nix box.
p And on the off chance you are wondering "install what, exactly?" the WMQ client install is downloadable for free as a href="http://ibm.co/SupptPacMQC71" rel="nofollow" SupportPac MQC71 /a .

p In a WebSphere cluster, each member receives the exact same application binaries. If you use code AdminApp.update /code to modify a property file in the application, then that change will be pushed to all cluster members.

p I saw a posting in here asking how to set a timeout for strong em sending requests /em /strong to a web service. He used JAXWS-RI 2.1. His problems described that if for some reason the webservice does not respond, the "client just seems to spin it's wheels forever." Here is the link:
p a href="http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2148915/how-do-i-set-the-timeout-for-a-jax-ws-webservice-client" How do I set the timeout for a JAX-WS webservice client? /a
p My problem is a little bit different. When I use a JAXWS-RI 2.1 client to call a vendor's .NET webservice, I get a java.net.SocketTimeoutException: Read Timed Out. The .NET framework they developed the Webservice in has a default TimeOut Property in the WebService class of 1 minute.
p The solution in the stackoverflow url above used the following BindingProviderProperties ((BindingProvider)port).getRequestContext().put(BindingProviderProperties.REQUEST_TIMEOUT, 180000); ((BindingProvider)port).getRequestContext().put(BindingProviderProperties.CONNECT_TIMEOUT, 120000);
p Is there a timeout property in JAXWS for the responseContext? Something like:RESPONSE_TIMEOUT?
p Websphere has these 1. CONNECTION_TIMEOUT: The amount of time WebSphere JAX-WS client would wait to establish a http/https connection (default is 180 seconds) 2. WRITE_TIMEOUT: The amount of time the client would wait to finish sending the request (default is 300 seconds) 3. RESPONSE_TIMEOUT: The amount of time the client would wait to finish receiving the response (default is 300 seconds)
p I am looking for something in JAXWS similar to number 3.
How do I set the response timeout for a webservice from a JAXWS-RI 2.1 client
jax-ws

p What he seem to be describing is the em platform for software /em (I'll leave it open if that is the same thing as the em software platform /em . I do include software service in the Application Infrastructure definition and also include connectivity/networking along with hardware and software as the three foundation corner stones of Infrastructure. Infrastructure is the general purpose commodity components as opposed to the domain specific components which will typically always be Software; (A possible exception would be an organisation uses custom hardware). AIH; a href="https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/mydeveloperworks/wikis/home/wiki/We98b8e939a26_4de1_8977_6a608ae3fc43 age/WebSphere%20Application%20Infrastructure%20Summit?lang=en" rel="nofollow" IBM pitch WebSphere as Appliction Infrastructure /a and Microsoft Consider their a href="http://download.microsoft.com/download/8/5/3/8533724A-1F88-4F19-AB49-690EF9AB3EEB/Gartner-Microsoft%20joint%20newsletter%20-%20Next-generation%20Application%20Infrastructure.pdf" rel="nofollow" Windows Server to the Application Infrasture /a both agree with you and I.

p EL 2.2 is not part of JSF 2.0. It's part of Servlet 3.0 which in turn is part of Java EE 6. But WebSphere 7 is a Java EE 5 container, not a Java EE 6 one. JSF 2.0 is part of Java EE 6 but backwards compatible with Servlet 2.5 / Java EE 5, that's probably where your confusion is coming from.
p As said, WebSphere 7 is a Servlet 2.5 container and thus doesn't ship with EL 2.2, but with EL 2.1. Your best bet is to install an EL 2.1 implementation which supports the same enhancements (invoking methods with arguments) as in EL 2.2. There's only one: a href="http://docs.jboss.org/seam/latest-2/reference/en-US/html/elenhancements.html" rel="nofollow" JBoss EL /a . To install it, just drop a href="https://maven.atlassian.com/content/repositories/jboss-releases/org/jboss/seam/jboss-el/2.0.0.GA/jboss-el-2.0.0.GA.jar" rel="nofollow" jboss-el.jar /a in webapp's code /WEB-INF/lib /code and add the following context parameter to code web.xml /code to tell MyFaces to use it instead.
pre code context-param param-name org.apache.myfaces.EXPRESSION_FACTORY aram-name param-value org.jboss.el.ExpressionFactoryImpl aram-value /context-param /code re

p Spring doesn't provide transaction support; it merely ties into existing mechanisms (JTA, local transactions, mock transactions). So you're at the mercy of whatever underlying transaction you're using.
p If you're in an application server, some of them allow parallel processing to be performed within the container. A container-managed thread pool has the advantage of propogating container resources (JNDI Contexts, transactions, etc.) to other threads.
p WebSphere and WebLogic, for instance, use the WorkManager API: a href="http://www.devx.com/Java/Article/28815/0" rel="nofollow" http://www.devx.com/Java/Article/28815/0 /a though I seem to recall that Java EE 6 now has support for thread pools (not sure about this, though).

p Environment: WebSphere Portal v7.0, IBM RationalÂ® Software Architect Version: 8.0.4, JSR 286, JSF 1.2, Richfaces 3.3.
Richfaces portlet | FacesContext not found
java jsf richfaces portlet websphere-portal

p We do all our rewrite rules in the fronting web server (in our case, IBM HTTP Server). See these articles for how to do that:
ul li a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/httpserv/ihsdiag lugin_alter_uri.html" rel="nofollow" http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/httpserv/ihsdiag lugin_alter_uri.html /a /li li a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/httpserv/ihsdiag/rewrite.html" rel="nofollow" http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/httpserv/ihsdiag/rewrite.html /a /li /ul
p Note particularly the code [PT] /code flag.
p I don't know of any way to create rewrite rules within WebSphere itself. You may require a web filter like a href="http://code.google.com /urlrewritefilter" rel="nofollow" http://code.google.com /urlrewritefilter /a

p Grizzly is the HTTP connector. Glassfish uses a fork of Tomcat's engine (Catalina) as servlet container. An easy evidence is checking the stacktrace when some exception occurs in your business code. You'll see code org.apache.catalina.* /code deep down in the trace, between the code com.sun.grizzly.* /code lines and the lines of your own business code. It typically look like this:
pre code ... at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardWrapper.service(StandardWrapper.java:1542) at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardWrapperValve.invoke(StandardWrapperValve.java:281) at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardContextValve.invoke(StandardContextValve.java:175) at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardPipeline.doInvoke(StandardPipeline.java:655) at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardPipeline.invoke(StandardPipeline.java:595) at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardHostValve.invoke(StandardHostValve.java:161) at org.apache.catalina.connector.CoyoteAdapter.doService(CoyoteAdapter.java:331) at org.apache.catalina.connector.CoyoteAdapter.service(CoyoteAdapter.java:231) at com.sun.enterprise.v3.services.impl.ContainerMapper$AdapterCallable.call(ContainerMapper.java:317) at com.sun.enterprise.v3.services.impl.ContainerMapper.service(ContainerMapper.java:195) at com.sun.grizzly.http.ProcessorTask.invokeAdapter(ProcessorTask.java:849) at com.sun.grizzly.http.ProcessorTask.doProcess(ProcessorTask.java:746) at com.sun.grizzly.http.ProcessorTask.process(ProcessorTask.java:1045) at com.sun.grizzly.http.DefaultProtocolFilter.execute(DefaultProtocolFilter.java:228) at com.sun.grizzly.DefaultProtocolChain.executeProtocolFilter(DefaultProtocolChain.java:137) at com.sun.grizzly.DefaultProtocolChain.execute(DefaultProtocolChain.java:104) at com.sun.grizzly.DefaultProtocolChain.execute(DefaultProtocolChain.java:90) at com.sun.grizzly.http.HttpProtocolChain.execute(HttpProtocolChain.java:79) at com.sun.grizzly.ProtocolChainContextTask.doCall(ProtocolChainContextTask.java:54) at com.sun.grizzly.SelectionKeyContextTask.call(SelectionKeyContextTask.java:59) at com.sun.grizzly.ContextTask.run(ContextTask.java:71) at com.sun.grizzly.util.AbstractThreadPool$Worker.doWork(AbstractThreadPool.java:532) at com.sun.grizzly.util.AbstractThreadPool$Worker.run(AbstractThreadPool.java:513) at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:680) /code re
p Glassfish is not the only which uses Catalina by the way, JBoss AS and IBM WebSphere also use it.

p I finally got this working.
p As I was expecting I was missing just some small configuration :)
pre code property name="hibernateProperties" props prop key="hibernate.dialect" org.hibernate.dialect.Oracle10gDialect rop prop key="hibernate.transaction.factory_class" org.hibernate.transaction.CMTTransactionFactory rop prop key="hibernate.transaction.manager_lookup_class" org.hibernate.transaction.WebSphereExtendedJTATransactionLookup rop rops roperty /code re
p I found these configuration options earlier while browsing, but for some reason they didn't work when I tried them. Probably I had something else wrong at that time... (see a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/techjournal/0609_alcott/0609_alcott.html" rel="nofollow" Transaction strategy configuration /a chapter)
p Thank you all for trying to help!

h1 Context /h1
p I need to measure HTTP request took over the network in a JavaScript web application connected to a Java backend (Servlet). The "total network duration" is computed as the total request duration from the client side (includes client- server communication, server processing, server- client communication), minus the server processing duration. Thus, the "total network duration" includes the following parts:
ul li HTTP request sending by the browser (may include request queuing) /li li Protocol stack for sending on the client (HTTP, TCP/IP, ...) /li li strong Wire communication client- server /strong (e.g. Ethernet network) /li li Protocol stack for receiving on the server (HTTP, TCP/IP, ...) /li li HTTP request reception by the application server (may include request queuing) /li li Protocol stack for sending on the server (HTTP, TCP/IP, ...) /li li strong Wire communication server- client /strong (e.g. Ethernet network) /li li Protocol stack for receiving on the client (HTTP, TCP/IP, ...) /li li HTTP request reception by the browser /li /ul
p In the general case, most of total duration in the wire duration. But in some cases, the "total network duration" for a given query is high and your network administrator shows you some stats where the wire communication is very low. In that case, the "total network duration" is consumed in the other elements above. In my specific case, I suspect the application server (WebSphere 7) to put the HTTP request in a waiting queue because the HTTP connection pool is full.
h1 Question /h1
p When the application server's HTTP connection pool is full, each incoming HTTP request is put in a waiting state into an "incoming HTTP request queue". The application server has configuration parameters used to tune this behavior (HTTP connection pool size, incoming HTTP request wait timeout, ...), but this is not the point here.
p strong How to get the HTTP request waiting time, i.e. when the HTTP request is processed by a Java Servlet or Filter or RequestListener, how to determine how much time the application server delayed the HTTP request when waiting for a free thread in the HTTP connection pool ? /strong
p The ideal solution would be to use an hypothetical application server API (in this case: which one, and ideally for WebSphere 7?). Alternatively, I thought about a HTTP proxy between the network and the application server. This proxy will add a timestamp header on the incoming HTTP request (e.g. "X-Request-Reception-Time = time in milliseconds "), so that I can determine time taken by the application server by doing "HTTP request Servlet start processing timestamp" - "X-Request-Reception-Time".
How to get HTTP request wait time when the application server's HTTP connection pool is full
java http time connection-pooling

p Hibernate does not use Log4J directly. This is why your messages are falling into WebSphere SystemOut.log file.
p Up to version 3.2, hibernate used Jakarta Commons Logging as a logging facade. From version 3.3 and above, it switched to SLF4J (Simple Logging Facade for Java). As jakarta commons logging (JCL), SLF4J is just a facade, often binding to other Logging Frameworks, like Java Logging or, in this case, Log4J itself.
p I understand your application already uses Log4J. I'm also assuming you're using Hibernate 3.3 or a newer version.
p The first thing is to add SLF4J support to your project. You do that by adding these dependencies (with Ivy, Maven or however you want):
p strong slf4j-api.jar /strong (Core SLF4J packages)
p strong slf4j-log4j12.jar /strong (Binds SLF4J to Log4J)
p This way, when Hibernate logs some message, SLF4J will capture it and route it to Log4J.
p Now, when it comes up to your own app code, you have two approaches.
p 1: Keep your classes directly interacting to Log4J classes (namely Logger and LoggerFactory)
p This way, you keep your classes directly referencing Log4J Logger, like this:
pre code Logger logger = Logger.getLogger("com.foo"); // from package org.apache.log4j /code re
p So, in short, Hibernate will use SLF4J - Log4J and you will use directly Log4J
p 2: The second approach is to have your code use SLF4J as well. This isn't so big a change, as you'll probably have to change just one line of code in each of your classes that produces log messages:
pre code Logger logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger("com.foo"); // from package org.slf4j /code re
p If you are using an older version of Hibernate (3.2 or older), you'll have to trick It not to use Jakarta Commons Logging. First, you'll have to purge commons-logging JAR files from your dependencies (either manually or with an exclusion, if you use any dependency manager). Then you'll have to add an SLF4J port of commons-logging to your classpath:
p add strong jcl-over-slf4j-x.y.z.jar /strong (x.y.z being its version. I use strong jcl-over-slf4j-1.6.1.jar /strong , for example).
p This jar has the exact classes and packages of old commons-logging.jar, thus effectively tricking all commons-logging dependent applications to log to SLF4J in fact.

p I use WebSphere 7.0 in my organization. I did use Jquery with JSF to accomplish some tasks. Because a lot of these frameworks don't work well with WebSphere. And a lot others need a lot of customization which my admin will never allow. Also the interface language is Arabic which makes another set of these frameworks useless to me. One other reason is that you may need it for one specific task which doesn't need you to overload your application with one of these frameworks since they add hooks and stuff into the lifecycle which may affect the scalability of your pages. But you have to note that working with these frameworks makes life a lot easier than working jsf with jquery to do the same task. br In the end, it's your call.

p Why is my JConsole with WebSphere 6.1 not refreshing JMX information? I can connect at any point in time and see the snapshot of how many threads and classes are loaded but the JConsole is not refreshing and showing me updated information. I tried to set the time scale to "10 minutes".
p Here is how I configured it:
blockquote ol li p Next, you need to edit the "Generic JVM arguments" of your server (via the administrative console at: Servers -- Application servers server1 Process definition Java and Process Management Java Virtual Machine) :
p -Djavax.management.builder.initial= -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.port=9099 -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.authenticate=false -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.ssl=false /li /ol
p This modifies the well-hidden server.xml file to have these JVM options. The resulting "Generic JVM Options" should now be: "-agentlib:getClasses -Djava.awt.headless=false -Djava.awt.headless=false -Djavax.management.builder.initial= -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.port=9099 -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.authenticate=false -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.ssl=false"
ol li p Start jconsole from your WAS_HOME/java/bin directory and login with localhost:9099, as defined in your jmx.properties file (Note: not recommended for production use, since security is disabled for that port). /li li p Youâ€™re done. Have a look at the threads, the memory consumption, the mbeans etc. /li /ol /blockquote
Why is my JConsole with WebSphere 6.1 not refreshing JMX information?
java websphere jmx websphere-6.1

p I solved it.
p There are four things to do:
ol li Say that OpenJpa logs the statements. That is done by the property entry in the persistence.xml. /li li Say Slf4j that it has to fetch the logs from JUL too. This can be done by installing the SLF4JBridgeHandler by SLF4J. I installed the bridge via a ServletContextListener which is called at application start. /li li Configure Logback that it does not log ALL logs from JUL but only the needed Logs. This is done by adding the LevelChangePropagator in the logBack-test.xml /li li Ask the WebSphere TraceService to hand down the logs from OpenJPA to the application. This is a setting in the WebSphere Administration Console /li /ol

p WebSphere 7 runs Java EE 5 (I think), so your choices are little bit limited in that regard.
p You can use a library like a href="http://quartz-scheduler.org/" rel="nofollow" Quartz Scheduler /a , but you have to be careful to hook it up to a thread pool which is managed by the container. I believe by default it just creates threads on its own which is outright prohibited in EJBs (and strongly discouraged in the web container).
p I found a nice blog post that walks you through the configuration of setting up a work manager pool on WebSphere: a href="http://sanjsuya.wordpress.com/2012/01/19/asynchronousbean-was-spring-integration/" rel="nofollow" http://sanjsuya.wordpress.com/2012/01/19/asynchronousbean-was-spring-integration/ /a
p If you're using Spring, you can then hook up the Quartz scheduler to this thread pool fairly easily using a WorkManagerTaskExecutor. Here's some Spring documentation on that (note, it's from Spring 2, but I'm sure you more-or-less do something like this for Spring 3 as well): a href="http://static.springsource.org/spring/docs/2.0.x/reference/scheduling.html" rel="nofollow" http://static.springsource.org/spring/docs/2.0.x/reference/scheduling.html /a
p EDIT: the architect in me is cringing slightly (though maybe you have a good reason for doing it the way you're doing it). Why are you writing e-mails to a DB and not to a queue? That way, they could be processed at the leisure of a receiving system, and you're not overloading a whole lot of background work onto WebSphere.

p The error means that JAVA_HOME in your shell used to invoke Ant is different from the Java that was included with the embedded WebSphere Application Server. Try using the WAS_HOME/bin/ws_ant script, or set JAVA_HOME to WAS_HOME/java/.

p Is it possible you don't actually need that at all if you're using IHS and the WebSphere plugin? a href="http://www-304.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21292700" rel="nofollow" This article seems to indicate you may only need that option if you're using Apache /a instead of IHS.

p IBM JVMs definitely support the Java interface java/lang/Compiler.disable() and .enable() which was introduced in Java 5, I believe. That includes WebSphere Real Time (which is a JVM designed to provide more predictable performance) as well as our "standard" JVMs. If you call disable(), it will prevent JIT compilations until you call enable().
p I work for IBM on the JIT compiler team. We don't usually recommend people to use this interface, because interfering with JIT compilation heuristics is generally not a good idea, but there are reasonable real-time scenarios where you would use it.

p Are you certain it's WebSphere holding the port? If you've stopped all the WebSphere processes, especially if you've stopped them normally, I can't imagine that it is still holding the port.
p On AIX, you can see which process is holding the port with a href="http://www-304.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21264632" rel="nofollow" the combination of netstat and rmsock described here /a (or a href="http:/ ortal2portal.blogspot.com/2011/06/aide-memoire-remembering-how-to.html" rel="nofollow" if you have lsof installed, that's even easier /a .)

p Please see the WebSphere Security Redbook chapter 4 for details - a href="http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/redbooks dfs/sg246316.pdf" rel="nofollow" http://www.redbooks.ibm.com/redbooks dfs/sg246316.pdf /a CONFIG_ROOT is a substitution variable, so you should be fine - a href="http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/iadthelp/v6r0/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.ws.ast.st.v6.doc/topics/tsubvarv6.html" rel="nofollow" http:/ ublib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/iadthelp/v6r0/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.ws.ast.st.v6.doc/topics/tsubvarv6.html /a . You can test which certificates are enabled using openssl from the command line - a href="http://www.cyberciti.biz/faq/test-ssl-certificates-diagnosis-ssl-certificate/" rel="nofollow" http://www.cyberciti.biz/faq/test-ssl-certificates-diagnosis-ssl-certificate/ /a

p I think you could use message grouping for this case. That way, you can group messages in one batch, given the sender has set the grouping headers. Here is info on how ActiveMQ handles this: a href="http://activemq.apache.org/message-groups.html" rel="nofollow" ActiveMQ on Message Grouping /a
p I'm no ruby coder, but I assume you are using some "on_message" function when you talk about event driven API. IBM has a nice tutorial how to do receive JMS message groups in a message listener (MDB). It's java and WebSphere MQ, but the JMS concept should be consistent. br a href="http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/library/techarticles/0602_currie/0602_currie.html#listing5" rel="nofollow" IBM on JMS message grouping in MDB /a
p You might or might not be able to translate that into rails, but it might give some hints while waiting for the correct code sample to show up here! :)

p Short: (Portlet-)Container swallows Exception thrown by @PostConstruct method in backing bean.
p Is this behavior intentional, a bug or container specific?
p Long: I am running a portlet on WebSphere Portal 7, where i force managed bean construction in a PhaseListener so it can send the user back to the start page, when the system encounters unrecoverable problems during Bean construction ost-construction.
p I am using the following code to 'force' construction:
pre code @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") public static T T getManagedBean(final String beanName) { final FacesContext context = getFacesContext(); return (T)context.getApplication().evaluateExpressionGet(context, "#{" + beanName + "}", Object.class); } /code re
p I tested throwing a RuntimeException from the @PostConstruct method
pre code @PostConstruct public void initialize() { throw new RuntimeException("test"); } /code re
p The stacktrace ends up on the RAD(Eclipse) log:
pre code com.ibm.ws.webcontainer.annotation.WASAnnotationHelper doInvoke unable to invoke method -- [initialize] on class -- [foo.bar.UpdateAddress] java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:60) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:37) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:611) at com.ibm.ws.webcontainer.annotation.WASAnnotationHelper.doInvokeSingle(WASAnnotationHelper.java:432) at com.ibm.ws.webcontainer.annotation.WASAnnotationHelper.doInvokeChain(WASAnnotationHelper.java:400) at com.ibm.ws.webcontainer.annotation.WASAnnotationHelper.doPostConstruct(WASAnnotationHelper.java:220) at com.sun.faces.vendor.WebSphereInjectionProvider.invokePostConstruct(WebSphereInjectionProvider.java:86) at com.sun.faces.mgbean.BeanBuilder.invokePostConstruct(BeanBuilder.java:225) ... Caused by: java.lang.RuntimeException: test at foo.bar.UpdateAddress.initialize(UpdateAddress.java:119) ... 121 more /code re
p But there is no exception to catch in my PhaseListener and it happily continues without being aware of an Exception during the @PostConstruct.
p Is this behavior intentional, a bug or container specific?
p It looks like at least JBoss has a similar way of handling : a href="http://www.coderanch.com/t/499013/JSF/java ostConstruct-exception-handling" rel="nofollow" http://www.coderanch.com/t/499013/JSF/java ostConstruct-exception-handling /a
behavior for @PostConstruct exception handling in WebSphere
java jsf websphere-7 websphere-portal postconstruct

p The code applications /code path under the Dmgr profile contains the files that have been deployed in the admin console.
p The code installedApps /code path under the Node profile contains those files after they've been synchronized out to each node. In most cases, this will be immediately after the deployment as well.
p The safest practice would be to deploy a single file using the admin console, rather than editing it in-place on the filesystem.
p That said, it is faster to edit on the filesystem, so we do that at times especially for like JSPs. To do that, you need to edit the copy under the Node's code installedApps /code directory.
p code web.xml /code , however, is different (at least on WebSphere 6.1). If you edit that in code installedApps /code , the changes won't take effect. Instead, you'll need to edit the one in a path something like:
p code $NODEPROFILE_HOME/config/cells/cellName/applications/earName.ear/deployments/applicationName/warName.war/WEB-INF /code
p Or do it in the $DMGRPROFILE_HOME and then synchronize the node (either through syncNode.sh or through the admin console).
p Either way, you'll then need to restart the enterprise application.

pre code MQQueue mqQueue = new MQQueueManager(queueName, props); /code re
